TITLE: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin tests positive for COVID-19
SUMMARY: Austin, 68, tested positive on Sunday. He said that his symptoms are mild, and he was fully vaccinated and boosted in October. He plans to continue with key meetings virtually during quarantine.

TITLE: This photographer captured how activists helped migrants at the Poland-Belarus border
SUMMARY: Polish-based photographer Kasia Strek documented what it was like for migrants and people in Poland as the crisis evolved at the border in November.

TITLE: FDA authorizes a Pfizer booster shot for children ages 12 to 15
SUMMARY: The agency also shortened the time between the completion of primary vaccination of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine and a booster dose, down to five months from six.

TITLE: The last living parent of a child killed in the 1963 Birmingham church bombing dies
SUMMARY: Maxine McNair's 11-year-old daughter, Denise McNair, was the youngest of the four Black girls killed in the bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church in 1963. She died Sunday at 93.

TITLE: With COVID outbreaks, Broadway's understudies take center stage
SUMMARY: Breakthrough infections from the omicron variant have been spreading like wildfire among casts and crews, so understudies and swing performers have been helping keep shows afloat.

TITLE: 6 questions for politics in 2022
SUMMARY: From control of Congress and the strength of the Biden presidency to potential Jan. 6 committee revelations and the future of abortion rights, there's a lot at stake in 2022.

TITLE: 6 in 10 Americans say U.S. democracy is in crisis as 'The Big Lie' takes root
SUMMARY: A year after the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, a new NPR/Ipsos poll finds that Americans are pessimistic about the future of democracy, as false claims about the 2020 election persist.

TITLE: Why your local library might be hiring a social worker
SUMMARY: Libraries in some cities are investing in staff members who can help patrons with complex issues such as housing insecurity, finding mental health and more.

TITLE: A year after Capitol Police's darkest day, its chief says the force is making gains
SUMMARY: Capitol Police Chief Tom Manger has been on the job less than six months. He hopes to lead a new chapter at the embattled agency.

TITLE: Seoul: North Korea defector likely made rare border crossing back
SUMMARY: A person who crossed the border from South Korea into North Korea on New Year's Day was likely a defector who had made the trip in the other direction in late 2020, the military said Monday.

TITLE: Quebec begins retail store closures amid new COVID-19 wave
SUMMARY: Quebec proceeded with the first of three planned closures of non-essential retail stores Sunday as the government tries to curb a new wave of COVID-19 driven by the highly infectious Omicron variant.

TITLE: Another Hong Kong news site shuts as pro-Beijing lawmakers sworn in
SUMMARY: A Hong Kong online news site said Sunday that it will cease operations in light of deteriorating press freedoms, days after police raided a separate pro-democracy news outlet, arresting seven.

TITLE: 2 remain missing after the Colorado fire. Survivors are counting their blessings
SUMMARY: The missing persons toll has dropped after one person was found alive. Residents who escaped the flames that destroyed some 1,000 homes returned to sort through what was left.

TITLE: Weekend storms bring damage to parts of Southern U.S.
SUMMARY: Severe storms took out power and destroyed homes in Alabama, hours after heavy rain and tornadoes tore through Kentucky. Several Alabama counties are under a tornado watch through early Monday.

TITLE: Sudan's prime minister announces his resignation amid political deadlock
SUMMARY: Abdalla Hamdok said Sunday that he will step down amid widespread protests condemn a military coup that derailed Sudan's shift to democratic rule. Over 50 protesters have died since the October coup.

TITLE: A federal court just released the settlement deal between Epstein and Giuffre
SUMMARY: The settlement between Jeffrey Epstein and Virginia Giuffre, one of his accusers, is emerging less than a week after his longtime partner Ghislaine Maxwell was found guilty of sex trafficking a minor.

TITLE: Famed fossil hunter and conservationist Richard Leakey dies at 77
SUMMARY: Leakey made important contributions to our understanding of human origins through his fossil finds. He later gained fame for taking on poachers who threatened to wipe out Kenya's elephants and rhinos.

TITLE: The FDA authorizes a Pfizer booster shot for children ages 12 to 15
SUMMARY: The authorization comes in the midst of an explosion of COVID-19 cases nationwide driven by the omicron variant — a surge that has brought a spike in pediatric hospitalizations.

TITLE: 2022 will be a tense year for Facebook and social apps. Here are 4 reasons why
SUMMARY: Social media companies will feel pressure from Washington, European regulators and even their own users over kids' safety and privacy, competition and election-related misinformation.

TITLE: 700 sheep and goats were arranged in the shape of a needle to encourage vaccinations
SUMMARY: A shepherd in Germany arranged her animals into a 330-foot syringe to encourage people to get vaccinated.

TITLE: New York's attorney general has subpoenaed Ivanka Trump and Donald Trump Jr.
SUMMARY: The subpoenas stem from an ongoing civil investigation into the Trump family's business practices. The former president has also been subpoenaed, and is now suing the attorney general.

TITLE: Schumer tees up vote on rules change if voting rights legislation is blocked
SUMMARY: It's the latest push by Senate Democrats to make good on their promise to pass voting rights legislation.

TITLE: A hockey fan spotted a staffer's suspicious mole from the stands, saving his life
SUMMARY: Kraken fan and future medical student Nadia Popovici alerted Canucks staffer Brian Hamilton to a suspicious mole, which turned out to be cancerous. The teams surprised her with a $10,000 scholarship.

TITLE: Fire reignites at South Africa's Parliament in Cape Town
SUMMARY: The fire started on Sunday and had been contained, but flared up again on Monday after firefighters had been sent home. A man was arrested in connection with the fire.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes trial: Jury is deadlocked on 3 of 11 fraud charges
SUMMARY: After hearing about the impasse, the judge instructed the jury to keep deliberating. Jurors have been debating Holmes' fate for seven days after a trial that has stretched on for four months.

TITLE: New Hampshire's longtime guardian of its early presidential primary is stepping down
SUMMARY: Secretary of State William Gardner, who earned a national reputation as gatekeeper of New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation presidential primary, has held the office since 1976.

TITLE: If you're clinging to an old BlackBerry, it will officially stop working on Jan. 4
SUMMARY: The company behind the once ubiquitous phones has transitioned to a security software focus, and says that starting on Tuesday, its classic devices will no longer reliably function.

TITLE: 700 sheep and goats were arranged in the shape of a syringe to encourage vaccinations
SUMMARY: A shepherd in Germany arranged her animals into a 330-foot syringe to encourage people to get vaccinated.

TITLE: Officials are determined to keep schools open, despite omicron
SUMMARY: As coronavirus cases, and pediatric hospitalizations, surge in the U.S., the majority of U.S. schools are staying open for in-person learning.

TITLE: Texas officials put the final death toll from last year's winter storm at 246
SUMMARY: The Texas Department of State Health Services adjusted the number of people who died from last February's storm to 246 people — up from July's tally of 210.

TITLE: Former Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes is found guilty on 4 counts in her fraud trial
SUMMARY: Holmes, who was once seen as one of the most promising leaders in Silicon Valley, could spend up to 20 years in prison for lying to investors and patients of the blood-testing company.

TITLE: Congress' doctor urges lawmakers to work remotely and upgrade masks as omicron rages
SUMMARY: The move follows an unprecedented spike in positivity rates in the Capitol, and mirrors record-high infection rates throughout Washington D.C., driven by the highly contagious omicron variant.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes verdict: Former Theranos CEO is found guilty on 4 counts
SUMMARY: Holmes, who was once seen as one of the most promising leaders in Silicon Valley, could spend up to 20 years in prison for defrauding investors of the blood-testing company.

TITLE: First Cambodian American mayor in U.S. takes office
SUMMARY: Sokhary Chau said his mother managed to keep her seven children alive for four years, surviving Cambodia's civil war to deliver them safely to the U.S.

TITLE: Teachers are on the front lines in Jan. 6 culture war
SUMMARY: Teachers now are left to decide how — or whether — to instruct their students about the events that sit at the heart of the country's division.

TITLE: Thousands of airline passengers are stranded. Here's what to do if you're one them
SUMMARY: Thousands of flights have been cancelled, leaving travelers scrambling to figure out how book new seats and get reimbursements for added expenses.

TITLE: Western Wall prayer site's future is in doubt under Israel's fragile government
SUMMARY: Israel's refusal to recognize liberal Reform and Conservative streams of Judaism has long been a point of tension with American Jews.

TITLE: Activists urge Tesla to close its new Xinjiang showroom
SUMMARY: Tesla on Friday announced the opening of its showroom in Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang, where officials are accused of abuses against mostly Muslim ethnic minorities.

TITLE: Rep. Jamie Raskin searches for answers in 'Unthinkable' journey of trauma and grief
SUMMARY: In a new memoir, the Democratic congressman recounts a year of loss and grief after the death of son Tommy — and a motivation to right the wrongs that occurred on Jan. 6.

TITLE: Thousands of airline passengers are stranded. Here's what to do if you're one of them
SUMMARY: Thousands of flights have been canceled, leaving travelers scrambling to figure out how to book new seats and get reimbursements for added expenses.

TITLE: These are the numbers health officials are watching at this point in the pandemic
SUMMARY: In the midst of record COVID case numbers in the U.S., biostatistician Natalie Dean walks us through how to assess the metrics.

TITLE: The Washington Football Team will have a new name next month
SUMMARY: Two fan favorites have been ruled out: Team president Jason Wright says that anything involving "Wolves" or "Red Wolves" isn't possible, because of trademark conflicts.

TITLE: Child care is getting more support from some private companies
SUMMARY: Some corporations are trying harder to help provide child care for families.

TITLE: The CDC now recommends Pfizer boosters after 5 months, not 6
SUMMARY: The move to shorten the Pfizer booster interval comes as the U.S. shatters daily case records. The recommended interval for those who received Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccines has not changed.

TITLE: Novak Djokovic gets a vaccination exemption to play in the Australian Open
SUMMARY: The tournament's defending champion posted a photo of himself smiling at an airport. But in Australia, some of the responses to his Twitter post were not happy ones.

TITLE: Drivers have been stuck for hours in freezing temperatures after crashes block I-95
SUMMARY: Jackknifed tractor trailers blocked traffic in both directions along the vital corridor south of the nation's capital. Some people waited 16 hours or more for rescue.

TITLE: More than 1 million Americans were diagnosed with COVID over the long holiday weekend
SUMMARY: The U.S. hit a new record high for infections in a single day on Monday, with 1,082,549 new cases recorded. Hospitalizations are also on the rise, but not at the same rate.

TITLE: Here's where election-denying candidates are running to control voting
SUMMARY: An NPR analysis found at least 15 Republican candidates for Secretary of State offices in 2022 who doubt Joe Biden's 2020 victory.

TITLE: After his son's suicide and the Jan. 6 attack, Rep. Jamie Raskin is not giving up
SUMMARY: Raskin's son died just days before the Capitol insurrection. Now Raskin serves on the House select committee charged with investigating the Jan. 6 attack. His new memoir is <em>Unthinkable

TITLE: The CDC now recommends Pfizer boosters after 5 months, down from 6
SUMMARY: The move to shorten the Pfizer booster interval comes as the U.S. shatters daily case records. The recommended interval for those who received Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccines has not changed.

TITLE: Longtime Chicago Congressman Bobby Rush is the latest Democrat to leave Washington
SUMMARY: The 75-year-old former Black Panther leader won't seek a 16th term in Congress, but vowed he'll remain an activist.

TITLE: Preet Chandi is the first woman of color to complete a solo expedition in Antarctica
SUMMARY: Chandi skiied 700 miles to the South Pole in just 40 days. The British Sikh army officer aims to inspire others to push boundaries, and is also raising funds to start an adventure grant for women.

TITLE: A lawsuit over Nirvana's 'Nevermind' baby album cover has been dismissed
SUMMARY: Judge Fernando M. Olguin dismissed the lawsuit on Monday after Spencer Elden, who appeared naked on the album's cover when he was a baby, failed to meet a court deadline.

TITLE: Car ads in France will soon have to encourage more environmentally friendly travel
SUMMARY: The automakers' ads will suggest people consider carpooling or cycling instead of driving. The new rules, beginning in March, come as the country is trying to cut down on its carbon emissions.

TITLE: The American Kennel Club adds 2 dog breeds, the Hungarian mudi and the Russian toy
SUMMARY: An athletic Hungarian farm dog and a tiny pet of bygone Russian aristocrats are the latest breeds in the American Kennel Club's purebred lineup for 2022.

TITLE: Late-night hosts Jimmy Fallon and Seth Meyers test positive for COVID-19
SUMMARY: The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon and Late Night With Seth Meyers

TITLE: The U.S. charges a former Colombian soldier in Haitian president's assassination
SUMMARY: The U.S. government announced that it charged Mario Antonio Palacios, a 43-year-old former Colombian soldier who is one of the main suspects in the July killing of Haitian president Jovenel Moïse.

TITLE: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope finishes deploying its sunshield amid cheers
SUMMARY: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope successfully finishing tensioning its massive sunshield on Tuesday, marking a critical step in the powerful observatory's zero-gravity deployment.

TITLE: The CDC resists pushback and says a test to get out of COVID isolation is not needed
SUMMARY: Those who contracted COVID-19 can end their isolation after five days while continuing to wear a well-fitting mask for an additional five days, according to the agency.

TITLE: House Jan. 6 committee seeks to question Fox News' Sean Hannity about the Capitol riot
SUMMARY: In its request to speak with Hannity, the panel disclosed newly revealed texts he allegedly sent, including one on Jan. 5 that said: "[I'm] very worried about the next 48 hours."

TITLE: Airbnb's new experiment in combatting rental bias means swapping names for initials
SUMMARY: The project is limited to Oregon users and follows a lawsuit settlement alleging that hosts could discriminate against Black renters based on their names.

TITLE: Officials finally clear up crashes that kept drivers in freezing temperatures on I-95
SUMMARY: Jackknifed tractor-trailers blocked traffic in both directions along the vital corridor south of the nation's capital. Some people waited 16 hours or more for rescue.

TITLE: Chicago public school classes are canceled after teachers union backs remote learning
SUMMARY: The announcement by district officials follows the teachers union voting to switch to remote learning due to the latest COVID-19 surge. The status of classes for the rest of the week remains in limbo.

TITLE: Virginia officials defend response to snowy gridlock on I-95
SUMMARY: There was plenty of outrage from motorists, some of whom were stranded overnight Monday into Tuesday, posting pleas for help on social media.

TITLE: Israel sets COVID-19 record as rule changes create whiplash
SUMMARY: The omicron variant is outpacing the government's ability to make and execute clear pandemic public policy.

TITLE: A year after the Capitol riot, work remains to safeguard it from another attack
SUMMARY: The Jan. 6 siege led to a transformation of security for the citadel of democracy and members of Congress. But many say plenty of work remains to ensure another attack never happens again.

TITLE: When facing loss, embrace change and don't force closure, a therapist urges
SUMMARY: Over the last two years, many have experienced a kind of ambiguous loss as we have lived with isolation and uncertainty in the pandemic. Author and therapist Pauline Boss explains how to move forward.

TITLE: Xi'an reacts to COVID lockdowns with outrage and humor
SUMMARY: Lockdowns are so strict and so prolonged in Chinese city that residents have taken to social media to complain and joke about a lack of basic supplies.

TITLE: A year after the Capitol riot, work remains to prevent another attack
SUMMARY: The Jan. 6 siege led to a transformation of security for the citadel of democracy and members of Congress. But many say plenty of work remains to ensure another attack never happens again.

TITLE: Residents of Xi'an, China, react to COVID lockdowns with outrage and humor
SUMMARY: Lockdowns are so strict and so prolonged in the Chinese city that residents have taken to social media to complain and joke about a lack of basic supplies.

TITLE: Airbnb's new experiment to combat rental bias uses initials instead of names
SUMMARY: The project is limited to Oregon users and follows a lawsuit settlement alleging that hosts could discriminate against Black renters based on their names.

TITLE: The CDC says a test to get out of COVID isolation is not needed, resisting pushback
SUMMARY: Those who contracted COVID-19 can end their isolation after five days while continuing to wear a well-fitting mask for an additional five days, according to the agency.

TITLE: Hong Kong bans flights from U.S. and 7 other countries as omicron surges
SUMMARY: Hong Kong authorities announced a two-week ban on flights from eight countries and held 2,500 passengers on a cruise ship for coronavirus testing as the city attempted to stem an omicron outbreak.

TITLE: Theranos whistleblower celebrated Elizabeth Holmes verdict by 'popping champagne'
SUMMARY: Theranos whistleblower Tyler Shultz reflects on Elizabeth Holmes' jury verdict. These days, he is the one making exaggerated claims to investors.

TITLE: Cheers erupt after James Webb Space Telescope deploys huge sunshield. Next up? Mirrors
SUMMARY: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope successfully deployed its massive sunshield Tuesday, a critical step in the powerful observatory's unfolding. It begins deploying its secondary mirror Wednesday.

TITLE: A Philadelphia house fire killed 13 people, including 7 children
SUMMARY: "Losing so many kids is just devastating," Mayor Jim Kenney said. The four smoke alarms in the building did not appear to have been working, fire officials said.

TITLE: France's Macron takes heat after saying he wants to 'piss off' the unvaccinated
SUMMARY: The French president made the remarks to a newspaper on Tuesday, causing opposition lawmakers to call a halt to debate on a new nationwide mandate.

TITLE: A Philadelphia man is free after serving 37 years because of a false witness
SUMMARY: Willie Stokes, 61, was freed in a murder case marred by detectives who allegedly offered a witness sex and drugs at police headquarters in 1983 in exchange for false testimony.

TITLE: Australian P.M. says Djokovic will be turned back if his vaccine exemption is bogus
SUMMARY: "If he's not vaccinated, he must provide acceptable proof that he cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons," Prime Minister Scott Morrison said of the top-ranked tennis player.

TITLE: The global supply chain is amazingly efficient. So why did it break down?
SUMMARY: "Americans went on a shopping spree as soon as lockdown started, and we haven't really stopped," journalist Christopher Mims says. His book, <em>Arriving Today

TITLE: GMO is out, "bioengineered" is in, as new U.S. food labeling rules take effect
SUMMARY: A new national standard is meant to give consumers clarity about how their food was produced, but critics say the rules will introduce more confusion and don't go far enough.

TITLE: A Texas team comes up with a COVID vaccine that could be a global game changer
SUMMARY: Peter Hotez and Maria Elena Bottazzi used an oldie-but- goodie technology to devise a vaccine that's easy to make — and relatively cheap. India has already ordered 300 million doses.

TITLE: 126 years after the 'separate but equal' ruling, Homer Plessy will be pardoned
SUMMARY: Plessy was arrested trying to board a "whites-only" train car. The Supreme Court's decision in Plessy v. Ferguson ushered in an era of laws that kept schools, housing and other venues segregated.

TITLE: 8 ways teachers are talking about Jan. 6 in their classrooms
SUMMARY: A year after a pro-Trump mob invaded the U.S. Capitol, teachers say they want students to grapple with the uncomfortable facts of the day.

TITLE: American Girl's 1st Chinese American 'Girl of the Year' doll aims to fight AAPI hate
SUMMARY: American Girl hopes Corinne Tan's story will teach kids about standing up to racism. It's also partnering with the nonprofit AAPI Youth Rising to "help amplify young voices like Corinne's."

TITLE: Remembering Edward O. Wilson, a conservation advocate who studied ant colonies
SUMMARY: A pioneer in the field of evolutionary biology, Wilson explored the complex cooperation among ants, including the role of natural in their colonies. He died Dec. 26. <em>Originally broadcast in 1994.

TITLE: GMO is out, 'bioengineered' is in, as new U.S. food labeling rules take effect
SUMMARY: A new national standard is meant to give consumers clarity about how their food was produced, but critics say the rules will introduce more confusion and don't go far enough.

TITLE: 126 years after the 'separate but equal' ruling, Homer Plessy is pardoned
SUMMARY: Plessy was arrested trying to board a "whites-only" train car. The Supreme Court's decision in Plessy v. Ferguson ushered in an era of laws that kept schools, housing and other venues segregated.

TITLE: The Grammys are postponed and Sundance is moved online because of omicron surge
SUMMARY: A new date has not been announced for the Grammys. Sundance events begin Jan 20.

TITLE: This heroic dog traversed the interstate to lead police to her injured owner
SUMMARY: What started as a report of a dog loose on the highway ended with the timely rescue of two injured humans. One-year-old Tinsley, a Shiloh Shepherd, is getting praise and extra treats for her heroism.

TITLE: Merrick Garland vows to keep following leads to hold Jan. 6 rioters accountable
SUMMARY: In a speech delivered Wednesday, the attorney general said the Justice Department "will follow the facts wherever they lead. ...The actions we have taken thus far will not be our last."

TITLE: A Missouri county asks for help designing a new seal after old one turns heads online
SUMMARY: The current St. Francois County seal, designed in 2018 by a county commissioner who says he is "not artistically inclined," was upvoted thousands of times on Reddit's "CrappyDesign" forum.

TITLE: An Afghan girls soccer team rebelled to play the game they love. Now they're refugees
SUMMARY: The teenagers on the Afghan girls national soccer team lean on each other as they adjust to a new life in Portugal, where they fled after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from the Capitol riot criminal cases, one year later
SUMMARY: NPR has been tracking every criminal case related to the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. One year after the riot, here are some of the key patterns that have emerged from the cases.

TITLE: Unionized Starbucks workers walk out in Buffalo, citing safety worries over COVID
SUMMARY: Employees of a Starbucks store in upstate New York who voted to unionize last month walked off the job, saying they lacked the staff and resources to work safely amid surging COVID-19 cases.

TITLE: They believe in Trump's 'Big Lie.' Here's why it's been so hard to dispel
SUMMARY: The resilience of the "Big Lie" is prompting consternation and creative efforts to reach those who remain adamant — despite all evidence to the contrary — that the 2020 Presidential vote was rigged.

TITLE: Children as young as 12 should get Pfizer COVID-19 booster vaccines, CDC advisers say
SUMMARY: If the CDC approves the advisory panel's recommendation, boosters for adolescents age 12-17 could be available as early as this week. The shots should be given five months after initial immunization.

TITLE: Here's what you should keep in your car and other ways to prepare for winter driving
SUMMARY: Having an emergency kit filled with first aid supplies, water and snacks is an important first step to keeping safe, and sane, if you find yourself stuck on the road. A well-maintained car helps, too.

TITLE: The oldest living American veteran of World War II dies at 112
SUMMARY: Lawrence Brooks served in the U.S. Army when the military was still racially segregated. But the Black soldier's deployment to Australia offered a reprieve from the racism of Jim Crow laws at home.

TITLE: CDC recommends Pfizer COVID booster for kids as young as 12
SUMMARY: The new recommendation for adolescents age 12-17 came hours after a panel of CDC advisers voted in favor of it. The boosters should be given five months after initial immunization.

TITLE: California extends its indoor mask mandate until February as omicron surge continues
SUMMARY: So far, nearly 80% of California residents have been vaccinated with at least one dose of the COVID vaccine. The extended statewide mask mandate is set to expire on Feb. 15.

TITLE: North Korea claims second successful test of hypersonic missile
SUMMARY: North Korea claimed Thursday to have conducted the second successful test flight of a hypersonic missile. Wednesday's launch was the North's first known weapons test in about two months.

TITLE: China lashes out at US for supporting Lithuania in feud with Beijing over Taiwan
SUMMARY: China lashed out at the United States over its support for the Baltic nation of Lithuania in its feud with Beijing over relations with Taiwan.

TITLE: A year after the Jan. 6 attack, Congress is plagued by a toxic atmosphere
SUMMARY: Distrust between the parties is high a year after the violent insurrection. And it has impacted how the institution operates.

TITLE: Where the investigation into the Jan. 6 insurrection stands, one year later
SUMMARY: Officials say the probe is one of the largest and most resource-intensive investigations in American history. More than 700 people have been charged already.

TITLE: One year after Jan. 6, signs of a nation deeper in peril
SUMMARY: A year after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, a growing realization that traditional tools to counter extremism in the U.S. may not apply.

TITLE: President Biden is expected to blame Trump for the Capitol riot in a Jan. 6 speech
SUMMARY: In a speech at the Capitol marking the riot's one-year anniversary, Biden will lay out "the singular responsibility President Trump has for the chaos and carnage," said press secretary Jen Psaki.

TITLE: China lashes out at U.S. for supporting Lithuania in feud with Beijing over Taiwan
SUMMARY: China lashed out at the United States over its support for the Baltic nation of Lithuania in its feud with Beijing over relations with Taiwan.

TITLE: Russia-led alliance troops have arrived in Kazakhstan after mass protests
SUMMARY: Russia-led alliance troops arrived in Kazakhstan on Thursday after increasingly chaotic and violent protests rocked the nation for days and resulted in dozens of people killed and hundreds injured.

TITLE: A murder warrant has been issued over the fatal shooting of rapper Young Dolph
SUMMARY: The first-degree murder warrant was issued for Justin Johnson, 23, in the Nov. 17 shooting of Young Dolph, who was gunned down in a daylight ambush at a popular cookie shop in November in Memphis.

TITLE: Watch: President Biden blames Trump for the Capitol riot in a Jan. 6 speech
SUMMARY: Biden is marking the anniversary with a speech at the Capitol in which he strongly condemned the violence and said Trump "has created and spread a web of lies about the 2020 election."

TITLE: Where the Jan. 6 insurrection investigation stands, one year later
SUMMARY: Officials say the probe is one of the largest and most resource-intensive investigations in American history. More than 700 people have been charged already.

TITLE: Coronavirus FAQ: When to test, what kind of test to use, what to do with the results
SUMMARY: We answer key questions about COVID tests: What types are there? Should you self-test right after exposure to someone with COVID? And what should you do if you test positive?

TITLE: One year after the Jan. 6 insurrection, signs of a nation deeper in peril
SUMMARY: A year after the attack on the Capitol, there's a growing realization that traditional tools to counter extremism in the U.S. may not apply.

TITLE: President Biden blasts Trump for 'spreading a web of lies' in a Jan. 6 speech
SUMMARY: Biden never uttered Trump's name but referred repeatedly to him with forceful and at times personal denunciations of his actions. "He's not just a former president. He's a defeated former president."

TITLE: A man who allegedly stole hundreds of unpublished book manuscripts now faces charges
SUMMARY: For nearly five years, Filippo Bernardini allegedly impersonated people in the book publishing industry, stealing unpublished manuscripts and notes, including from a Pulitzer Prize winner.

TITLE: Morgan Wallen and Adele topped music sales in 2021, according to a year-end report.
SUMMARY: Albums by Wallen and Adele were the top sellers of 2021, according to MRC Data and Billboard's annual tally. Other findings: audio on-demand streaming soared, and sales of vinyl outpaced CDs.

TITLE: Sister of slain security officer sues Facebook over killing tied to Boogaloo movement
SUMMARY: It is latest attempt to hold a Big Tech company responsible for harm caused in the real world that allegedly was fueled by a social media platform.

TITLE: COVID testing FAQ: When to test, what kind of test to use and what your results mean
SUMMARY: We answer key questions about COVID tests: What types are there? Should you self-test right after exposure to someone with COVID? And what should you do if you test positive?

TITLE: Republicans criticize Ted Cruz for calling Jan. 6 a violent terrorist attack
SUMMARY: "Of all the things that Jan. 6 was, it was definitely not a violent terrorist attack," Fox News commentator Tucker Carlson said in reply to Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas.

TITLE: Read President Biden's Jan. 6 speech in full
SUMMARY: Biden blasted former President Donald Trump in an address from the U.S. Capitol on the anniversary of the insurrection.

TITLE: How Dan Bongino is building a right-wing media infrastructure in time for 2024
SUMMARY: <em>New Yorker

TITLE: 'The Last Picture Show' director Peter Bogdanovich has died at 82
SUMMARY: Writer, director, actor and lifelong cinephile Peter Bogdanovich has died. He directed the Oscar-nominated movie The Last Picture Show, along with Paper Moon, They All Laughed and What's Up Doc.

TITLE: Short-staffed and COVID-battered, U.S. hospitals are hiring more foreign nurses
SUMMARY: Montana's largest hospital recently signed employment contracts with two dozen foreign nurses. Nationwide, a backlog of 5,000 international nurses await approval to enter the U.S.

TITLE: Kicked off Facebook and Twitter, far-right groups lose online clout
SUMMARY: In the year since the January 6th Capitol attack, far-right influencers and extremists are taking new approaches to organizing online.

TITLE: Tampa Bay Buccaneers release Antonio Brown after Sunday's mid-game walkout
SUMMARY: After Sunday's game, Buccaneers head coach Bruce Arians told media that Antonio Brown was "no longer a Buc," due to his third-quarter walkout in the team's game against the New York Jets.

TITLE: What we know about the symptoms — and the severity — of the omicron variant
SUMMARY: Researchers are looking at data from U.S. cases to determine if the variant causes milder disease. Even if the answer is yes, they say, rates of hospitalization could be high during the surge.

TITLE: For many Afghans, winter is forcing a cruel choice of whether to eat or stay warm
SUMMARY: "It shouldn't be a lottery of life about who gets to eat, who doesn't get to eat. Do I keep my child warm or do I give my child food?" a World Food Programme Afghanistan spokesperson tells NPR.

TITLE: How tennis star Novak Djokovic ended up in Australian immigration detention
SUMMARY: After months of speculation over whether the vaccine-skeptical star would take part in the Australian Open, Djokovic seemed set to play — then border officials revoked his visa, leaving him in limbo.

TITLE: An Uber rider who got stuck in the Virginia traffic jam ended up with a $600 bill
SUMMARY: Andrew Peters was stuck on I-95 for nine hours this week after snow and ice caused tractor-trailers to jackknife on the interstate, making the road impassable. By Thursday, Uber had offered a refund.

TITLE: The Mid-Atlantic and Northeast are bracing for several more inches of snow
SUMMARY: Heavy snow rolled through Tennessee and Kentucky on Thursday, and was expected to hit several states across the northeast next.

TITLE: Japan approves new restrictions for areas hard hit by COVID
SUMMARY: Japan has undergone periods of similar restrictions over the past two years. This time, the spread of the omicron variant appears to be first hitting prefectures that house the U.S. military.

TITLE: The leader of Kazakhstan says constitutional order 'mainly restored' amid unrest
SUMMARY: The president of Kazakhstan on Friday declared that constitutional order was "mainly restored" but "terrorists are still using weapons and are damaging people's property" and would be dealt with.

TITLE: U.S. women ski jumpers won't compete in the Beijing Olympics after failing to qualify
SUMMARY: Women ski jumpers fought for more than a decade to compete in the Olympics. Now the U.S. women's team has failed to qualify for Beijing.

TITLE: The Western megadrought is revealing America's 'lost national park'
SUMMARY: A famed desert landscape has re-emerged as water levels in Lake Powell reservoir have fallen to record lows. It's raising questions about the future of this oasis, and water in the American West.

TITLE: The immovable Republican Party and 'ink-blot politics'
SUMMARY: Several of the key facts of the Jan. 6 insurrection are indisputable. And yet millions on the right do dispute them. Here's a look at how that happened.

TITLE: Why some cities are operating legal homeless camps even in the dead of winter
SUMMARY: Facing worsening homelessness and sprawling illegal encampments, some American cities are resorting to setting up regulated, outdoor shelters even in the dead of winter.

TITLE: What it really takes to keep schools open during the omicron surge
SUMMARY: Schools are just starting to get regular access to testing; teachers are still paying out of pocket for masks and air purifiers; and qualified substitutes and bus drivers can be hard to find.

TITLE: Employers added only 199,000 jobs in December even before omicron started to surge
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added 199,000 jobs in December as the unemployment rate fell to 3.9%, marking a second consecutive month of disappointing numbers.

TITLE: U.S. women's ski jumpers won't compete in the Beijing Olympics. They failed to qualify
SUMMARY: Women's ski jumpers fought for more than a decade to compete in the Olympics. Now the U.S. women's team has failed to qualify for Beijing.

TITLE: Rare Toni Morrison short story to be published this month
SUMMARY: "Recitatif," written by Morrison in the early 1980s, follows the lives of two women from childhood to their contrasting fortunes as adults.

TITLE: Watch live: 3 white men who killed Ahmaud Arbery face life in prison
SUMMARY: A judge is handing down the sentences in a Glynn County courtroom Friday, about six weeks after a jury found them guilty in a high-profile case that is widely seen as racially motivated.

TITLE: A pub that let people buy beers for Betty White will now donate the money to charity
SUMMARY: The Golden Girl had a golden ale named for her at the pub in Mineral Point, Wis. Now the brewery is using its "buy a beer for a friend" system to support animal charities in White's honor.

TITLE: To quell unrest, Kazakhstan's president authorizes forces to shoot to kill
SUMMARY: President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev opened the door for a dramatic escalation in a crackdown on anti-government protests that have turned violent.

TITLE: What crying baby mice could teach us about human speech
SUMMARY: Scientists have found a cluster of rhythmic brain cells in newborn mice that may explain why spoken languages around the world share a common tempo.

TITLE: FDA shortens the wait time between Moderna vaccine and booster to 5 months
SUMMARY: Now, both the Pfizer and the Moderna booster shots can be given five months after the second dose of vaccine — down from six months.

TITLE: Photos: Dramatic scenes from Kazakhstan's massive protests and crackdown
SUMMARY: Here are some of the images of the unrest this week in the former Soviet republic of Kazakhstan, where the authoritarian government is fighting to quash large public protests.

TITLE: Kids are back in school — and struggling with mental health issues
SUMMARY: This school year was supposed to bring a return to normalcy. But the stress of transitioning back to in-person learning and the ever-changing pandemic has caused a surge in mental health needs.

TITLE: A fire that destroyed a Planned Parenthood building was intentionally set
SUMMARY: The New Year's Eve fire that caused a "total loss" of the Planned Parenthood building in Knoxville, Tenn., has been ruled an arson, investigators say.

TITLE: Supreme Court conservatives appear skeptical of vaccine-or-test mandate for businesses
SUMMARY: Business groups, 27 states and some individuals have questioned the authority of the Occupational Safety and Health Agency to impose a nationwide rule.

TITLE: The key to Nelson Mandela's Robben Island prison cell is returning to South Africa
SUMMARY: New York auction house Guernsey's has postponed the sale of some of the South African leader's belongings, including the key to his cell and the shirt he wore when he was released from Robben Island.

TITLE: Global wishes for 2022: a gift box for everyone, greater girl power, vertical gardens
SUMMARY: We asked global thinkers like Malala, doctors dealing with the pandemic, educators and more — if you were in charge of the world, what would you like to see happen this year.

TITLE: Supreme Court conservatives seem skeptical of vaccine-or-test mandate for businesses
SUMMARY: Business groups, 27 states and some individuals have questioned the authority of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to impose a nationwide rule.

TITLE: All 3 white men convicted of Ahmaud Arbery's murder are sentenced to life in prison
SUMMARY: Travis McMichael, who pulled the trigger, and his father, Greg, have no chance for parole. A federal hate crimes trial remains in a case widely seen as racially motivated.

TITLE: Prosecutors detail warning signs missed by parents of Mich. school shooting suspect
SUMMARY: The parents of the Michigan school shooting suspect ignored numerous warning signs that included hallucinations, animal torture and obsession over guns and Nazi propaganda, prosecutors say.

TITLE: Jan. 6 panel chair says committee will ask Mike Pence to voluntarily appear
SUMMARY: The chair of the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack says they'll ask former Vice President Mike Pence to testify by month's end. They may also request testimony from Ivanka Trump.

TITLE: CDC is criticized for failing to communicate, promises to do better
SUMMARY: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention held only two telebriefings in 2021. That lack of transparency has prompted criticism — and a pledge from director Dr. Rochelle Walensky to be more open.

TITLE: The chair of the Jan. 6 panel says the committee will ask Mike Pence to appear
SUMMARY: The chair of the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack says they'll ask former Vice President Mike Pence to testify by month's end. They may also request testimony from Ivanka Trump.

TITLE: Supreme Court's conservatives cast cloud over vaccine-or-test mandate for businesses
SUMMARY: Justices seemed more open to the vaccine mandate for almost all workers at hospitals, nursing homes, and other medical providers receiving federal Medicare and Medicaid funds.

TITLE: All 3 white men convicted of murdering Ahmaud Arbery are sentenced to life in prison
SUMMARY: Travis McMichael, who pulled the trigger, and his father, Greg, have no chance for parole. A federal hate crimes trial remains in a case widely seen as racially motivated.

TITLE: Pacific Northwest storm causes flooding and landslides and shuts roads
SUMMARY: Parts of Washington state's two major highways, Interstate 90 and Interstate 5, were closed, and flooding swamped roads and closed schools in parts of Oregon.

TITLE: Officer blames bad information for 2020 sinking that killed 9 Marines
SUMMARY: A three-officer panel will issue a recommendation as to whether a decorated officer should be considered for discharge just shy of his 20-year mark and be denied retirement benefits.

TITLE: A South Korean village is protesting U.S. plans for THAAD missile defense upgrades
SUMMARY: The potential upgrade at a U.S. air defense base, within range of missiles in North Korea and China, has residents concerned as Seoul walks a delicate balancing act between the rival powers.

TITLE: Tallest Galapagos volcano erupts, spewing lava and ash
SUMMARY: Ecuador's Emergency Operations Committee said the eruption on Isabela Island didn't represent a risk to humans or to native local species.

TITLE: Djokovic's lawyers say he had COVID last month, according to report
SUMMARY: If he fails to have his visa cancellation overturned and gets deported, Djokovic risks missing more than one Australian Open and could be barred for up to three years.

TITLE: There's chaos in Kazakhstan. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: A New Year's Day doubling of gas prices sent shock waves through the country, sparking deadly unrest that has engulfed the Central Asian nation. But the origins of discontent run much deeper.

TITLE: Congress may change this arcane law to avoid another Jan. 6
SUMMARY: Lawmakers passed the Electoral Count Act in 1887 after a contested election, and experts say they did a "terrible job." There may now be bipartisan support for a refresh.

TITLE: How Bosnia's Dodik went from a moderate reformist to genocide-denying secessionist
SUMMARY: Bosnian Serb leader responds to new U.S. sanctions saying the days when the U.S. and other Western democracies "modeled Bosnia to their taste" are long gone.

TITLE: Top global TikToks of 2021: Defiant Afghan singer, Kenya comic, walnut-cracking elbow
SUMMARY: What did the world watch on TikTok last year? We round up some favorite videos — including a mukbang ASMR Thai star (don't worry, we explain it) and a potato chip-crunching Kenyan comedian.

TITLE: In Pakistan, 22 die in subfreezing temperatures as their cars are stuck in heavy snow
SUMMARY: Most of the victims died of hypothermia, officials said, as overnight temperatures fell to 17.6 Fahrenheit amid heavy snowfall at Pakistan's mountain resort town of Murree.

TITLE: Kazakhstan's former anti-terror chief is arrested over protests
SUMMARY: Karim Masimov has been arrested on charges of attempting to overthrow the government following violent protests that the president has blamed on foreign-backed terrorists.

TITLE: Djokovic's lawyers say he had COVID last month, grounds for vaccination exemption
SUMMARY: If he fails to have his visa cancellation overturned and gets deported, Novak Djokovic risks missing more than one Australian Open and could be barred for up to three years.

TITLE: Turkmenistan's leader wants 'Gates of Hell' fire put out
SUMMARY: The president of Turkmenistan is calling for an end to one of the country's most notable but infernal sights — a natural gas crater that has burned for decades.

TITLE: John Thune, No. 2 Senate GOP leader, announces he will seek reelection
SUMMARY: The South Dakota Republican, a likely successor to Republican leader Mitch McConnell, says he will run for reelection in 2022, putting an end to the speculation about his political future.

TITLE: NASA's James Webb telescope completes its final unfolding in space
SUMMARY: Considered the most powerful telescope in space, the James Webb telescope has completed its deployment process. It will still be five months before NASA can start receiving its images.

TITLE: Coast Guard issues new safety rules stemming from 2019 boat fire that killed 34
SUMMARY: The fire aboard the Conception off Santa Barbara marked the deadliest marine disaster in modern state history and led to criminal charges and calls for tougher regulations for small passenger boats.

TITLE: Amy Schneider is the first woman to win more than $1 million on 'Jeopardy!'
SUMMARY: Since her record-breaking run began on Nov. 17, Schneider has won 28 consecutive victories and become just the fourth person to top $1 million in regular-season earnings.

TITLE: Wisconsin Republican Sen. Ron Johnson is running for reelection
SUMMARY: The controversial Republican said he will seek a third term, in what is expected to be a hotly contested race that could determine which party controls the Senate.

TITLE: Britney Spears left her guardianship, but others who want independence remain stuck
SUMMARY: If a judge rules a person can't make their own decisions, the next step can be a legal guardianship or conservatorship.  Some states allow less restrictive options, but advocates say it's not enough.

TITLE: Scientists vacuum zoo animals' DNA out of the air
SUMMARY: Researchers who detected that detecting environmental DNA, or eDNA, in two zoos say the technique could one day be used to look for endangered species in remote locations in the wild.

TITLE: Shoba Narayan's fight for South Asian representation began long before Jasmine
SUMMARY: Cast as <em>Aladdin

TITLE: A wall of rock fell on boaters in a Brazilian lake, killing 6
SUMMARY: A towering slab of rock broke from a cliff and toppled onto pleasure boaters drifting near a waterfall in a Brazilian lake Saturday.

TITLE: Biden, Obama among those to eulogize Senate titan Harry Reid at memorial service
SUMMARY: "In a town obsessed with appearances, Harry had a real vanity deficit. He didn't like phonies. He didn't like grandstanding. He was proud of the fact that he didn't own a tuxedo," said Obama.

TITLE: Michael Lang, a co-creator of the Woodstock festival, has died at 77
SUMMARY: Lang helped make Woodstock a defining moment of the 1960s. He once called it "a test of whether people of our generation really believed in one another and the world we were struggling to create."

TITLE: 22 tips for 2022: If you want to succeed, choose your failures — in advance
SUMMARY: If you feel like you're always running behind on your task list and can never quite get enough done, it's probably because you've got too much to do. Try strategic underachievement.

TITLE: Classes for Chicago students are in limbo as teachers, mayor wrangle over omicron
SUMMARY: Teachers began refusing to show up for their jobs in-person on Wednesday amid skyrocketing COVID-19 cases, prompting the cancellation of classes for more than 300,000 public school students.

TITLE: Actor and comedian Bob Saget dies at 65
SUMMARY: Saget was a prominent presence on American television screens throughout the 1990s as the father Danny Tanner on Full House and the host of America's Funniest Home Videos.

TITLE: Neither side is optimistic ahead of U.S.-Russia talks over Ukraine
SUMMARY: The U.S. and its European allies want Russia to reduce troop buildup along the Ukraine border. Russia wants U.S. troops out of Eastern Europe. Both sides say those demands are non-starters.

TITLE: A fire in a Bronx apartment building leaves 19 dead, including 9 children
SUMMARY: The blaze, caused by a malfunctioning space heater, injured more than 60 people in all. "This is a horrific, horrific, painful moment for the city of New York," Mayor Eric Adams said.

TITLE: Death toll rises to 10 after a wall of rock fell on boaters in a Brazilian lake
SUMMARY: A towering slab of rock broke from a cliff and toppled onto pleasure boaters drifting near a waterfall in a Brazilian lake Saturday. Dozens were injured.

TITLE: Djokovic's visa is reinstated but his Australian Open status remains unclear
SUMMARY: Australia's immigration minister could still "exercise a personal power of cancelation," which would mean mean Djokovic could face deportation again and miss the tournament, which starts on Jan. 17

TITLE: Myanmar's Suu Kyi sentenced to 4 more years in prison
SUMMARY: Suu Kyi was convicted last month on two other charges and given a four-year prison sentence, which was then halved by the head of the military-installed government.

TITLE: On COVID vaccinations, Pope says health care is a 'moral obligation'
SUMMARY: Francis says individuals have a responsibility to care for themselves "and this translates into respect for the health of those around us."

TITLE: Djokovic's visa is reinstated, but his Australian Open status remains unclear
SUMMARY: The tennis star, who sought a COVID-19 vaccine exemption to play in the tournament, could face deportation again. The battle has sparked protests in the widely vaccinated country.

TITLE: U.S. greenhouse gas emissions jumped in 2021, a threat to climate goals
SUMMARY: The spike was attributed to a slew of causes, including behavior changes after COVID-19 vaccines became widely available, but environmental advocates say it's worrisome.

TITLE: Michaela Jaé Rodriguez from 'Pose' is the 1st trans actress to win a Golden Globe
SUMMARY: While Sunday night's Golden Globes were not televised, Rodriguez gave an acceptance speech on Instagram Live in which she thanked those who worked on the show and spoke of paving the way for others.

TITLE: Imagine another American Civil War, but this time in every state
SUMMARY: If America has another civil war, it is more likely to be a war within the states than between them. Citizens of any state of any size, red or blue, may not have to go far to find a fight.

TITLE: A plane crashed, then was smashed by a train. Its pilot was rescued just in time
SUMMARY: A Los Angeles police officer's body-cam video captured the dramatic sequence, showing police and a bystander working to free the man from the wreckage.

TITLE: New York revises the death toll in fatal Bronx fire to 17, including 8 children
SUMMARY: City officials had said on Sunday that 19 people perished in the fire, including nine children.

TITLE: Bob Saget's co-stars and fellow comedians are remembering his humor and kindness
SUMMARY: John Stamos, Norman Lear and Whoopi Goldberg are among those paying tribute to the actor and comedian, who was found dead in an Orlando hotel room on Sunday at age 65.

TITLE: Robert Durst, real estate heir, dies in prison at 78
SUMMARY: Durst was sentenced in October to life in prison for killing Susan Berman and indicted in November for second-degree murder in his wife Kathie's death.

TITLE: Bob Saget pushed boundaries in his stand-up shows
SUMMARY: Bob Saget was found dead Sunday night at age 65. Many remember him for his roles on TV. But he was most at home by himself, on stage, telling often-raunchy and boundary-pushing jokes.

TITLE: How the current COVID surge is hurting learning and kids' mental health
SUMMARY: Thousands of schools around the country have once again shifted to remote learning as COVID cases rise. It's taking a huge toll on children.

TITLE: The U.S. and Russia tackle growing tensions over Ukraine
SUMMARY: The U.S and Russian deputy foreign ministers kick off a week of talks, hoping to ease tensions over Ukraine, which Russia is threatening with a troop build-up near their shared border.

TITLE: Voting rights groups speak out ahead of Biden and Harris' trip to Georgia
SUMMARY: Nsé Ufot, CEO of the New Georgia Project, speaks with NPR's Ailsa Chang about her view of Democrats' voting rights efforts ahead of the president and vice president's visit to Georgia this week.

TITLE: White House adviser discusses U.S. coronavirus testing shortages
SUMMARY: New White House testing adviser Dr. Tom Inglesby talks to NPR's Ari Shapiro about COVID testing shortages in the U.S. and the Biden administration's efforts to increase access, including at-home kits.

TITLE: Mexican American writer Henry Barajas brings history into his work
SUMMARY: Graphic novelist Henry Barajas is finding success by incorporating Mesoamerican history — and his own family's past — into his work.

TITLE: Staffing crisis is slamming California hospitals
SUMMARY: California hospitals are calling in the National Guard to help with a staffing crisis. So many nurses and other health care workers are out with COVID that administrators can't fill necessary shifts.

TITLE: The UAE attempts to overhaul harsh criminal and financial laws
SUMMARY: The United Arab Emirates has been criticized for human rights violations but is now overhauling its laws to ease up on some social and economic restrictions.

TITLE: Vindman discusses U.S. options on Russia-Ukraine tensions
SUMMARY: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks to Alexander Vindman, former director for European affairs at the United States National Security Council, about how the U.S. might deter Russia from invading Ukraine.

TITLE: A growing problem in public health is getting people to heed advice
SUMMARY: As COVID cases surge, many Americans are tuning out the pandemic. Public health messages and guidance are running into widespread indifference and disengagement.

TITLE: Officials investigate deadly Bronx fire that killed 17 people
SUMMARY: A day after a fire killed 17 people and injured dozens at an apartment building in the Bronx, residents try to regroup. An investigation is underway.

TITLE: Russia digs in on Ukraine never joining NATO, on a day of talks with the U.S.
SUMMARY: "For us, it's absolutely mandatory to make sure that Ukraine never, never, ever becomes a member of NATO," Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said.

TITLE: Doctors transplant a genetically modified pig heart into a human for the 1st time
SUMMARY: While it's too soon to know if the operation really will work, it marks a step in the decades-long quest to one day use animal organs for life-saving transplants.

TITLE: How to get insurance to pay for at-home COVID tests, according to the White House
SUMMARY: The Biden administration says Americans should be able to order COVID tests online later this month. Those who are eligible can get eight free over-the-counter at-home tests a month.

TITLE: The president of Mexico says he has COVID for a 2nd time
SUMMARY: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador wrote that he tested positive, after he had sounded hoarse at a morning news briefing. He contracted COVID-19 and recovered from it the first time in early 2021.

TITLE: Speed skater Erin Jackson lost a chance at gold — until her teammate stepped in
SUMMARY: Speed skater Brittany Bowe relinquished her spot on the U.S. Olympic team for the 500 meter speed skating event to give her teammate, Jackson, a shot at gold.

TITLE: For this Latinx graphic novelist, superheroes can be real. They can even be family
SUMMARY: Graphic novelist Henry Barajas is finding success by incorporating Mesoamerican history — and his own family's past — into his work.

TITLE: Chicago union leaders approve a plan to return to in-person classes
SUMMARY: Both sides had been locked in a standoff that canceled classes for four days in the nation's third-largest district. The full deal still requires approval by the union's full 25,000 members.

TITLE: The poet Maya Angelou is the first Black woman to be featured on a U.S. quarter
SUMMARY: The Maya Angelou design is the first quarter in the "American Women Quarters Program" — a four-year program that will feature prominent women in U.S. history.

TITLE: Georgia snaps a 41-year title drought with a 33-18 win over Alabama
SUMMARY: The final blow came from Georgia's dominant defense. Kelee Ringo intercepted an underthrown deep ball and took off for a 79-yard touchdown.

TITLE: Imagine another American Civil War, but this time in every state
SUMMARY: If America has another civil war, it is more likely to be a war within the states than between them. Citizens of any state of any size, red or blue, may not have to go far to find a fight.

TITLE: North Korea launches another suspected missile amid stalled talks with the U.S.
SUMMARY: Some experts say North Korea may have tested its purported hypersonic missile again in response to the South Korean military playing down a previous test.

TITLE: Djokovic gets some court time in Australia as leaders discuss his visa
SUMMARY: The prime ministers of Australia and Serbia talked by phone about the tennis star's visa as he is seeded No. 1 in Australian Open.

TITLE: Biden will 'forcefully advocate' for protecting voting rights in Atlanta speech
SUMMARY: The president has been under increasing pressure to more aggressively combat threats to voting rights. And advocates say speeches are not a substitute for legislative action.

TITLE: EU Parliament President David Sassoli dies at age 65
SUMMARY: The Italian journalist had been hospitalized since Dec. 26 due to abnormal functioning of his immune system.

TITLE: Cyber risks add to climate threat, World Economic Forum warns
SUMMARY: Survey of 1,000 experts and leaders finds cybersecurity and space add to the existing challenges of climate change and the coronavirus pandemic.

TITLE: Who gets to use NASA's James Webb Space Telescope? Astronomers work to fight bias
SUMMARY: With the James Webb Space Telescope safely deployed, many scientists want to use it. To minimize the effect of unconscious biases, they go through a process developed for the Hubble Space Telescope.

TITLE: People hate overdraft fees. Capital One is ditching them and other banks may follow
SUMMARY: One of the nation's biggest banks says it will stop charging overdraft fees to all of its customers. These hefty fees hit people with low incomes the hardest. More banks could follow suit.

TITLE: Legendary reporter Carl Bernstein revisits early career in 'Chasing History'
SUMMARY: It would have been easy for the famous journalist to fall into the nostalgia trap with his memoir, which chronicles his earliest years in the newspaper business. Happily, he doesn't.

TITLE: U.S. COVID hospitalizations hit new record high, raising risks for patients
SUMMARY: There are more patients and, in some places, not enough health care workers to go around. Research shows the crowding will impact care and increase mortality for all patients.

TITLE: Biden is expected to back changing the filibuster to pass voting rights bills
SUMMARY: The president has been under increasing pressure to more aggressively combat threats to voting rights. And advocates say speeches are not a substitute for legislative action.

TITLE: Welcome to the era of omicron rules and regs
SUMMARY: As the highly transmissible variant spreads rapidly around the world, some countries have reimposed harsh COVID measures like those seen in the early days of the pandemic.

TITLE: Legendary reporter Carl Bernstein revisits his early career in 'Chasing History'
SUMMARY: It would have been easy for the famous journalist to fall into the nostalgia trap with his memoir, which chronicles his earliest years in the newspaper business. Happily, he doesn't.

TITLE: The house from 'A Nightmare on Elm Street' just sold for nearly $3 million
SUMMARY: Even Freddy Krueger might be frightened by today's hyper-competitive housing market.

TITLE: Extreme weather in the U.S. cost 688 lives and $145 billion last year, NOAA says
SUMMARY: In an on overview published ahead of its full report, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that 2021 ranked the third costliest on record for such events.

TITLE: Israeli scientists have trained goldfish to drive, in a scene out of a Dr. Seuss book
SUMMARY: An experiment involving a robotic tank on wheels and six trained goldfish may offer insights into animals' ability to navigate unfamiliar environments.

TITLE: A potentially deadly risk to kids prompts 3 companies to recall in-home elevators
SUMMARY: Bella Elevator, Inclinator Company of America and Savaria Corporation recalled about 69,000 elevators that pose a risk of pinning children between the elevator car door and the exterior landing door.

TITLE: A court upheld the firing of 2 LAPD officers who ignored a robbery to play Pokémon Go
SUMMARY: A California court denied the appeal of Louis Lozano and Eric Mitchell, who were fired from the Los Angeles Police Department after the 2017 incident. Their lawyer says they're evaluating next steps.

TITLE: The Justice Department will create a domestic terrorism unit to counter rising threats
SUMMARY: The announcement was made Tuesday by Matthew Olsen, the head of the department's National Security Division, and comes as the nation faces a constellation of extremist threats on the home front.

TITLE: Why United Arab Emirates is relaxing laws on sex, marriage, liquor, vapes and more
SUMMARY: The UAE is overhauling laws on an array of business, cultural and social norms. On paper, it makes the emirate one of the region's most progressive countries, but critics say the reality is complex.

TITLE: People hate overdraft fees. Banks are ditching or reducing them
SUMMARY: Capital One says it will stop charging overdraft fees and Bank of America is reducing them<strong>.

TITLE: Magawa, a heroic bomb-sniffing rat who is credited with saving lives, has died
SUMMARY: "His contribution allows communities in Cambodia to live, work, and play; without fear of losing life or limb," the nonprofit APOPO said after the death of Magawa, an African giant pouched rat.

TITLE: Biden will focus in on voting rights and election integrity in Atlanta speech
SUMMARY: The president is expected to speak to the importance of election integrity as a means to preserving democracy and also back changing the filibuster to make it easier to pass voting rights bills.

TITLE: The Red Cross says there's a blood shortage nationwide. Here's how you can help
SUMMARY: A combination of the pandemic and severe weather have disrupted planned blood drives and caused a drop in donations.

TITLE: Journalist Ida B. Wells is commemorated with a Barbie doll for fearless activism
SUMMARY: Wells was a writer and anti-lynching campaigner who edited and co-owned the <em>Memphis Free Speech

TITLE: Boris Johnson is in hot water for hosting a BYOB party during the U.K.'s 2020 lockdown
SUMMARY: On the date of the prime minister's party, the country's COVID restrictions meant that people were required to remain in their homes and away from others unless they had a "reasonable excuse."

TITLE: United says 3,000 employees have COVID, but its vaccine mandate has saved lives
SUMMARY: In a memo to employees, United CEO Scott Kirby said the airline has 3,000 employees who are currently positive for Covid but that zero of its vaccinated employees are currently hospitalized.

TITLE: A medical helicopter carrying an infant crashed near a church; everyone survived
SUMMARY: The pilot crash landed the aircraft, which was carrying four people, without casualties in a residential area of suburban Philadelphia, miraculously avoiding a web of power lines and buildings.

TITLE: Why the kids of Venezuela aren't getting enough to eat
SUMMARY: Many are small for their age — a sign of a growing crisis of malnutrition. Government mismanagement is to blame, say political analysts. And there could be lifelong impacts for these children.

TITLE: Judge allows Federal Trade Commission's latest suit against Facebook to move forward
SUMMARY: The judge had previously tossed the FTC's first attempt at attacking Facebook's alleged monopoly power for lack of evidence. This time, the judge said the FTC "has done its homework."

TITLE: In Quebec, people who refuse to be vaccinated for COVID will face a financial penalty
SUMMARY: The Canadian province's premier said not getting vaccinated leads to consequences for the health care system and not all Quebecers should pay for that.

TITLE: Biden calls for changes to the Senate's filibuster to pass voting rights bills
SUMMARY: The president's remarks were among his most forceful denunciations of voter suppression legislation introduced in a number of GOP-controlled regions as well as for changing the Senate filibuster.

TITLE: Medicare proposes covering expensive Alzheimer's drug for those in clinical trials
SUMMARY: Aduhelm is the first treatment approved in the country to slow cognitive decline in those living with Alzheimer's. Doctors have refused to prescribe it, given the lack of data and evidence behind it.

TITLE: Many of those who died in the Bronx apartment fire were from West Africa
SUMMARY: The dead included 11 people from Gambia. A spokesperson for the medical examiner's office said officials are working to confirm the identities of the victims — nine adults and eight children.

TITLE: U.S. Navy agrees to drain a Hawaii fuel tank system blamed for tainted drinking water
SUMMARY: After initially resisting, the Navy will comply with the state's order to remove fuel from a massive underground storage tank facility near Pearl Harbor, officials say.

TITLE: A 2nd suspect is arrested, another is indicted in rapper Young Dolph's death
SUMMARY: A grand jury indicted Cornelius Smith, 32, on first-degree murder and other charges in the shooting that killed the rapper in November, officials say.

TITLE: Twin panda cubs delight devoted fans at Tokyo zoo in COVID shortened debut
SUMMARY: Twin panda cubs made their first public appearance before delighted fans in Tokyo but only briefly for now — just for three days — due to a spike in COVID-19 cases driven by the omicron variant.

TITLE: Djokovic clarifies timeline before arriving in Australia as visa saga continues
SUMMARY: Djokovic moved to clarify the timeline while he was infectious last month and about errors on the travel document he used to enter Australia to defend his Australian Open title.

TITLE: NATO and Russia in high-level talks as Ukraine tensions simmer
SUMMARY: The meeting comes during a week of high-stakes diplomacy and a U.S.-led effort to prevent what Washington believes could be a Russian invasion of Ukraine. Moscow denies it is planning an attack.

TITLE: Pressed on his election lies, former President Trump cuts NPR interview short
SUMMARY: The former president blasted Republicans who have crossed him and kept up repeated election lies in an NPR interview.

TITLE: The White House will distribute 10 million more COVID tests per month to schools
SUMMARY: President Biden and others in his administration insist schools should stay open, even with the omicron wave making it harder than ever to manage.

TITLE: Inflation is still surging and some Democrats see one culprit: Greedy companies
SUMMARY: Consumer prices are soaring at their highest annual pace in almost 40 years. Some progressives such as Sen. Elizabeth Warren blame corporate profiteering, but most economists scoff.

TITLE: Medicaid pays millions for patient transportation. Sometimes the ride never comes
SUMMARY: Medicaid's transportation contracts can be worth tens of millions for companies that land them. But patients say rides to and from medical care often show up late — or sometimes not at all.

TITLE: Read NPR's full interview with former President Donald Trump
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep spoke with former President Donald Trump on Monday. Trump continued to repeat false claims that the 2020 election was rigged.

TITLE: China's Tianjin orders more testing on 14 million after omicron reaches city
SUMMARY: The city of Tianjin ordered a second round of COVID-19 testing on Wednesday in the city about an hour from Beijing, which is set to host the Winter Olympics from February 4th.

TITLE: NATO and Russia are in high-level talks as Ukraine tensions simmer
SUMMARY: The meeting comes during a week of high-stakes diplomacy and a U.S.-led effort to prevent what Washington believes could be a Russian invasion of Ukraine. Moscow denies it is planning an attack.

TITLE: Twin panda cubs delight devoted fans at Tokyo zoo in a COVID shortened debut
SUMMARY: Twin panda cubs made their first public appearance before delighted fans in Tokyo but only briefly for now — just for three days — due to a spike in COVID-19 cases driven by the omicron variant.

TITLE: Djokovic clarifies his timeline before arriving in Australia as visa saga continues
SUMMARY: Djokovic moved to clarify the timeline while he was infectious last month and about errors on the travel document he used to enter Australia to defend his Australian Open title.

TITLE: This is Wordle, the word game everyone on Twitter won't stop talking about
SUMMARY: It's a simple game to guess a five-letter word. People on social media have been very enthusiastic about sharing how well they did.

TITLE: COVID was again the leading cause of death among U.S. law enforcement in 2021
SUMMARY: Some 458 officers died in the line of duty, making 2021 the deadliest year since 1930. The vast majority of deaths — 301 — are attributed to COVID-19, followed by firearm and traffic incidents.

TITLE: New businesses soared to record highs in 2021. Here's a taste of one of them
SUMMARY: The number of business applications reached 5.4 million last year, surpassing the 2020 record of 4.4 million. In the pandemic, millions of people have decided this is the moment to chase their dreams.

SUMMARY: Reid was recalled as a "legendary leader" as colleagues and friends gathered to pay tribute to a hardscrabble Democrat who rose from poverty in Nevada to the most powerful position in the Senate.

TITLE: Here's what's behind the Wordle c-r-a-z-e
SUMMARY: It's a simple game to guess a five-letter word. People on social media have been very enthusiastic about sharing how well they did.

TITLE: Americans are tuning out as omicron rages. Experts call for health messaging to adapt
SUMMARY: Amid a surge in omicron cases and hospitalizations, public health is grappling with how to get a tuned out public to pay attention. Experts urge communicators to cut through the noise.

TITLE: Clyde Bellecourt, co-founder of the American Indian Movement, dies of cancer at 85
SUMMARY: Bellecourt died on Tuesday night in Minneapolis, where more than 50 years ago he helped launch the American Indian Movement.

SUMMARY: Labour Party leader Keir Starmer called Prime Minister Boris Johnson's apology worthless, adding that his defense is that "he didn't realize he was at a party."

SUMMARY: The British prince's lawyers argued that a $500,000 settlement Virginia Giuffre and Jeffrey Epstein reached in 2009 should prevent her from suing him.

TITLE: The Jan. 6 panel requests the top House Republican's voluntary testimony
SUMMARY: Among its questions, the committee is probing any conversations Kevin McCarthy had with former President Donald Trump on the day of the Capitol attack.

SUMMARY: Ronnie Spector, founder of the girl group The Ronettes, has died at 78 after suffering from cancer. She recorded a string of pop hits in the 1960s including "Walking In The Rain" and "Be My Baby."

SUMMARY: The U.S. is also proposing U.N. sanctions in response to North Korea's six ballistic missile launches since September, each of which it says "were in violation of UN Security Council resolutions."

SUMMARY: The number of Democrats citing abortion rights as a top priority for the federal government to address jumped from less than 1% in 2021 to 13% in a new poll.

SUMMARY: China is battling coronavirus outbreaks in six cities. More than 20 million people are in some form of lockdown.

TITLE: Abortion rights jump to a top priority for Democrats in a new poll
SUMMARY: The number of Democrats citing abortion rights as a top priority for the federal government to address jumped from less than 1% in 2021 to 13% in a new poll.

TITLE: In a landmark case, a German court convicts an ex-Syrian officer of torture

SUMMARY: Winsome Sears, a Republican, will be sworn into office Saturday in Virginia alongside Gov.-elect Glenn Youngkin. Sears ran, in part, on the idea that the country's racial reckoning has gone too far.

SUMMARY: People are sitting out college in droves. During the pandemic, undergraduate enrollment has dropped nearly 7%. The long-term effects of this decline could have a dramatic impact on the economy.

SUMMARY: An investigation from the state's attorney general's office found that the Virginia Beach Police used forged documents to get confessions in at least five instances.

SUMMARY: The loan servicing giant has agreed to cancel student loan debts owed by roughly 66,000 borrowers as part of a settlement the company reached with 39 state attorneys general.
