TITLE: Despite fears of a Russian invasion, one Ukrainian family tries to keep life normal
SUMMARY: "You have to find ways to live a normal life," says a mother of four in Kyiv. She and her family keep their car full of fuel and plan to take refuge in a village outside the capital if Russia attacks.

TITLE: Attorney General Garland pledges a comprehensive response to violent crime
SUMMARY: The federal government will stand "shoulder to shoulder" with communities working to fight gun violence, Merrick Garland tells a meeting of U.S. mayors.

TITLE: Could the world become too warm to hold Winter Olympics?
SUMMARY: Climate change may mean many Winter Olympics host cities will eventually become unsuitable for the games.

TITLE: Thich Nhat Hanh, Buddhist monk and peace activist, dies at 95
SUMMARY: Nhat Hanh distilled Buddhist teachings on compassion and suffering into easily grasped guidance over a lifetime dedicated to working for peace.

TITLE: Rio de Janeiro delays Carnival parades as omicron spikes in Brazil
SUMMARY: Rio Mayor Eduardo Paes announced weeks ago that the raucous street parties, which draw hundreds of thousands of revelers, wouldn't proceed in the manner they did before the pandemic.

TITLE: A rare blast of snow and ice is taking aim at the Southeast U.S. coast
SUMMARY: Transportation officials say crews are working to treat roads ahead of snow and ice, but warned people to stay off of them.

TITLE: A rare blast of snow and ice hits the Southeast U.S. coast
SUMMARY: A taxiing Delta Airlines plane skidded off the runway at snowy Raleigh-Durham International Airport as the winter storm descended on the Carolinas. No injuries were reported.

TITLE: New Yorkers want gun violence to end. A controversial police unit returns to help
SUMMARY: New York City's new mayor, Eric Adams, a former NYPD officer, says the unit will help curb gun violence and will be run differently than the original, which was ruled unconstitutional.

TITLE: We asked how you are finding joy in the pandemic. Here are 12 surprising ideas
SUMMARY: It's been two long years of COVID gloom. But NPR's readers didn't let it keep them down. From cicada tracking to open-water swimming to roller-skating squads, you share how you bring the fun.

TITLE: How to talk to vaccine doubters: 5 tips for parent 'ambassadors'
SUMMARY: A health communications expert has developed a free online course to help people talk to those who are vaccine hesitant — and to fight misinformation with empathy.

TITLE: For all of Biden's successes or failures, it's really about 'COVID, stupid'
SUMMARY: No matter all the other problems and mistakes, successes or failures detailed and worked over in his exhaustive press conference, as goes COVID, likely so goes the Biden presidency.

TITLE: Black Mississippi senators walk out in protest over critical race theory ban
SUMMARY: The lawmakers withheld their votes as the state Senate passed a bill that would ban schools from teaching critical race theory. The education superintendent has said it is not being taught in schools.

TITLE: Brian Laundrie wrote that he killed Gabby Petito, the FBI says
SUMMARY: It was the first time authorities squarely pinned the blame for Petito's death on Laundrie. The FBI also said Laundrie had sent texts to deceive people that Petito was still alive.

TITLE: Architect behind Googleplex now says it's 'dangerous' to work at such a posh office
SUMMARY: Clive Wilkinson says it's really not a good thing for employees to work at a place that has catered meals, private parks, massage tables and a laundromat. Because why would you ever leave?

TITLE: China's Olympics aim to keep COVID at bay with armpit sensors, robots and more
SUMMARY: Athletes and other attendees will be in a closed "loop" with strict rules about everything from daily testing for athletes to how spectators should respond — no cheering out loud, please!

TITLE: A wildfire near California's Big Sur forces residents to evacuate
SUMMARY: Those living in the Big Sur area were told to evacuate from their homes due to a wildfire that began late Friday, officials said. A wind advisory had been issued in the Bay Area.

TITLE: 90 tons of U.S. lethal aid arrives in Ukraine as border tensions with Russia rise
SUMMARY: The aid, which includes ammunition, is part of a $200 million package that President Biden approved in December and is meant for Ukraine's frontline defenders should Russia choose to invade.

TITLE: Coastal Virginia and the Carolinas get snow and ice
SUMMARY: A winter weather system brought colder temperatures and precipitation not often seen in the region. Authorities urged drivers to stay off the roads, which forecasters said are slick and snow-packed.

TITLE: 90 tons of U.S. military aid arrives in Ukraine as border tensions with Russia rise
SUMMARY: The aid, which includes ammunition, is part of a $200 million package that President Biden approved in December and is meant for Ukraine's front-line defenders should Russia choose to invade.

TITLE: What life is like for an 11-year-old
SUMMARY: Avah Lamie, 11, says this is a stressful time to be a kid. Rates of anxiety and depression among children and youth were on the rise even before COVID, but the past two years have made things worse.

TITLE: Arizona Democrats have censured Kyrsten Sinema over her pro-filibuster vote
SUMMARY: The symbolic action comes as Sinema has come under criticism from progressive groups in Arizona after she voted to uphold the filibuster in the Senate.

TITLE: Kiribati and Samoa implement rare lockdowns after travelers test positive
SUMMARY: Dozens of travelers from Fiji tested positive in Kiribati, prompting the island nation to implement its first lockdown. Samoa's order followed a cluster of cases in airline passengers from Australia.

TITLE: Why rapid COVID tests aren't more accurate and how scientists hope to improve them
SUMMARY: Recent research — and plenty of anecdotes — suggest some rapid tests may be less sensitive at detecting omicron if you don't have symptoms.  Here's how researchers hope to make them more effective.

TITLE: How colleges are dealing with high COVID case counts on campus
SUMMARY: Despite the omicron surge, college students are starting the spring semester on campus – and administrators are bracing for the worst.

TITLE: Omicron hampers Broadway. Fewer tourists are there for just a score of shows
SUMMARY: Tickets may be easier and cheaper to get for the plays that are still open.  Some producers reopened until the virus raced through the cast and crew. Future productions are hard to see on the horizon.

TITLE: Simone Biles has a rival — a tiny bark beetle (but it can't stick the landing)
SUMMARY: A team of researchers has discovered the gymnastic ability of bark beetle larvae. Scientists recently recorded the larvae performing the twisting leap for the first time.

TITLE: Sarah Palin's defamation suit against 'The New York Times' gets its day in court
SUMMARY: Jury selection begins Monday in the former Alaska governor's case. A 2017 <em>Times

TITLE: Why Tonga is opting for 'contactless' humanitarian aid
SUMMARY: It's a pandemic predicament. With only 1 recorded case of COVID-19 in their island nation, Tongans are desperate for help after the volcanic eruption — but eager to keep the virus out.

TITLE: Biden's predecessors could have felt his first-year pain
SUMMARY: Yet these early reversals haven't always been crippling. On the contrary, three of the past four presidents elected — and five of the past eight — have recovered from shaky starts to win re-election.

TITLE: Ukraine crisis deepens after U.K. says Russia may try to install a pro-Kremlin leader
SUMMARY: The situation along the Russia-Ukraine border remains tense, with thousands of Russian troops amassed just across the divide and Ukraine preparing for a possible invasion.

TITLE: Don Wilson, cofounder of the instrumental guitar group The Ventures, dies at age 88
SUMMARY: Wilson played rythim guitar for The Ventures, which with over 100 million records sold, was the best-selling instrumental band of all time.

TITLE: Who is Yevheniy Murayev, the man the U.K. says Russia wants to install in Ukraine?
SUMMARY: The British government named Murayev as one of Russia's top picks to lead Ukraine were it to invade the country. Murayev, a critic of Ukraine's pro-Western government, has dismissed the claim.

TITLE: 4 were killed and 1 wounded in 'ambush' shooting at a house party near Los Angeles
SUMMARY: Inglewood Mayor James Butts called the shooting an "ambush" involving multiple shooters.

TITLE: Los Angeles school district tells students to upgrade from cloth masks
SUMMARY: Students will have to wear "well-fitting, non-cloth masks with a nose wire." Employees will have to wear surgical grade masks or higher.

TITLE: State Department orders family of embassy staff to leave Ukraine
SUMMARY: Citing a "continued threat of Russian military action," the U.S. State Department ordered eligible family members of personnel at its embassy in Kyiv to leave the country.

TITLE: Jan. 6 panel is investigating a Trump administration plan to seize voting machines
SUMMARY: Rep. Bennie Thompson of Mississippi confirmed Sunday that an executive order was drafted for Trump to sign that would have used the military to seize machines in battleground states.

TITLE: State Department orders families of embassy staff to leave Ukraine
SUMMARY: Citing a "continued threat of Russian military action," the U.S. State Department also authorized the voluntary departure of nonessential embassy employees at its embassy in Kyiv.

TITLE: U.S. weighs sending 5,000 troops to Eastern Europe to counter Russia
SUMMARY: Biden is considering sending up to 5,000 troops to Eastern European countries, including Romania and Poland, a U.S. official told NPR. Russia has stationed 100,000 troops near Ukraine.

TITLE: UAE says it has intercepted 2 missiles from Yemen's Houthis
SUMMARY: The missile fire further escalates tensions across the Persian Gulf, which previously had seen a series of assaults near Emirati soil.

TITLE: A popular uprising and soldier mutinies challenge Burkina Faso's president
SUMMARY: Government officials had sought to reassure people that the situation was under control even as shots rang out for hours at the army base.

TITLE: French fashion designer Thierry Mugler dies at 73
SUMMARY: "May his soul Rest In Peace," his Instagram said in a post that was all black with no image. It did not give a cause of death.

TITLE: The doctor didn't show up, but the hospital ER still billed $1,012
SUMMARY: A toddler burned his hand on the stove. The pediatrician told mom over the phone to take him to the emergency room. But after a long wait for a doctor who never showed, they left. Then the bill came.

TITLE: California's embattled utility leaves criminal probation, but more charges loom
SUMMARY: Since 2017 the utility has been blamed for more than 30 wildfires that wiped out more than 23,000 homes and businesses and killed more than 100 people.

TITLE: Burkina Faso's president is being held by mutinous soldiers
SUMMARY: The mutiny came a day after a public demonstration calling for Kabore's resignation.

TITLE: Afghanistan's Taliban have started their first talks in Europe since takeover
SUMMARY: Taliban representatives will be certain to press their demand that nearly $10 billion frozen by the United States be released as Afghanistan faces a precarious humanitarian situation.

TITLE: Seniors are at high risk of COVID, but Medicare doesn't pay for rapid tests.
SUMMARY: The laws governing Medicare don't provide coverage for self-administered diagnostic tests, including rapid antigen tests. Here's how seniors can get free tests anyway.

TITLE: 'The Last Cuentista' and 'Watercress' Win Top Children's Book Awards
SUMMARY: The 2022 Newbery and Caldecott medals, among several other honors, were awarded Monday to the children's books that American librarians chose as the most distinguished this year.

TITLE: Stormy Daniels and Michael Avenatti will face off at trial
SUMMARY: Prosecutors are trying to prove that California lawyer cheated porn star Stormy Daniels out of $300,000 in book proceeds. Daniels is known for her lawsuits against former President Donald Trump.

TITLE: Seniors are at high risk of COVID, but Medicare doesn't pay for rapid tests
SUMMARY: The laws governing Medicare don't provide coverage for self-administered diagnostic tests, including rapid antigen tests. Here's how older adults can get free tests anyway.

TITLE: So you want to be the landlord-king of a remote English island
SUMMARY: Piel Island is a 50-acre landmass half a mile off England's northwestern coast, home to wildlife, castle ruins and a centuries-old pub. It's looking for a new landlord, who will also be crowned king.

TITLE: It's getting uglier in stock markets as fears about inflation spark a brutal drop
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is gearing up to raise interest rates after inflation hit a 40-year high, sparking fears in Wall Street about what these steps will mean for the economy.

TITLE: A luxury cruise ship rerouted to the Bahamas over an arrest warrant for unpaid fuel
SUMMARY: The Crystal Symphony was supposed to dock in Miami, but ended up in the Bahamas after a U.S. judge granted an order to seize the ship as part of a breach-of-contract lawsuit.

TITLE: A court in the U.K. says Julian Assange can keep fighting his extradition to the U.S.
SUMMARY: Lawyers for the WikiLeaks founder have 14 days to submit their application to the U.K.'s Supreme Court, which will decide whether to hear the case. His supporters see the ruling as a partial win.

TITLE: 'The Last Cuentista' and 'Watercress' win top children's book awards
SUMMARY: The 2022 Newbery and Caldecott medals, among several other honors, were awarded Monday to the children's books that American librarians chose as the most distinguished this year.

TITLE: 'Camera Man' unspools the colorful life of silent film star Buster Keaton
SUMMARY: By age 5, Keaton was a star in his family's vaudeville act; he went on to star in and direct silent films, performing jaw-dropping stunts. <em>Slate

TITLE: The federal trial begins for 3 other officers at the scene of George Floyd's murder
SUMMARY: Former Minneapolis police officers Tou Thao, Thomas Lane and J. Alexander Kueng are charged with failing to provide medical care to George Floyd as Derek Chauvin knelt on his neck.

TITLE: Soldiers say a military junta now controls Burkina Faso
SUMMARY: The mutiny came a day after a public demonstration calling for Kabore's resignation.

TITLE: Businessman and Mavs owner Mark Cuban launches an online pharmacy for generic drugs
SUMMARY: The pharmacy says it will bypass healthcare industry "middlemen" and help consumers avoid high drug prices by charging manufacturers' prices plus a flat 15% markup and pharmacist fee.

TITLE: Playoff thriller between Bills and Chiefs puts NFL on defense over its overtime rules
SUMMARY: Kansas City's 42-36 win was an instant classic, but fans have been calling foul in response to league rules that denied Buffalo any chance at victory in overtime.

TITLE: Homeless camps are often blamed for crime but experts say it's not so simple
SUMMARY: Specific homeless camps may fuel property crime, but one researcher says on average, camps do not appear to increase city-wide crime rates.

TITLE: Dough-nate for doughnuts: Krispy Kreme says it will give blood donors a free dozen
SUMMARY: The promotion follows an announcement from the Red Cross earlier this month that it is facing its worst blood shortage in more than a decade.

TITLE: A special grand jury has been granted in Fulton County's Trump investigation
SUMMARY: The decision comes after Fulton District Attorney Fani Willis requested one. A special grand jury has subpoena power and the authority to obtain documents. It will begin on May 2.

TITLE: Don't ignore your spam folder. It's how this woman learned she won a $3 million lotto
SUMMARY: Laura Spears, 55, says she stumbled on her life-changing win a few days after buying a ticket for the Mega Millions jackpot. "I couldn't believe what I was reading," she says.

TITLE: Billionaire Mark Cuban launches online pharmacy aimed at lowering generic drug prices
SUMMARY: The pharmacy says it will bypass health care industry "middlemen" and help consumers avoid high drug prices by charging manufacturers' prices plus a flat 15% markup and pharmacist fee.

TITLE: Stocks are in the midst of a wild ride as the U.S. gets ready to fight inflation
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is gearing up to raise interest rates after inflation hit a 40-year high, sparking fears in Wall Street about what these steps will mean for the economy.

TITLE: Police document: 19-year-old Elizabeth Holmes reported sexual assault from Stanford
SUMMARY: A document obtained by NPR through a public records request shows that Holmes reported to local authorities that she was allegedly assaulted in a frat house while she was attending the school.

TITLE: The U.S. is placing 8,500 troops on alert for possible deployment to Eastern Europe
SUMMARY: The Pentagon said no final decision has been made, but Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin wanted U.S. forces to be ready "just in case" of a Russian invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Appeals court reinstates drop boxes for Wisconsin's February primary
SUMMARY: The ruling temporarily blocks a judge's order that would have banned the use of absentee ballot drop boxes in the swing state.

TITLE: James Webb telescope reaches its final destination in space, a million miles away
SUMMARY: The $10 billion telescope is nearly ready to begin capturing images that scientists hope will help uncover the mysteries of the universe. And help scope out other possible habitable planets.

TITLE: Internet to Tonga's main island cut by volcano could be restored in 2 weeks
SUMMARY: A second, domestic fiber-optic cable that connects Tonga's smaller islands to the main island could prove much more difficult to repair.

TITLE: COVID outbreak on relief ship causes fears of spread in Tonga
SUMMARY: Since the pandemic began, Tonga has reported just a single case of COVID-19 and has avoided any outbreaks.

TITLE: Prosecutors in multiple states are investigating false Electoral College submissions
SUMMARY: Legal experts say the illegitimate submissions should motivate Congress to update the Electoral Count Act and "firm up the guardrails" of democracy.

TITLE: From Kabul to Virginia: An Afghan family is starting over in America
SUMMARY: In only a matter of days, the lives of an Afghan family changed forever. After the Taliban took control of Kabul, they were forced to start over in a foreign country.

TITLE: Yemen's Houthis have launched two attacks against the U.A.E. — here's why
SUMMARY: The attacks underscore how Yemen's civil war, which has ground on for over seven years, can flare into a regional danger.

TITLE: Anti-abortion groups are raking in fundraising as Supreme Court decision looms
SUMMARY: Susan B. Anthony List secured $20 million in pledged financial contributions, five times more than it has had at the outset of an election year over its 30-year history,

TITLE: Starting in 2024, U.S. students will take the SAT entirely online
SUMMARY: The College Board, the organization behind the test, also announced the exam will shrink from three hours to two, and students will be able to use a calculator for the math section.

TITLE: Pfizer and BioNTech begin testing an omicron-specific COVID-19 vaccine
SUMMARY: Though people who are vaccinated and boosted appear to be better protected against omicron, the highly contagious variant has still led to breakthrough cases and a surge in infections worldwide.

TITLE: The James Webb telescope reaches its final destination in space, a million miles away
SUMMARY: The $10 billion telescope is nearly ready to begin capturing images that scientists hope will help uncover the mysteries of the universe — and scope out other possible habitable planets.

TITLE: Meet Justice Ayesha Malik, Pakistan's first female Supreme Court judge
SUMMARY: Malik was sworn in on Monday, shattering a glass ceiling in a country where only about 17% of judges are women.

TITLE: At least 6 people are reported dead from a crush at an African Cup soccer match
SUMMARY: The apparent stampede outside of a stadium in Cameroon has renewed the focus on prior warnings that the nation was ill-equipped to host the continent's biggest sporting event.

TITLE: A Black man jailed instead of a white male felon with a similar name is suing police
SUMMARY: Nevada police thought Shane Lee Brown, who is Black, was Shane Neal Brown, who is white, taller and roughly twice as old. Now, Shane Lee Brown has filed suit, seeking $500,000 in damages.

TITLE: Shark bites surged in 2021, rebounding from a drop earlier in the pandemic
SUMMARY: Still, the Florida Museum of Natural History's International Shark Attack File says the high number of shark bites and deaths last year was on par with long-term averages.

TITLE: Want to understand the U.S.? This historian says the South holds the key
SUMMARY: Imani Perry says the South can be seen as an "origin point" for the way the nation operates. Her book, <em>South to America,

TITLE: Kyiv or Kiev? Why people disagree about how to pronounce the Ukrainian capital's name
SUMMARY: What's the correct way to call a foreign city — by its English name, if it has one, or by its name in the local language? For the people involved, it can be a serious matter entwined with geopolitics.

TITLE: Hospitals use a lottery to allocate scarce COVID drugs for the immunocompromised
SUMMARY: So far the government has distributed about 300,000 doses of Evusheld, a new drug that protects against COVID-19. Some 7 million Americans could benefit from the drug right away.

TITLE: Readers' global wishes for 2022: More kindness, more nature ... and kitties!
SUMMARY: What could the world achieve this year if we had a limitless budget and full support from global leaders? Our audience shares their heartfelt ideas.

TITLE: Bobbe 'Beegie' Long Adair, a formative center of Nashville's jazz scene, dies at 84
SUMMARY: Adair was a superb soloist and tremendous accompanist, as well as the bedrock of Nashville's jazz scene after first relocating there in the early '60s.

TITLE: Climate Lawsuit Against Major Oil Companies Moves Forward In Appeals Court
SUMMARY: The case brought by Baltimore is one of more than 20 similar lawsuits nationwide that seek to hold fossil fuel companies accountable for their role in climate change.

TITLE: Three Baltimore firefighters have died after getting trapped in a collapsed rowhome
SUMMARY: Baltimore Mayor Brandon M. Scott called it a "gut wrenching tragedy" for the city, the fire department and the firefighters' families.

TITLE: Free N95 masks are arriving at pharmacies and grocery stores. Here's how to get yours
SUMMARY: Some retailers are starting to get the first wave of the 400 million free masks being distributed by the federal government. Every person is allowed to receive up to three masks.

TITLE: Apple's Tim Cook wins restraining order against woman, citing trespassing and threats
SUMMARY: A judge granted a restraining order against a woman who allegedly showed up twice to Cook's home in Palo Alto. The filing states she also threatened Cook with photos of a handgun.

TITLE: Federal court says Alabama's congressional map disadvantages Black voters
SUMMARY: Blocking the new congressional map from taking effect, a panel of judges says Alabama needs at least two, not one, congressional districts in which Black voters are the majority, or close to it.

TITLE: Coast Guard searching for 39 people whose boat reportedly capsized near Florida coast
SUMMARY: The Coast Guard said the missing appear to have been part of a "suspected human smuggling venture" that took off from Bimini, Bahamas, a small island roughly 55 miles east of Miami.

TITLE: Testimony begins in the dueling defamation suits over Roy Moore molestation claims
SUMMARY: The allegations overshadowed Moore's 2017 campaign as he fell in a stunning defeat to Doug Jones, the first Alabama Democrat elected to the Senate in 25 years.

TITLE: Lawsuit alleging oil companies misled public about climate change moves forward
SUMMARY: The case brought by Baltimore is one of more than 20 similar lawsuits nationwide that seek to hold fossil fuel companies accountable for their role in climate change.

TITLE: Pelosi is running for reelection but is silent on a bid to retain her leadership post
SUMMARY: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., who's 81, did not say whether she will stick by a pledge she made in 2018 to limit her tenure in elected leadership.

TITLE: New York's mask mandate temporarily restored by appeals judge
SUMMARY: Monday's ruling that overturned the mandate caused confusion, with some school administrators quickly announcing masks would be optional and others continuing to enforce wearing them.

TITLE: Elton John postpones Texas concerts after testing positive for COVID-19
SUMMARY: John said that he's fully vaccinated and boosted, experiencing only mild symptoms, and expects to be able to perform at his scheduled show this weekend in Arkansas.

TITLE: 'Big Papi' makes it into Baseball Hall of Fame as Bonds and Clemens get shut out
SUMMARY: The beloved Red Sox player who helped put an end to the "Curse of the Bambino" was voted into the elite group in his first year on the ballot. Bonds and Clemens fell short in their final year.

TITLE: Russia has officially named jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny a terrorist
SUMMARY: Navalny and eight of his allies — including top aides Lyubov Sobol and Georgy Alburov — were on Tuesday added to the registry by Russia's Federal Financial Monitoring Service.

TITLE: US Coast Guard searching for 39 people missing in 'suspected human smuggling venture'
SUMMARY: The Coast Guard said the missing appear to have been part of a "suspected human smuggling venture" that took off from Bimini, Bahamas, a small island roughly 55 miles east of Miami.

TITLE: A town in Mexico survives entirely on money sent back by U.S. migrants
SUMMARY: The money has allowed their families to remain in Comachuen, a town in the Michoacan mountains rather than moving to other parts of Mexico for work.

TITLE: Coast Guard searches for 39 people missing in 'suspected human smuggling venture'
SUMMARY: The Coast Guard said the missing appear to have been part of a "suspected human smuggling venture" that took off from Bimini, Bahamas, a small island roughly 55 miles east of Miami.

TITLE: 3 Baltimore firefighters have died after getting trapped in a collapsed rowhome
SUMMARY: Baltimore Mayor Brandon M. Scott called it a "gut wrenching tragedy" for the city, the fire department and the firefighters' families.

TITLE: Tanya Tagaq's powerful new album 'Tongues' aims for hope among hard truths
SUMMARY: Tagaq, a recipient of the national Polaris Music Prize, discusses the subjugation of Canada's Indigenous people and her hopes for healing through acknowledging that difficult history.

TITLE: Flaws plague a tool meant to help low-risk federal prisoners win early release
SUMMARY: The Justice Department created an algorithm to measure a person's risk of committing a new crime after leaving prison. But even after multiple tweaks the tool is leading to racial disparities.

TITLE: A true crime writer struggles with his responsibility to the victims in 'Devil House'
SUMMARY: Novelist John Darnielle — also singer-songwriter with the Mountain Goats — has a hero who wants to honor the victims he's writing about but doesn't much like them.

TITLE: U.K.'s Boris Johnson braces for 'partygate' investigation report
SUMMARY: Senior civil servant Sue Gray could turn in her report to the government as soon as Wednesday. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's office promised to publish its findings.

TITLE: Indonesia's capital is rapidly sinking into the sea
SUMMARY: Now the government is leaving, and moving the country's capital to the island of Borneo.

TITLE: Testimony begins in the dueling defamation suits over Roy Moore molestation claims
SUMMARY: The allegations overshadowed Moore's 2017 campaign as he fell in a stunning defeat to Doug Jones, the first Alabama Democrat elected to the Senate in 25 years.

TITLE: Satellite images show the aftermath of Tonga volcano's eruption
SUMMARY: The images show populated areas in the archipelago with heavily damaged or destroyed buildings and homes and at least one island covered with ash.

TITLE: There's one population that gets overlooked by an 'everyone will get COVID' mentality
SUMMARY: The roughly 7 million Americans who are immunocompromised — including many disabled people — live with much higher risk of COVID, and near-constant vigilance.

TITLE: Disney defends its 'Snow White' remake after criticism from Peter Dinklage
SUMMARY: Disney says it is taking "a different approach" to its live-action remake of <em>Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs

TITLE: 'Big Papi' makes it into the Baseball Hall of Fame as Bonds and Clemens get shut out
SUMMARY: The beloved Red Sox player who helped put an end to the "Curse of the Bambino" was voted into the elite group in his first year on the ballot. Bonds and Clemens fell short in their final year.

TITLE: Dolly Parton's new line of Southern baking mixes is already sold out
SUMMARY: The limited-edition collections from Dolly Parton and Duncan Hines have been snapped up, but their Southern-inspired cake and frosting mixes are expected to hit grocery store shelves in March.

TITLE: Peter Robbins, who voiced Charlie Brown in the 1960s, has died
SUMMARY: As a child actor, Robbins voiced one of Charlie Brown's most famous lines — "I got a rock" — in <em>It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown

TITLE: A California redwood forest has officially been returned to a group of Native tribes
SUMMARY: Save the Redwoods League purchased and donated the 523-acre area to the InterTribal Sinkyone Wildnerness Council, a group of 10 tribes that have been connected to the land for thousands of years.

TITLE: Justice Stephen Breyer, an influential liberal on the Supreme Court, to retire
SUMMARY: Behind the scenes, Breyer pushed and prodded his fellow justices for consensus. His decision gives President Biden his first opportunity to name a new justice to the court.

TITLE: Ozzie, the world's oldest male gorilla, dies at 61
SUMMARY: Ozzie was experiencing symptoms such as decreased appetite, facial swelling and weakness in the past week. He was found deceased on Tuesday at the Atlanta zoo, where he lived since 1988.

TITLE: It's likely to be a frustrating tax season, deputy treasury secretary says
SUMMARY: NPR's A Martinez talks to Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo about the challenges for the IRS this tax season --- due in part to a lack of funding and a backlog from 2020.

TITLE: The U.S. says it will stand firm against major Russian demands as tension rises
SUMMARY: Among the demands from Russia was a guarantee that Ukraine be permanently barred from NATO membership. That would violate a U.S. "core principle," Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Wednesday.

TITLE: Game time: The Fed unveils a tougher plan to fight stubbornly high inflation
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is preparing to raise interest rates sooner – and perhaps – more aggressively after inflation reached the highest in nearly 40 years.

TITLE: Remembering Thich Nhat Hanh, peace activist and Vietnamese Buddhist monk
SUMMARY: One of the world's most influential Zen masters, Thich Nhat Hanh championed "engaged Buddhism," which combines meditation and anti-war work. He died Jan. 22. <em>Originally broadcast in 1997.

TITLE: Twitter boots a bot that revealed Wordle's upcoming words to the game's players
SUMMARY: A bot account sent mean notes to users who posted their Wordle score — and it also revealed the next day's answer. It was suspended for violating Twitter's rules.

TITLE: A nor'easter could bring several inches of snow to the Northeast this weekend
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service said it was too early to predict snowfall totals but warned that "blizzard conditions near the coast" could occur depending on the storm's path.

TITLE: 50 years ago, 'Zoom' spoke to children about their real lives
SUMMARY: For the anniversary of the kids' TV show<em>,

TITLE: Why a mailbox continues to loom over Amazon union vote at Alabama warehouse
SUMMARY: The mailbox was a key reason why labor officials ruled to re-do a union election at Amazon's Alabama warehouse. For the re-vote, the mailbox got moved. The union wants it gone.

TITLE: A Texas man is accused of selling gun used to take synagogue hostages
SUMMARY: Earlier Wednesday, British police said they arrested two more men in Manchester related to the hostage-taking incident.

TITLE: A Georgia county set off a tense debate by planning to reduce polling sites
SUMMARY: A debate about poll closures in a rural Georgia county underscores how divisive any and all voting issues have become.

TITLE: Prince Andrew again seeks dismissal of sexual abuse suit, demands a trial if it's not
SUMMARY: Among Andrew's grounds for dismissal is that if any sexual activity did occur between the prince and Virginia Giuffre, it was consensual.

TITLE: Amazon faces another union vote, this time at a Staten Island warehouse
SUMMARY: Federal labor officials found enough support among Amazon workers on Staten Island to pave wave for a union election. It could be the second union vote for Amazon this year.

TITLE: North Korea fires two suspected missiles in sixth round of launches this month
SUMMARY: North Korea last week issued a veiled threat to resume  testing nuclear explosives and long-range missiles targeting the U.S.

TITLE: Amy Schneider's 'Jeopardy!' run has come to an end after 40 games
SUMMARY: Schneider ends her storied run on the show with the second-longest consecutive win streak in its history and $1,382,800 in earnings.

TITLE: Patient who refused COVID vaccine was denied a heart transplant
SUMMARY: Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston said the COVID-19 vaccine is one of several immunizations required by most U.S. transplant programs.

TITLE: Spotify removes Neil Young's music after he objects to Joe Rogan's podcast
SUMMARY: The move comes two days after Neil Young requested that his work be removed from Spotify in protest over coronavirus misinformation on Joe Rogan's podcast.

TITLE: Iran is undergoing a mass vaccination campaign as omicron looms
SUMMARY: Iran has found a rare, if fleeting, respite from the anxiety and trauma of the pandemic.

TITLE: China is demanding US end its 'interference' in Beijing Olympics

SUMMARY: All chimps managed by the National Institutes of Health that are currently eligible to go to a sanctuary have been moved there, but animal welfare advocates say more should be allowed to go.

SUMMARY: June Hur's history-based novel binds fiction to fact in a gripping young adult mystery. A nurse in 18th century Korea's royal court tries to track down the killer of four women.

SUMMARY: A poor reader, Matthew Reeves is intellectually disabled and wasn't capable of making a decision on the method of execution without assistance, his lawyers arg93ued.

TITLE: Toni Morrison's only short story is available in book form for the first time
SUMMARY: The late Nobel Laureate and novelist was known for her examination of the Black experience. "Recitatif" is about two girls, one Black and one white, but doesn't reveal which is which.

TITLE: Why Americans should care about the Russia-Ukraine standoff
SUMMARY: The standoff between Ukraine and Russia is about global security and an attempt to "rewrite rules on which the world is based," says Ukraine's foreign minister.

TITLE: The U.S. and Russia are still far apart on Ukraine, Putin says
SUMMARY: The Russian leader's remarks came as diplomatic efforts continue. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited Kyiv and Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke with his Russian counterpart.

TITLE: A new Belgian law grants certain workers the 'right to disconnect' after hours
SUMMARY: Thousands of federal civil servants will no longer have to answer calls or emails from their bosses outside of working hours. The law aims to address burnout exacerbated by the pandemic.

TITLE: Israel is an apartheid state, Amnesty International says
SUMMARY: "The Israeli government is committing the crime against humanity of apartheid against Palestinians," the rights group said. Israel's foreign ministry says the new Amnesty report is anti-Semitic.

TITLE: Abdul Alim of Pakistan, a COVID survivor and vaccine advocate, dies at age 104
SUMMARY: In his final days, Alim asked people not to visit him or his family due to rising COVID cases in his community. "Even in death he wanted to keep people and our family safe," says his son.

TITLE: Here are the 7 new Olympic events to watch in Beijing
SUMMARY: The 2022 Winter Olympics are set to begin this week in Beijing, China. And viewers will be able to tune into a series of new events appearing at the Games.

TITLE: Two male penguins become 1st same-sex foster parents at a New York zoo
SUMMARY: The Rosamond Gifford Zoo says Elmer and Lima are its first same-sex parents to successfully hatch an egg, calling the penguins "exemplary in every aspect of egg care."

TITLE: Heartbroken? There's a scientific reason why breaking up feels so rotten
SUMMARY: Science writer Florence Williams experienced what felt like a brain injury when her husband left her after more than 25 years. Her new book is <em>Heartbreak: A Personal and Scientific Journey.

TITLE: 'Hadestown' creator Anaïs Mitchell's new solo album reaches forward in looking back
SUMMARY: Anaïs Mitchell spent more than a decade developing her hit musical <em>Hadestown

TITLE: A celebrity groundhog dies shortly before his big day
SUMMARY: New Jersey's Milltown Mel "recently crossed over the rainbow bridge," his handlers say — and they scrambled to find a replacement rodent for Groundhog Day, to no avail.

TITLE: FBI advises athletes to leave their personal phones at home for the Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: The bureau is advising travelers to use a temporary phone while in China in order to protect themselves from potential cyber attacks.

TITLE: Two male penguins welcome hatchling as New York zoo's 1st same-sex foster parents
SUMMARY: The Rosamond Gifford Zoo says Elmer and Lima are its first same-sex parents to successfully hatch an egg, calling the penguins "exemplary in every aspect of egg care."

TITLE: In Belgium, government workers no longer have to answer the boss's emails after hours
SUMMARY: Thousands of federal civil servants will no longer have to answer calls or emails from their bosses outside of working hours. The law aims to address burnout exacerbated by the pandemic.

TITLE: Feds' contract with Pfizer for Paxlovid has some surprises
SUMMARY: NPR has obtained the government's $5.3 million contract for the first 10 million courses of Paxlovid, an antiviral pill for COVID-19. Here's what's in it.

TITLE: Native American tribes reach a tentative opioid settlement with J&J and distributors
SUMMARY: Johnson & Johnson, AmerisourceBergen, McKesson and Cardinal Health will pay $590 million to Native American tribes under a proposed settlement for the companies' role in the opioid crisis.

TITLE: First African American picked for key Southern Baptist Convention position
SUMMARY: McLaurin, 48, will fill the post vacated by Ronnie Floyd, who resigned over the Executive Committee's handling of a third-party investigation into how the it addressed sexual abuse reports

TITLE: A 104-year-old COVID survivor has died. He wanted to keep people safe until the end
SUMMARY: In his final days, Alim asked people not to visit him or his family due to rising COVID cases in his community. "Even in death he wanted to keep people and our family safe," says his son.

TITLE: Jury begins deliberations in Roy Moore defamation case
SUMMARY: An attorney for Leigh Corfman, who accused the former Senate candidate of molesting her, told jurors in closing arguments that the case is ultimately about who they believe is telling the truth.

TITLE: A small island nation has cooked up not 1, not 2 but 5 COVID vaccines. It's Cuba!
SUMMARY: Cuba has one of the world's highest COVID vaccination rates, with more than 85% of the nation fully immunized and kids as young as 2 getting inoculated. And it's done so using homegrown vaccines.

TITLE: 2 officers killed at Bridgewater College in Virginia; a suspect is in custody
SUMMARY: A police spokeswoman said officers responded to reports of a suspicious man on campus and after a brief interaction, the man opened fire on the officers and fled on foot.

TITLE: Ex-Miami Dolphins coach Brian Flores accuses NFL of racial discrimination in lawsuit
SUMMARY: Flores alleges that the league is "managed much like a plantation" charging that its 32 owners, none of whom are Black, profit from the labor of its players, 70% of whom are African American.

TITLE: Whoopi Goldberg suspended for 2 weeks over Holocaust remarks
SUMMARY: The suspension came a day after Goldberg's comment during a discussion on "The View" that race was not a factor in the Holocaust.

TITLE: Tonga enters lockdown after first community transmitted COVID-19 cases detected
SUMMARY: Two wharf workers tested positive Tuesday February 1st. The Ministry of Health has been testing workers there amid international aid shipments after last month's volcanic eruption.

TITLE: Another winter storm now threatens a large swath of Central and Eastern U.S.
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service predicts a prolonged, major winter storm that could travel across parts of the Midwest into the Northeast later this week.

TITLE: When can babies and kids under age 5 get their shots? Here's the timeline
SUMMARY: The first big hurdle was crossed when Pfizer shared its clinical trial data with the FDA. Now there are five more steps get through before this vulnerable population can finally be vaccinated.

TITLE: Some families are being forced to choose between remote learning and school meals
SUMMARY: Many low-income families who want their children to keep learning remotely are losing access to a federal program that helped them pay for meals.

TITLE: National Guard soldiers now substitute teaching in New Mexico
SUMMARY: New Mexico is short 1,000 teachers, National Guard volunteers now serve as substitute teachers

TITLE: At the Beijing Olympics, a Kashmiri skier will carry India's flag — all by himself
SUMMARY: When you think of India, you might think of heat and humidity before snow. But India is home to parts of the Himalayan mountains. That's where Olympian Arif Khan first put on skis.

TITLE: The Washington Football Team's new name is the Washington Commanders
SUMMARY: The big announcement ends 18 months of research, focus groups and fan submissions for the organization's new identity and brand.

TITLE: When did America's culture wars begin, and how can they end? Jon Ronson has answers
SUMMARY: America's culture wars are creating a world of "magnificent heroes and sickening villains" as people fight a fierce battle in black and white, says writer and podcaster Jon Ronson.

TITLE: Another winter storm now threatens a large swath of the Central and Eastern U.S.
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service predicts a prolonged, major winter storm that could travel across parts of the Midwest into the Northeast later this week.

TITLE: These 2 groundhogs have conflicting weather predictions — so take your pick
SUMMARY: On the day when America puts its faith in the paws of furry forecasters, prominent groundhogs Punxsutawney Phil and Staten Island Chuck do not agree on how many more weeks of winter there will be.

TITLE: New Mexico asks National Guard to work as substitute teachers to keep classrooms open
SUMMARY: New Mexico is short 1,000 teachers, National Guard volunteers now serve as substitute teachers

TITLE: U.S. sending troops to Eastern Europe as Russia masses forces near Ukraine
SUMMARY: The Pentagon announced Wednesday that thousands of U.S. troops will soon be dispatched to Eastern Europe amid a major military buildup of Russian forces around Ukraine.

SUMMARY: El Salvador's national soccer team plays its World Cup qualifying match against Canada Wednesday night — with several players and coaches from the United States.

TITLE: Senators make headway on Russia sanctions bill, but two sticking points remain
SUMMARY: Senate Democrats and Republicans are close to striking a deal on a sanctions package for Russia to deter further aggression towards Ukraine. But there's two sticking points.

TITLE: A piece of space junk the size of a school bus is barreling straight toward the moon
SUMMARY: Astronomers predict that on March 4th, a piece of a rocket launched in 2015 will crash into the moon. It's believed to be first time something man-made has accidentally crashed into the moon.

TITLE: U.S. Army begins to discharge soldiers who refuse COVID-19 vaccination
SUMMARY: "Unvaccinated Soldiers present risk to the force and jeopardize readiness," Secretary of the Army Christine Wormuth says. The Army says 96% of active troops have been vaccinated.

SUMMARY: President Biden is relaunching "Cancer Moonshot," an initiative he led as vice president. It aims to dramatically reduce cancer deaths and improve the experience of patients, survivors and families.

SUMMARY: The former bandmates of Neil Young said they were supporting his protest against COVID-19 misinformation on the music streaming platform.

SUMMARY: Some of the troops are being moved from Germany to Romania; others will be deployed from Fort Bragg to bolster positions in Europe.

TITLE: Alexander Vindman sues Trump allies for alleged intimidation over impeachment hearing
SUMMARY: Vindman accuses Donald Trump Jr., Rudy Guiliani and others of conspiring to intimidate and then punish him for testifying in the former president's 2019 impeachment case.

TITLE: Lawmakers urge making Lunar New Year a federal holiday
SUMMARY: Rep. Grace Meng says she introduced the measure to send the message to Asian Americans that they are a valued part of  American society. If the bill passes, it would become the 12th federal holiday.

SUMMARY: The versatile movie star headlined Michelangelo Antonioni's <em>L'Avventura

TITLE: David Crosby, Graham Nash and Stephen Stills ask to pull their content from Spotify
SUMMARY: The former bandmates of Neil Young said they were supporting his protest against COVID-19 misinformation on the music streaming platform.

TITLE: Here's how the Biden administration says it will halve cancer death rates by 2047
SUMMARY: President Biden is relaunching "Cancer Moonshot," an initiative he led as vice president. It aims to dramatically reduce cancer deaths and improve the experience of patients, survivors and families.

TITLE: A butterfly conservatory is shutting down due to right-wing harassment
SUMMARY: The National Butterfly Center in Mission, Texas, has been embroiled in political turmoil after fighting against the erection of a border wall.

TITLE: Explosion fears remain as North Carolina fertilizer plant burns for a third day

SUMMARY: St. Timothy's Episcopal Church and the Episcopal Diocese of Oregon say the ordinance restricting them to two free meal giveaways per week violates their constitutional right to religious expression.

TITLE: So you've got COVID. Here's what to do
SUMMARY: Omicron is still spreading and it's crazy contagious. Experts share 7 steps to deal with an infection, protect your household from getting sick and stay sane in the process.

TITLE: Man accused of killing officers at private college was a former student, school says
SUMMARY: Suspect's mother says "My son is mentally ill and he did something that I could not control and no one could come to help him."

TITLE: Senators make headway on Russia sanctions bill, but 2 sticking points remain
SUMMARY: Senate Democrats and Republicans are close to striking a deal on a sanctions package for Russia to deter further aggression towards Ukraine. But there are two sticking points.

SUMMARY: Mississippi voters approved a medical marijuana initiative in November 2020 but the state Supreme Court invalidated it six months later, ruling the measure was not put properly on the ballot.

TITLE: 4 men arrested in the overdose death of 'The Wire' actor Michael K. Williams
SUMMARY: They are accused of selling fentanyl-laced heroin to Williams, the five-time Emmy nominated actor, best known for his role as a gay robber of drug dealers in the TV series <em>The Wire

TITLE: A church is suing after a town says it can give away free meals only twice per week
SUMMARY: St. Timothy's Episcopal Church and the Episcopal Diocese of Oregon say the ordinance restricting them to two free meal giveaways per week violates their constitutional right to religious expression.

TITLE: The U.S. has conducted a counterterrorism operation in Syria
SUMMARY: The Pentagon did not say who it targeted, but called the mission successful. Local media report civilian causalities.

TITLE: Winter storm packing snow and freezing rain is moving across the U.S.
SUMMARY: By early Thursday thousands were without power across Texas and Oklahoma. Airlines have also canceled thousands of flights because of the storm.

SUMMARY: As the Winter Olympics begin Friday, China is welcoming the world at a time when Beijing's aggressive foreign policy is creating friction with several other parts of the globe.

TITLE: GOP Rep. Rice stands by his impeachment vote of Trump. It could cost him his job
SUMMARY: The South Carolina Republican faces a number of primary challengers, including one who was just endorsed by the former president.

TITLE: Therapists say a new law requiring upfront cost estimates could discourage patients
SUMMARY: Some mental health providers object to the new requirement, which is part of the No Surprises Act. They say giving detailed cost estimates could discourage patients from getting care.

SUMMARY: Being a student parent or student caregiver comes with its own unique challenges — challenges not every college is equipped to help with.

TITLE: Facebook's transition to metaverse has eaten into the social media giant's profits
SUMMARY: Shares dropped more than 20% in after hours trading on news of slowing growth, competition and heavy spending on hardware.

TITLE: U.S. counterterrorism operation in Syria kills civilians, aid group says
SUMMARY: At least thirteen civilians were killed in an attack the Pentagon called "successful."

TITLE: Olympic Committee president will meet with Peng Shuai in Beijing this month
SUMMARY: International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach avoided taking positions on any political controversies ahead of the beginning of the Beijing Winter Games.

TITLE: Calls to volunteer fire departments are at a high but they have few first responders
SUMMARY: Fewer volunteers are answering triple the number of calls they did decades ago and those who do show up tend to be older. Some departments were already stretched thin and then along came the pandemic.

TITLE: Biden says U.S. strike killed ISIS leader in Syria
SUMMARY: The president, who is expected to deliver remarks on the operation later Thursday, said all Americans returned safely from the operation.

TITLE: Sarah Palin's court battle with the 'New York Times' resumes after her COVID illness
SUMMARY: Palin is seeking damages against over an editorial that she says hurt her budding career as a political commentator. The start of the trial was delayed after she tested positive for COVID-19.

TITLE: The Olympic chief will meet with Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai after safety concerns
SUMMARY: International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach avoided taking positions on any political controversies ahead of the beginning of the Beijing Winter Games in a news conference Thursday.

TITLE: What will happen to the International Space Station when it is retired?
SUMMARY: NASA says the International Space Station will stop operating at the end of 2030. After that, the space agency plans to crash the football field-sized craft into a remote part of the Pacific Ocean.

TITLE: Biden says ISIS leader is dead after U.S. strike
SUMMARY: The president said all Americans returned safely from the operation. "Thanks to the bravery of our troops this horrible terrorist leader is no more," Biden said in remarks at the White House.

TITLE: The officer who killed Laquan McDonald is free after three years. Activists are angry
SUMMARY: Former Chicago police officer Jason Van Dyke earned early release from prison. Activists now seek federal charges for violating McDonald's civil rights. He was 17 when he was killed in 2014.

TITLE: As the Olympics open, China seeks the limelight but warns against criticism
SUMMARY: As the Winter Olympics begin Friday, China is welcoming the world at a time when Beijing's aggressive foreign policy is creating friction with several other parts of the globe.

TITLE: Why a 20-year effort by the NFL hasn't led to more minorities in top coaching jobs
SUMMARY: The NFL's Rooney Rule set out to correct inequities at the top of pro football's hierarchy. But today, there are still few minorities in head coaching positions.

TITLE: 2 years after the debacle at the Iowa caucuses, Democrats eye changes to the calendar
SUMMARY: On Feb. 3, 2020, an app meant to streamline the process for Iowa Democrats' presidential contest failed. That added to longstanding criticisms of the caucuses and Iowa's place on the calendar.

TITLE: Ex-Washington football employee brings new harassment claim against owner Dan Snyder
SUMMARY: A day after the Washington Football Team unveiled its new name, former employees appeared on Capitol Hill to share stories of workplace harassment, including a new allegation against Snyder himself.

TITLE: What is known about the ISIS leader who died during a U.S. raid in Syria
SUMMARY: The leader of the Islamic State group who died during a U.S. raid overnight in northwest Syria was largely a mystery, with almost no known photos, never appearing in public or in the group's videos.

TITLE: A winter storm packing snow and freezing rain knocks out power and disrupts flights
SUMMARY: More than 100,000 homes and businesses lost power and  thousands of flights were canceled as states from New Mexico to Maine were placed under winter storm warnings and watches.

TITLE: The Winter Olympics start Friday. Here's how to follow along
SUMMARY: The 2022 Olympics kick off in Beijing on Friday. Here's how to watch the opening ceremony and follow NPR's coverage for the next two weeks.

TITLE: From slavery to socialism, new legislation restricts what teachers can discuss
SUMMARY: Researcher Jeffrey Sachs says that U.S. teachers are being censored for broaching certain topics. One group in New Hampshire is offering a $500 bounty for teachers who discuss critical race theory.

TITLE: The fight for equality in women's ski jumping is about more than ski suits
SUMMARY: The sport's governing body has gotten rid of a rule that required hip-enhancing panels on women's ski suits. Ski jumpers still want to see better pay and more opportunities to compete.

TITLE: Furniture tip-overs are declining but still injure thousands in the U.S. each year
SUMMARY: The Consumer Product Safety Commission also found that there have been 581 tip-over fatalities in the U.S. since 2000. Four in five of the deaths were children.

TITLE: Facebook just had its worst day ever on Wall Street
SUMMARY: Investors wiped more than $200 billion of the market value of Facebook owner Meta after the company warned competition from TikTok is weighing on growth.

TITLE: Uyghur kids recall physical and mental torment at Chinese boarding schools in Xinjiang
SUMMARY: Being hit, locked in a dark room and forced to hold a stress position — two small Uyghur children recount abusive experiences in boarding school in Xinjiang, where they also lost their mother tongues.

TITLE: Amazon raises price of annual Prime membership to $139
SUMMARY: Amazon is increasing the U.S. subscription cost to $139 a year from $119, citing more customer benefits and higher employee wages and transportation costs.

TITLE: A satellite finds massive methane leaks from gas pipelines
SUMMARY: A satellite has detected massive leaks of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, from natural gas plants and pipelines. Most of these releases are deliberate, resulting from sloppy pipeline repairs.

TITLE: U.S. says Russia is planning a staged attack in Ukraine to justify an invasion
SUMMARY: The Biden administration said on Thursday that disinformation campaigns, like a potential false-flag operation, are part of Russia's standard playbook.

TITLE: Brian Flores took a big risk suing the NFL. Here's why he thinks it's worth it
SUMMARY: The ex-head coach of the Miami Dolphins alleges racial discrimination in his suit against the NFL. The ultimate goal is change – even if he gets blackballed in the process, Flores tells NPR.

TITLE: A new study predicts a huge increase in catastrophic hurricanes for the northeastern U.S.
SUMMARY: When hurricanes cause both extreme high tides and heavy rains, devastating floods ensue. Such storms will get much more frequent by the end of the century, according to a new study.

TITLE: Over-the-counter COVID tests will soon be free for Medicare recipients
SUMMARY: The Biden administration said that Medicare recipients will be able to get up to eight tests a month, free of charge.

TITLE: The reporter who broke the gender barrier in NHL locker rooms has died at age 70
SUMMARY: Herman hoped her "mini sports history" moment would go quietly unnoticed. Instead, the locker room quickly devolved into a "circus scene."

TITLE: First Black leader of Human Rights Campaign sues, says he was fired because of race
SUMMARY: Alphonso David also said during contract negotiations HRC board members "acknowledged" that he was severely underpaid in comparison to his white predecessor "because of his race."

TITLE: Greg McMichael reverses plan to plead guilty to a hate crime in Ahmaud Arbery's death
SUMMARY: McMichael and his son Travis had agreed to plead guilty in return for serving time in a federal prison instead of a state one in a deal rejected by a judge after Arbery's parents objected to it.

TITLE: Figure skater Nathan Chen kicks off redemptive Beijing Olympics with a bang
SUMMARY: Chen's showing at the Capital Indoor Stadium in Beijing clenched a season-best international score and helped put U.S. figure skating on top in the team event.

TITLE: U.S. biathletes focus on process in their quest for a first-ever Olympic medal
SUMMARY: The U.S. Biathlon team has never won an Olympic medal — the only U.S. athletes not to do so. New innovations may lead to a medal finish in the combined cross-country skiing and target shooting event.

TITLE: France's Macron to visit Russia and Ukraine next week on mediation trip amid tensions
SUMMARY: While France is a major player in NATO, President Macron has also been actively pushing for dialogue with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The two are set to meet Monday one-on-one.

TITLE: Amazon warehouse workers in Alabama vote for second time in union effort
SUMMARY: Last year, Alabama workers voted against forming the first unionized Amazon warehouse in the U.S. Then, federal labor officials said Amazon unfairly influenced that election. Now, a re-vote begins.

TITLE: Americans get sicker as omicron stalls everything from heart surgeries to cancer care
SUMMARY: Slammed by COVID-19, many U.S. hospitals have put off essential procedures. Delays are leading to consequences like heart attacks and sending people to emergency rooms to get care.

TITLE: The U.S. census's 72-year confidentiality rule has a strange history
SUMMARY: Under federal law, the U.S. government must restrict access to people's records for the once-a-decade tally until 72 years after a count's Census Day. The exact origins of that time span are murky.

TITLE: In Ohio's Senate race, Democrat Ryan hopes to beat the odds with a pitch to workers
SUMMARY: Democratic Rep. Tim Ryan is seeking the U.S. Senate on a pledge to stand up for workers, a key voting bloc for Donald Trump, who carried the increasingly Republican state twice.

TITLE: About 350,000 customers lost power as a winter storm heads to the Northeast
SUMMARY: Texas is facing a test of its power grid after last year's deadly outages. Ice threatens to wreak havoc on travel and electric service as the storm moves toward the Atlantic Ocean.

TITLE: In a big surprise, the job market surged in January even as omicron cases spiked
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added 467,000 jobs last month despite a surge of coronavirus infections. The unemployment rose to 4% from 3.9% in December.

TITLE: The 2022 Winter Olympics open with a colorful but subdued ceremony in Beijing
SUMMARY: The Winter Games kicked off Friday night in Beijing with an eye-catching but scaled-back opening ceremony. China has made history as the first country to host both the Summer and Winter Games.

TITLE: Tongan flag bearer Pita Taufatofua is skipping the Games to focus on volcano relief
SUMMARY: Taufatofua made headlines as Tonga's bare-chested, oiled-up flag bearer at the last three opening ceremonies. He's missing the 2022 Games to help his country recover from January's deadly tsunami.

TITLE: Actor Thandiwe Newton addresses colorism in the casting of films
SUMMARY: While promoting her new movie <em>God's Country

TITLE: How the Winter Olympics are being received in China
SUMMARY: Despite a campaign from China to increase enthusiasm for winter sports, many in the country are indifferent to the Games and excitement is more muted than in 2008.

SUMMARY: The cauldron is a snowflake, with a much smaller flame than usual. It was lit by two Olympians, including an athlete from the Xinjiang Uyghur autonomous region.

TITLE: U.S. House passes bill to bolster competition
SUMMARY: The bill includes a number of provisions, such as $52 billion for chip manufacturing, $45 billion to improve supply chains for critical items, and $160 billion for scientific research and innovation.

TITLE: Greg and Travis McMichael have withdrawn hate crime guilty pleas in Arbery murder
SUMMARY: Travis McMichael on Friday reversed his plan to plead guilty in the federal case days after a judge rejected terms of a plea deal that was met with passionate objections by Ahmaud Arbery's parents.

SUMMARY: More than 220 athletes will represent the United States at the Olympics in Beijing, making it the largest delegation at the Games. Other large teams include China and the Russian Olympic Committee.

SUMMARY: The Winter Games kicked off Friday night in Beijing with an eye-catching but scaled-back opening ceremony. The city has made history as the first to host both the Summer and Winter Games.

TITLE: COVID-19 jeopardizes medal hopes for some Olympic athletes in Beijing
SUMMARY: All the training in the world can't help COVID-positive athletes test negative faster. Even with strict protocols in place, athletes risk missing events as the infections rise inside the Games bubble.

SUMMARY: News Corp. — which owns the publishers of The Wall Street Journal and the New York Post

SUMMARY: Antibody tests may be coming soon to a pharmacy near you. Here's what the tests do — and don't — reveal about you and COVID-19.

SUMMARY: The bill includes a number of provisions, such as $52 billion for chip manufacturing, $45 billion to improve supply chains for critical items, and $160 billion for scientific research and innovation.

TITLE: Why Malta enters before Australia, and other facts about the Parade of Nations
SUMMARY: Hint: The order of countries presented in the Olympics opening ceremony doesn't follow the English Alphabet.

SUMMARY: The Republican National Committee voted to censure the two House GOP members involved in investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol insurrection, which it referred to as "legitimate political discourse."<strong>

SUMMARY: Ice threatens to wreak havoc on travel and power service as the storm moves toward the Atlantic Ocean. Meanwhile. Texas is facing a test of its power grid after last year's deadly outages.

TITLE: Minneapolis police kill a Black man while executing a no-knock warrant

SUMMARY: He co-founded The New York Review of Books and worked with such novelists as E.L. Doctorow, Vladimir Nabokov and Philip Roth.

TITLE: 900,000 Americans have died of COVID in just 2 years of global pandemic
SUMMARY: The U.S. death rate from COVID-19 continues to increase daily, as the rolling seven-day average for daily COVID-19 deaths has been above 2,000 since Jan. 23.

SUMMARY: The lawyer was convicted of charges he cheated the porn actor out of money she was supposed to get for writing a book about an alleged tryst with former President Donald Trump.

SUMMARY: The U.S. death rate from COVID-19 continues to increase daily, as the rolling seven-day average for daily COVID-19 deaths has been above 2,000 since Jan. 23.

TITLE: First Black University of Alabama student to share a building name with a Klan leader

TITLE: Here's how to best protect your home from freezing temperatures
SUMMARY: Icy winter weather can mean frozen pipes or roof damage. Here are some helpful tips for getting your home through the colder months of the year.

SUMMARY: The North Carolina Republican's ability to run for reelection in the fall is being challenged, in part because of his actions on the day of the attack on the U.S. Capitol.

SUMMARY: Beijing previously hosted the 2008 Summer Games. The National Speed Skating Oval is the city's only new ice-sport venue built for the Winter Games.

SUMMARY: The divided court struck down the state's new maps for congressional and General Assembly seats. The ruling is a major victory for Democrats and their allies.

TITLE: Speedskaters at the Winter Olympics are adapting to a new venue and its special ice
SUMMARY: Beijing repurposed some of the sites used in the 2008 Summer Games. The National Speed Skating Oval is the city's only new ice-sport venue built for the Winter Games.

TITLE: Calling Rep. Cawthorn an insurrectionist, challengers aim to keep him off the ballot
SUMMARY: The North Carolina Republican's ability to run for reelection in the fall is being challenged, in part because of his actions on the day of the attack on the U.S. Capitol.

TITLE: Explaining the U.S. military presence in Europe as 2,000 more troops deploy
SUMMARY: The number of U.S. troops in Europe has shrunk dramatically since the end of the Cold War — but tensions with Russia since 2014 have prompted U.S. leaders to beef up numbers and move troops eastward.

TITLE: Newly deployed U.S. troops arrive in Europe as Russia bolsters its own forces
SUMMARY: New satellite images show the buildup of Russian forces and equipment along Ukraine's borders with western Russia, Belarus and Crimea — including new tents, an indicator that troops may be present.

TITLE: A 5-year-old boy has been trapped in a well for days. Rescuers fear for his life
SUMMARY: Online messages of support and concern for the boy trapped in a well in Morocco poured in from around the world as rescue efforts stretched into a fourth day.

TITLE: Post-Confederate law bars Jan. 6 speaker Rep. Cawthorn from office, challengers argue
SUMMARY: The North Carolina Republican is accused of engaging in insurrection, which would make him ineligible for office under the 14th Amendment, which was intended to keep Confederates from holding office.

TITLE: This 8-year-old's book is a hit at his library. He offers advice for aspiring authors
SUMMARY: Dillon Helbig wrote a book over winter break and slipped it onto a local library shelf in Boise, Idaho. After librarians found it, they entered it into their catalog. Now it's on a long waiting list.

TITLE: A 5-year-old boy dies after he was trapped in a well for days
SUMMARY: Moroccan King Mohammed VI expressed his condolences to the boy's parents in a statement released by the palace.

TITLE: Two dead and two injured after a shooting outside of Milwaukee
SUMMARY: The suspect was among those injured at an apartment complex in Brown Deer, Wis., police said. Officials believe there was a shooting inside an apartment as well as in the parking lot.

TITLE: Joe Rogan apologizes for using racial slurs after a video compilation emerges
SUMMARY: Rogan's apology comes as Spotify is promising to combat the spread of COVID-19 misinformation in response to a campaign among musicians to pull their content from the streaming service.

TITLE: A 5-year-old boy dies after he was trapped in a well for 4 days
SUMMARY: Moroccan King Mohammed VI expressed his condolences to the boy's parents in a statement released by the palace. The exact circumstances of how the boy fell in the well are unclear.

TITLE: Overdoses far exceed COVID deaths in a San Francisco district. The mayor has a plan
SUMMARY: San Francisco Mayor London Breed's recent emergency declaration will allow the city to fast-track social services to address drug overdoses and crime.

TITLE: Queen Elizabeth supports a 'Queen Camilla' — shaping the future of the UK monarchy
SUMMARY: In remarks delivered on the eve of the 70th anniversary of her accession to the throne, the monarch said she wants Camilla be known as "Queen Consort" if Charles, the Prince of Wales, succeeds her.

TITLE: 2 dead and 2 injured after a shooting outside of Milwaukee
SUMMARY: The suspect was among those injured at an apartment complex in Brown Deer, Wis., police said. Officials believe there was a shooting inside an apartment as well as in the parking lot.

TITLE: 3 are dead, including the suspect, after a shooting outside of Milwaukee
SUMMARY: The 26-year-old suspect allegedly killed two people at an apartment complex in Brown Deer, Wis., police said. At least one person was injured.

TITLE: The U.S. wins its first medal at the Beijing Olympics in women's snowboarding
SUMMARY: American snowboarder Julia Marino took silver in the women's snowboard slopestyle final on Sunday coming in second after New Zealand's Zoi Sadowski Synnott.

TITLE: U.S. luge racer Emily Sweeney's return to the OIympics is a story of survival
SUMMARY: "I think the more important part of my story for myself at least is that I'm still here," said U.S. luger Emily Sweeney, who suffered a devastating crash at the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

TITLE: A Beijing Olympic luge racer honors his cousin who died at the Vancouver Games
SUMMARY: Twelve years after Nodar Kumaritashvili died in a luge crash at the Vancouver Winter Olympics, his cousin Saba is racing in Beijing. "I wasn't afraid. I wanted to be in the Olympics to race."

TITLE: High winds derail men's downhill ski final at the Winter Olympics
SUMMARY: Referees postponed the men's downhill alpine ski event after officials decided high winds at the Yanqing course posed a safety risk. This comes after multiple days of practice cancellations.

TITLE: No internet, bad food and dirty rooms: Olympic athletes struggle in COVID quarantine
SUMMARY: Olympic organizers scrambled to address major complaints from athletes isolating in Beijing due to positive COVID-19 tests.

TITLE: Tiny homes, big dreams: How some activists are reimagining shelter for the homeless
SUMMARY: From hand-built wooden sheds to Conestoga huts to prefab shelters, tiny homes are cropping up to get people off the streets, especially during the cold of winter and amid the pandemic.

TITLE: An experimental depression treatment uses electric currents to bring relief
SUMMARY: The remedy is a new type of transcranial magnetic stimulation that's showing good results in just five days of treatment. For some patients, it's life-changing.

TITLE: The U.S. is considering a radical rethinking of the dollar for today's digital world
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is considering whether to adopt a digital version of the dollar, one better suited to a world where we are already using Venmo and Apple Pay. Here's what to know.

TITLE: Beijing and Moscow unite in efforts to redefine democracy itself
SUMMARY: In a pointed message to their international critics, the two autocrats declared it was only up to their own people "to decide whether their State is a democratic one."

TITLE: Drug-resistant malaria is emerging in Africa. Doctors are worried — yet hopeful
SUMMARY: Resistance to the drug artemisinin was confirmed in Africa. Without better surveillance, experts say it is hard to track the threat.

TITLE: Lata Mangeshkar, the sweetheart of Bollywood, dies at 92
SUMMARY: She was one of the most famous and beloved playback singers. She recorded songs used in movie soundtracks, which generations of actresses would then lip-sync onscreen.

TITLE: As Queen Elizabeth marks 70 years as monarch, she looks to Camilla and the future
SUMMARY: The monarch said she wants Camilla be known as "Queen Consort" if Charles, the Prince of Wales, succeeds her.

TITLE: The first 2022 Winter Olympic medals have been awarded. Here's what they look like
SUMMARY: Beijing Olympic Committee organizers pulled from Chinese culture and relied on the 2008 medal design for the 2022 gold, silver, and bronze medallions.

TITLE: For many Native Americans, the Washington Commanders' new name offers some closure
SUMMARY: Two women central to efforts to get the NFL team to drop its offensive name say the name change marks an end to a dark chapter that celebrated a harmful stereotype. And yet, their fight isn't over.

TITLE: An estimated 45,000 people have been displaced by a cyclone in Madagascar
SUMMARY: The cyclone has caused widespread damage by blowing the roofs off homes, knocking down trees and utility poles, making roads impassable and flooding many areas.

TITLE: U.S. says Russia has amassed about 75% of the troops it would need to invade Ukraine
SUMMARY: Officials warn that an attack could result in the deaths of tens of thousands of soldiers and civilians, while millions of Ukrainian refugees would be left to flee, likely to nearby Poland.

TITLE: Federal hate crimes trial set to begin for the 3 men charged in Ahmaud Arbery's death
SUMMARY: The Justice Department has charged Travis McMichael, his father Gregory McMichael and their neighbor William "Roddie" Bryan with hate crimes and attempted kidnapping of the 25-year-old.

TITLE: Experts say Delta's call for an unruly passenger no-fly list invites legal turbulence
SUMMARY: The number of disorderly passengers on airplanes has spiked during the pandemic. Now, one airline CEO is renewing his call for a national no-fly list — and asking the U.S. government for backup.

TITLE: The Navy is investigating the death of a SEAL candidate who finished 'Hell Week'
SUMMARY: Kyle Mullen, a 24-year-old, died after completing a 5 1/2-day assessment designed to test SEAL candidates' endurance and mental rigor. A second candidate is in stable condition, the Navy said.

TITLE: U.S. ski champ Mikaela Shiffrin is out of Olympic giant slalom event after falling
SUMMARY: Shiffrin, known as the reigning queen of the slopes, fell in her first run in the giant slalom at the Beijing Olympics. It was the first time she did not finish a giant slalom race in four years.

TITLE: Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star, denies sexual assault by government leader
SUMMARY: In a carefully-managed interview with a French magazine, Peng also said she was retiring from tennis and said her private life should not be brought up in politics or sport.

TITLE: U.S. figure skater Vincent Zhou tests positive for COVID-19 at the Winter Olympics
SUMMARY: Zhou competed on Sunday in the team event as a substitute for three-time world champion Nathan Chen. He is supposed to compete again on Tuesday in the men's short program.

TITLE: No snow? No problem. How Beijing made the white stuff in time for the Olympics
SUMMARY: The Beijing Games are just the latest winter sporting event to use nearly all human-made snow for competitions. Winter sports experts say this is just the new reality.

TITLE: A brain circuit tied to emotion may lead to better treatments for Parkinson's disease
SUMMARY: The symptoms of Parkinson's disease can vanish briefly in the face of stress or a strong emotion. Now scientists are searching for a treatment based on this phenomenon, a form of the placebo effect.

TITLE: The future of the pandemic is looking clearer as we learn more about infection
SUMMARY: Scientists are beginning to come up with answers to the question of how long antibodies from an infection can protect you — and what they'll protect you from.

TITLE: Asia sees a spike in COVID-19 cases after Lunar New Year celebrations
SUMMARY: Health officials are grappling with the highly-transmissible omicron variant and expectations that numbers will continue to rise in coming weeks. But so far there are fewer deaths than with delta.

TITLE: Federal hate crimes trial set to begin for Ahmaud Arbery's convicted killers
SUMMARY: The Justice Department's case against Travis McMichael, Greg McMichael and William "Roddie" Bryan directly addresses their motive in killing Arbery, in contrast to the state trial.

TITLE: Israeli and Palestinian figures propose a plan for an independent state of Palestine
SUMMARY: An independent Palestine and Israel would coordinate on issues that affect both populations in a two-state confederation. The plan by former officials will be submitted to the U.N. and U.S. next week.

TITLE: George Crumb, an influential and deeply American composer, has died at age 92
SUMMARY: The Pulitzer Prize winner, whose music enveloped everything from the horrors of the Vietnam War to the calls of humpback whales, died Sunday.

TITLE: Dutch speedskater Ireen Wüst is the 1st athlete to win individual gold at 5 Olympics
SUMMARY: "Age is just a number. It's just about how you feel. I'm not thinking like, 'I'm 35, I'm too old,' hell no," Wüst said after her latest Olympic feat.

TITLE: Ottawa declares a state of emergency over truckers' growing anti-government protests
SUMMARY: The mayor called the situation "the most serious emergency our city has ever faced." Police are ramping up enforcement as the standoff continues.

TITLE: Low-cost airlines Frontier and Spirit announce they're merging
SUMMARY: The combined airline would offer 1,000 daily flights to more than 145 destinations in 19 countries and directly add 10,000 jobs by 2026.

TITLE: NFL star Alvin Kamara is charged with battery during Vegas visit for Pro Bowl
SUMMARY: The battery reportedly occurred at a nightclub. The running back was arrested without incident and posted bond.

TITLE: New Jersey and Delaware set timelines to end mask mandates for schools
SUMMARY: It's a sign the two Northeastern states are changing how they manage the COVID-19 pandemic as cases from the omicron surge continue to drop.

TITLE: I thought Encanto's songs were forgettable. So I went back to see what I was missing
SUMMARY: After watching <em>Encanto
