SUMMARY: "The enormity of the situation ... the pain of it all, is pretty insane," Zhou said in an emotional video posted to Instagram. A silver medalist in the team event, he was to compete again on Tuesday.

TITLE: Biden says the Nord Stream 2 pipeline won't move ahead if Russia invades Ukraine
SUMMARY: "If Russia invades, that means tanks or troops crossing the border of Ukraine again, there will no longer be a Nord Stream 2," Biden said, without offering specifics.

TITLE: Bomb threats against Black institutions are deeply rooted in U.S. history
SUMMARY: "HBCUs are resilient institutions that will persist through all forms of adversity," the Congressional Bipartisan HBCU Caucus said after bomb threats earlier this month.

TITLE: Why remdesivir, a highly effective treatment, is a last resort for providers
SUMMARY: The antiviral infusion was just revived as an early treatment for COVID patients. But the drug is relatively expensive and hard to administer, relegating it what some are calling "stopgap" status.

TITLE: Connecticut, New Jersey and Delaware set timelines to end mask mandates for schools
SUMMARY: It's a sign the three Northeastern states are changing how they manage the COVID-19 pandemic as cases from the omicron surge continue to drop.

TITLE: Corporate climate pledges are weaker than they seem, a new study reports
SUMMARY: Many companies mislead by using accounting practices that make their environmental goals relatively meaningless or exclude parts of their businesses in their calculations, NewClimate Institute finds.

TITLE: 15 boxes of White House records have been recovered at Trump's Mar-a-Lago
SUMMARY: The 15 boxes of records discovered at Mar-a-Lago should have been transferred to officials from the White House at the end of the Trump administration, officials say.

TITLE: Frontier-Spirit merger promises better deals and service; critics aren't so sure
SUMMARY: The combined airline would offer 1,000 daily flights to more than 145 destinations in 19 countries and directly add 10,000 jobs by 2026. But consumer advocates have their doubts.

TITLE: A judge ordered the U.S. to pay $230 million to victims of a Texas church massacre
SUMMARY: The Air Force failed to put the shooter's name on a database that could have prevented him from legally buying guns. He killed 26 people and injured 22 in Sutherland Springs, Texas, in 2017.

TITLE: Top White House science adviser announces resignation after reports of bullying
SUMMARY: Eric Lander tendered his letter of resignation hours after a Politico article reported that the White House had found that he bullied and demeaned his subordinates.

TITLE: Unlucky curve 13 - Olympic luge racers crash out at same place on Beijing course
SUMMARY: U.S. luge racer Emily Sweeney walked away from a crash on a day when numerous athletes lost control on the newly-built sled track in Yanqing.

TITLE: Civil rights leaders call on the NFL to replace the Rooney Rule
SUMMARY: The Rooney Rule, a policy that went into effect in 2003, requires NFL teams to interview candidates of color for head coaching and senior operation vacancies.

TITLE: 4 states announce they're dropping mask mandates for schools
SUMMARY: It's a sign the three Northeastern states are changing how they manage the COVID-19 pandemic as cases from the omicron surge continue to drop.

TITLE: U.S. figure skater Nathan Chen sparkles in men's single event at Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: Majestic and composed, Chen exulted the skate at the end — shaking off his terrible short performance four years ago at the Pyeongchang Olympics.

TITLE: U.S. Olympic skier River Radamus debuts a wild look in Beijing
SUMMARY: Radamus, an alpine skier, is competing in Beijing for the U.S. during Tuesday's men's super-G race. His crazy hair is a standout.

SUMMARY: Ryan Cochran-Siegle's Vermont family has sent six athletes to the Winter Olympics. His mom, Barbara Cochrane, won gold in Sapporo, Japan as an alpine ski racer in 1972.

SUMMARY: Majestic and composed, Chen exulted the skate at the end — shaking off his terrible short performance four years ago at the Pyeongchang Olympics.

SUMMARY: Beijing Olympic officials said the COVID-19 situation within the closed-loop bubble of the Games is tightly managed now. They may add more spectators to venues as the competitions continue.

SUMMARY: Gu, who is American born to a Chinese mother, is representing China during the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. She has competed under the Chinese flag since 2019.

TITLE: Why buying a car is still such a miserable experience
SUMMARY: Car buyers today continue to face fewer choices and much higher prices – and cheap vehicles are especially hard to find. It's not just that there are fewer cars; the ones being made are fancier, too.

SUMMARY: Representatives of the International Olympic Committee said the risk of catching COVID-19 within the bubble at the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing is far less than it is outside.

SUMMARY: Those records should have been transferred to officials from the White House at the end of the Trump administration, according to federal law.

TITLE: Why remdesivir, a highly effective COVID treatment, is a last resort for providers
SUMMARY: The antiviral infusion was just revived as an early treatment for COVID patients. But the drug is relatively expensive and hard to administer, relegating it to what some are calling "stopgap" status.

SUMMARY: He asked forgiveness for any "grievous faults" in his handling of clergy sex abuse cases, but admitted to no personal or specific wrongdoing after an independent report criticized his actions.

SUMMARY: Diggins snared a hard-won bronze medal in the grueling event after Swedish skiers took an early lead. The only other time a U.S. athlete has won an individual medal in cross country came in 1976.

TITLE: 'The Power of the Dog' and 'Dune' nab the most 2022 Oscar nominations
SUMMARY: Jane Campion's and Denis Villeneuve's films got the highest amount of nominations, 12 and 10 each. <em>Drive My Car,

SUMMARY: Women's groups have petitioned the Delhi High Court to close a legal loophole and criminalize marital rape. A decision is expected soon. Men who oppose the petitions have gone on a "marriage strike."

SUMMARY: John Foley is out after extended tumult at the company, which is also cutting almost 3,000 jobs. Barry McCarthy, who served as CFO at Spotify and Netflix, will take over the CEO position.

TITLE: Inside an Oregon hospital, here's what it takes to provide care through the chaos
SUMMARY: Salem Health in Oregon is a major hospital, but the omicron onslaught has strained the staff like never before. Still, they show up. For the patients, and for each other. And some see signs of hope.

SUMMARY: The suit said that the university ignored decades of complaints and deliberately concealed abuse of several hundred women by former UCLA gynecologist James Heaps.

SUMMARY: Hosted by Tracee Ellis Ross and Leslie Jordan, the Academy named Jane Campion's The Power of the Dog and Denis Villeneuve's Dune

SUMMARY: Women's groups have petitioned the Delhi High Court to close a legal loophole and criminalize marital rape. A decision is expected soon. Men who oppose the petitions have gone on a "marriage strike."

SUMMARY: Car buyers today continue to face fewer choices and much higher prices — and cheap vehicles are especially hard to find. It's not just that there are fewer cars; the ones being made are fancier, too.

SUMMARY: SoftBank has dropped its plans to sell the British semiconductor and software design company Arm to U.S. chipmaker Nvidia. The Federal Trade Commission had sued to block the $40 billion deal.

SUMMARY: New York Times reporter Jeremy Peters says the religious right and social conservatives "got basically everything that they wanted" from Trump's presidency. Peters' new book is Insurgency.

SUMMARY: The so-called "Freedom Convoy" began last month as a caravan of truck drivers who planned to drive to Ottawa to voice their opposition to the government's cross-border vaccine mandate.

SUMMARY: The poverty-fighting charity points to unprecedented new wealth accrued by the ultra-rich — and asserts that the result of the world's growing inequality is "economic violence" for the impoverished.

TITLE: 5 women ski jumpers are disqualified at the Olympics over their jumpsuits
SUMMARY: "The sport of ski jumping has experienced one of its darker days," a Norwegian official said, after athletes from some of the top medal contenders were disqualified from competing.

TITLE: A pub that claims to be England's oldest could close its doors because of COVID
SUMMARY: Ye Olde Fighting Cocks in St. Albans dates back to the 8th century, with a storied past featuring medieval pigeons, Oliver Cromwell and tunnels once traversed by monks. Now its future is uncertain.

SUMMARY: Kotsur was born deaf and grew up in Mesa, Arizona. In <em>CODA

SUMMARY: The Health Resources and Services Administration is distributing $66.5 million to community groups working across 38 states and Washington, D.C. to help with local vaccine outreach.

TITLE: DOJ arrests New York couple and seizes $3.6 billion in bitcoin related to 2016 hack
SUMMARY: Ilya Lichtenstein and Heather Morgan were arrested Tuesday in Manhattan on money laundering and conspiracy charges.

TITLE: You tested positive. The contact tracer never called. Here's why
SUMMARY: Swamped by thousands of calls a day, contact tracing programs have been forced to adapt. Even though they can't call everyone, experts say it's too early to give up on this pillar of disease control.

SUMMARY: As Russian troops threaten to Ukraine, the U.S. is publicizing what it says are Russian attempts to sow disinformation. The goal is to undermine Russian claims that might be used to provoke a war.

TITLE: School leaders say HBCUs are undeterred after a series of bomb threats
SUMMARY: "We have to show that we are not afraid," Dillard University President Walter Kimbrough says. The FBI is probing the threats as racially or ethnically motivated violent extremism and hate crimes.

TITLE: Oxfam says the rich got richer in the pandemic, and the wealth gap is killing the poor
SUMMARY: The poverty-fighting charity points to unprecedented new wealth accrued by the ultra-rich — and asserts that the result of the world's growing inequality is "economic violence" for the impoverished.

TITLE: Coal-dependent West Virginia eliminates ban on nuclear power
SUMMARY: The state's ban on nuclear plants was enacted in 1996, but nuclear power has gained support as a tool to keep climate change under control and other states are transitioning away from fossil fuels.

TITLE: Glaciers are shrinking fast. Scientists are rushing to figure out how fast
SUMMARY: Billions of people rely on glaciers for drinking water, hydropower and irrigation. A raft of new research suggests there is less ice left than previously thought.

TITLE: House passes stopgap bill to avoid government shutdown
SUMMARY: This is the third stopgap spending bill to keep the federal government afloat since October.

TITLE: D.C. sniper's case for reconsidering his sentences is heard by Maryland Supreme Court
SUMMARY: Lee Boyd Malvo's attorneys argue that his six life sentences should be reconsidered because of a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that barred mandatory life sentences for juveniles.

TITLE: Former 'New York Times' editor testifies on Sarah Palin editorial: 'This is my fault'
SUMMARY: Former <em>New York Times

TITLE: If you tested positive and the contact tracer never called, here's why
SUMMARY: Swamped by thousands of calls a day, contact tracing programs have been forced to adapt. Even though they can't call everyone, experts say it's too early to give up on this pillar of disease control.

TITLE: 2 Capitol riot suspects were arrested from online sleuths' info, documents show
SUMMARY: The FBI has cited information compiled by online sleuths in many of the more than 730 riot-related cases filed in federal court so far.

TITLE: Olympic star Mikaela Shiffrin fails to finish a second race at the 2022 Winter Games
SUMMARY: Shiffrin, a two-time Olympic champion, bailed out of the women's slalom race on Wednesday. She previously won a gold medal in this competition in 2014 during the Sochi Olympics.

TITLE: Lindsey Jacobellis wins the U.S. its first gold medal at the 2022 Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: Jacobellis, a five-time Olympian, also won her first gold medal during the women's snowboard cross event on Wednesday.

TITLE: 2 of the U.S.'s snowboard champs are in medal contention at Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: Despite a fall during one of their qualifying runs, Shaun White and Chloe Kim were able to move on to the medal round of the men's and women's halfpipe events.

TITLE: Interior Department hires former top cop to review jail deaths on his watch
SUMMARY: The Interior Department ordered a review of tribal jail deaths, but the man who got the contract is a former agency official who oversaw the jails when some of the deaths occurred.

TITLE: What a bottle of ivermectin reveals about the shadowy world of COVID telemedicine
SUMMARY: An anti-vaccine group known for spreading medical disinformation is writing prescriptions for unproven COVID-19 treatments, with the help of a doctor whose medical license was revoked in Alabama.

TITLE: An unexpected item is blocking cities' climate change prep: obsolete rainfall records
SUMMARY: Cities are experiencing heavier storms and flooding as the climate gets hotter. But due to outdated rainfall records, many are still building infrastructure for the climate of the past.

TITLE: Right-wing conspiracies have a new target: a tool that fights actual voter fraud
SUMMARY: The bipartisan program — called ERIC — allows states to improve voting access and election security at the same time. But it's currently under attack from the far-right.

TITLE: A new program in Canada gives doctors the option of prescribing national park visits
SUMMARY: And the best part? The annual passes are free.

TITLE: Olympic star Mikaela Shiffrin doesn't finish a second race at the 2022 Winter Games
SUMMARY: Shiffrin, a two-time Olympic champion, did not to finish the women's slalom race on Wednesday. She previously won a gold medal in this competition in 2014 during the Sochi Olympics.

TITLE: New Zealand convoy clogs streets near Parliament to protest vaccine mandates
SUMMARY: Among the protesters' grievances is the requirement in New Zealand that certain workers get vaccinated against the coronavirus, including teachers, doctors, nurses, police and military personnel.

TITLE: Mitch McConnell criticizes the RNC for censuring 2 Republicans on Jan. 6 panel
SUMMARY: In a rare break with his party, the Senate minority leader said that it's not the RNC's job to single out party members with different views, referring to Reps. Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger.

TITLE: A fluffy panda mascot is all the rage at the Winter Olympics
SUMMARY: The stuffed animal version of mascot Bing Dwen Dwen has become so sought after that people are camping overnight to buy it in Beijing.

TITLE: A motorcycle tire stuck around a crocodile's neck for 6 years is finally removed
SUMMARY: The beast was seen on Palu's river with the tire around its neck becoming increasingly tighter, running the risk of choking her.

TITLE: 'Don't Say Gay' bill would limit discussion of sexuality and gender in Florida schools
SUMMARY: Supporters say the measure empowers parents to have a say in what their children learn. Critics argue it will harm LGBTQ kids. President Biden slammed the bill, which has Gov. Ron DeSantis' support.

TITLE: Colorado Springs will pay $3 million to family of a Black man fatally shot by police
SUMMARY: The city has reached a settlement in a lawsuit brought by the family of 19-year-old De'Von Bailey, who died after being shot in the back by police officers in 2019.

TITLE: A Welsh company is taking its whole staff on vacation as a reward for pandemic work
SUMMARY: Cardiff-based Yolk Recruitment Ltd. is taking its more than 50 employees on an all-expenses-paid vacation to the island of Tenerife in April. The four-day trip will reportedly cost more than $135,515.

TITLE: The Dutch vow to egg Jeff Bezos' yacht if a bridge is dismantled to let his boat pass
SUMMARY: After early reports that Rotterdam would briefly take apart a historic bridge for the yacht's passage, thousands of people joined a Facebook event called "Throwing eggs at superyacht Jeff Bezos."

TITLE: New York lifts indoor mask mandate, with California and N.J. mandates also set to end
SUMMARY: New York will no longer require masks in most indoor public settings, but they will still be required in schools and health care facilities. Several other states have made similar moves this week.

TITLE: Bipartisan duo say voters want Congress to stop trading stocks, leaders open to a vote
SUMMARY: Virginia Democratic Rep. Abigail Spanberger and Texas Republican Chip Roy say their bill to ban lawmakers from picking stocks is picking up steam. Top leaders have now signed on, showing momentum.

TITLE: SpaceX says up to 40 of its new Starlink satellites are falling out of orbit
SUMMARY: The satellites that can't maintain orbit will burn up as they reenter Earth's atmosphere, SpaceX says. A geomagnetic storm hit the day after they were launched.

TITLE: Explaining why natural gas plays such a big role in the Russia-Ukraine crisis
SUMMARY: As much as 40% of Europe's natural gas supply comes from Russia, a reliance that puts U.S. allies like Germany in a jam when it comes to finding a sanctions solution to the crisis.

TITLE: Take a look at SARS-CoV-2's family tree. It's full of surprises
SUMMARY: The family history of SARS-CoV-2 is not what virologists expected — and sheds light on the virus that launched a pandemic. Check out our illustration of the virus' family tree.

TITLE: People who work at Dollywood will soon be eligible for free tuition
SUMMARY: The Dolly Parton amusement park's parent company will fund all tuition and fees for select programs. "Their futures should be grown with love, not loans," Herschend Enterprises CEO Andrew Wexler says.

TITLE: TikTok bans misgendering, deadnaming from its content
SUMMARY: The changes are part of updated guidelines designed to improve safety and security on TikTok. It will also pull content that promotes disordered eating and restrict content related to dangerous acts.

TITLE: Jan. 6 panel subpoenas former Trump White House trade advisor Peter Navarro
SUMMARY: The House Jan. 6 panel says former Trump White House trade advisor Peter Navarro documented, in his own book, efforts to delay certification of 2020 election results.

TITLE: Senators announce a deal to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act
SUMMARY: The bipartisan announcement comes after months of negotiations in the chamber. The legislation offers resources for victims of domestic abuse and sexual violence.

TITLE: U.K. soccer player Kurt Zouma is under fire after a video showed him abusing cats
SUMMARY: The West Ham United player has been fined for his actions and the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has launched an investigation into the matter.

TITLE: Friends who have attended every Super Bowl are planning their final trip
SUMMARY: The far-flung friends, all in their 80s, use the Super Bowl to meet up, spend time together and reminisce. But in recent years they've come to grips with the fact it must come to an end one day

TITLE: 1 in 5 Patriot Front applicants say they have ties to the military
SUMMARY: The group, which is a rebrand of a group that attended the "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Va., has created an image of Americana bolstered by racism, antisemitism and neo-fascism.

TITLE: Snoop Dogg now owns Death Row Records
SUMMARY: "It feels good to have ownership of the label I was part of at the beginning of my career and as one of the founding members," the 50-year-old rapper and mogul said.

TITLE: Actor Bob Saget died in his sleep after hitting his head, his family says
SUMMARY: The Saget family says they have been "overwhelmed with the incredible outpouring of love" from his fans, saying the support has been "a great comfort" to them.

TITLE: NFL says it will control investigation into Commanders owner Dan Snyder, not the team
SUMMARY: Hours after the team's announcement of its independent investigation, the NFL said the team "would not control the probe."

TITLE: U.S. snowboarder Chloe Kim makes history winning second Olympic halfpipe gold
SUMMARY: Kim dominated the leaderboard after her stellar first run at the women's snowboard halfpipe event on Thursday, Feb. 10 in Beijing. She's the first woman to win multiple Olympic golds in the halfpipe.

TITLE: U.S.'s Nathan Chen wins gold in men's figure skating at the Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: The 22-year-old Chen topped a competitive field Thursday in Beijing. Figure skaters from Japan came in second and third.

TITLE: Jan. 6 panel subpoenas former Trump White House trade adviser Peter Navarro
SUMMARY: The House Jan. 6 panel says former Trump White House trade adviser Peter Navarro documented, in his own book, efforts to delay certification of 2020 election results.

TITLE: The Philippines welcomes back foreign travelers after nearly 2 years
SUMMARY: The Philippines lifted a nearly 2-year ban on fully vaccinated foreign travelers Thursday to boost tourism and related industries as an omicron-fueled surge eases.

TITLE: Indian state begins voting in key test for PM Narendra Modi's ruling party
SUMMARY: The state polls in Uttar Pradesh – India's most populous with over 230 million people – are a test for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party ahead of general elections in 2024.

TITLE: On a new album, 'Heterosexuality,' Shamir tackles the trauma of being oneself
SUMMARY: Shamir's new album, 'Heterosexuality,' confronts how the public viewed him back in 2014, when his debut single nearly made him a pop star at the age of 19.

TITLE: How dairy farmers are cashing in on California's push for cleaner fuel
SUMMARY: Big dairy farms are profiting from California's tougher limits on greenhouse emissions. They're getting paid to capture methane from cow manure. But critics say the system subsidizes polluters.

TITLE: Tonga's COVID outbreak is growing rapidly with omicron cases confirmed
SUMMARY: Health Minister Saia Piukala told reporters that 31 more people had tested positive for the COVID-19, nearly doubling Tonga's active cases for the second day in a row, local media reported.

TITLE: With evictions on the rise, House Democrats team up to push new housing protections
SUMMARY: Three Democrats are hoping to provide a legislative lifeline to tenants facing eviction. But the bill faces some steep hurdles in Congress.

TITLE: Biden administration to reverse Medicaid changes that Trump had OK'd in some states
SUMMARY: Federal officials now say states can no longer charge premiums to low-income residents enrolled in Medicaid and have ruled out work requirements.

TITLE: She's 30 and has never seen inflation this high. Her mom remembers when it was worse
SUMMARY: People under 40 have never seen inflation as high as it is right now, but their parents lived through even sharper price hikes. That colors how each generation views the economy.

TITLE: Amid a housing crisis, renters challenge firms they say are being exploitative
SUMMARY: Low-income housing is in crisis - corporate landlords are squeezing renters with higher rents in often unsafe housing units. Renters are fighting back

TITLE: The economy is strong but voters aren't feeling it. That's a problem for Biden
SUMMARY: President Biden's first year in the White House has been marked by record GDP growth and job gains, so why do voters keep giving him poor marks on the economy?

TITLE: Uber adds passengers, food orders amid omicron surge
SUMMARY: Rival Lyft predicted the omicron surge would hinder growth, a sign that despite easing health restrictions, ride-hailing apps are still adapting to the pandemic.

TITLE: A top researcher says it's time to rethink our entire approach to preschool
SUMMARY: A long-term study of a statewide preschool program tracked students through the sixth grade, and found those who attended prekindergarten falling behind.

TITLE: U.S. snowboarder Chloe Kim makes history winning 2nd Olympic halfpipe gold
SUMMARY: Kim dominated the leaderboard after her stellar first run at the women's snowboard halfpipe event on Thursday in Beijing. She's the first woman to win multiple Olympic golds in the halfpipe.

TITLE: Former major leaguer Jeremy Giambi dies in California at 47
SUMMARY: Jeremy Giambi spent six seasons in the major leagues.  He died Wednesday at his parents' home in Southern California, police and his agent said.

TITLE: Inflation hits another 40-year high. It's bad, but older folks say they've seen worse
SUMMARY: Consumer prices in January were up 7.5% from a year ago, the biggest annual gain since 1982. That may seem like a lot for those under 40, but older folks have lived through even sharper price hikes.

TITLE: Nathan Chen wins gold in men's figure skating at the Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: The 22-year-old Chen topped a competitive field Thursday in Beijing. Figure skaters from Japan came in second and third.

TITLE: Olympic figure skaters' medals are in limbo over a (new) Russian doping scandal
SUMMARY: Reports have surfaced that Kamila Valieva, 15, tested positive for a heart drug called trimetazidine, which can boost athletes' endurance and blood efficiency.

TITLE: Biden administration will reverse Medicaid changes that Trump had OK'd in some states
SUMMARY: Federal officials now say states can no longer charge premiums to low-income residents enrolled in Medicaid and have ruled out work requirements.

TITLE: Congress approves bill to end forced arbitration in sexual assault cases
SUMMARY: The bipartisan bill bans employers from inserting provisions in contracts that require individuals who allege claims of sexual assault or harassment to go through a secretive process.

TITLE: How Trump sought to use fake electors, conspiracy theories to remain in power
SUMMARY: <em>New York Times

TITLE: Automakers face even more supply chain pain as Canadian protesters block a key bridge
SUMMARY: Car makers are canceling some production shifts as protests over public health measures in Canada shut a key bridge that connects Detroit to Ontario.

TITLE: La. Senate candidate Gary Chambers burns a Confederate flag in his new campaign ad
SUMMARY: The Democratic U.S. Senate candidate from Louisiana made headlines last month by smoking marijuana in a campaign ad. Now he's back with another lighter and a message about gerrymandering.

TITLE: Bill that would give the U.S. Postal Service a major overhaul moves to the Senate
SUMMARY: The embattled USPS has been losing billions of dollars annually in recent years. The bill, which focuses on cutting health care costs, would result in $50 billion in savings over 10 years.

TITLE: The Portland Pickles need your help finding their stolen mascot, Dillon T. Pickle
SUMMARY: After being lost in transit for days, Dillon T. Pickle was shipped to the team's office — only to be stolen off its porch. The team is offering a reward for information or a no questions asked return.

TITLE: Watch these robotic fish swim to the beat of human heart cells
SUMMARY: Tiny, robotic fish powered by human heart cells suggest that scientists are getting closer to their goal of building replacement hearts from living tissue.

TITLE: Meet the first Black skeleton athlete to compete for the U.S. at the Olympics
SUMMARY: Skeleton is a heart-racing event where a single racer flies face first down a frozen track. The inherent pressure of being "the first" and "only" isn't phasing her, Kelly Curtis said.

TITLE: In rural America, patients are waiting for care — sometimes with deadly consequences
SUMMARY: When cancer survivor Katie Ripley got pneumonia, the 25-bed hospital in her small town didn't have the specialized care she needed. But with omicron surging, there was no ICU bed to transfer her to.

TITLE: Russia holds a massive military exercise with Belarus, raising concerns in Ukraine
SUMMARY: "The buildup of troops along the borders is psychological pressure from our neighbors," Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said. Belarus is a possible route for Russian troops to invade Ukraine.

TITLE: Truckers may try to disrupt Super Bowl and the State of the Union, DHS memo says
SUMMARY: A Department of Homeland Security memo says truckers protesting vaccine requirements are planning a potential disruption at the Super Bowl in Los Angeles and the State of the Union in Washington, D.C.

TITLE: The hamsters of Hong Kong offer a cautionary COVID tale
SUMMARY: A new study documents that infected hamsters, imported from the Netherlands, passed the virus on to humans. Previously only minks had been identified as a source of animal-to-human transmission.

TITLE: Abortions in Texas fell 60% in the first month after its new law took effect
SUMMARY: The numbers offer a fuller picture of the sharp drop in patients that Texas doctors have described in their clinics over the past five months.

TITLE: A Canadian judge has frozen access to donations for the trucker convoy protest
SUMMARY: After losing access to GoFundMe campaigns, those involved with "Freedom Convoy 2022" then moved to Christian fundraising site GiveSendGo.

TITLE: Lawmakers question Interior Dept.'s awarding of contract to review tribal jail deaths
SUMMARY: Lawmakers are pushing for a "do-over" of an Interior Department contract to review tribal jail deaths awarded to a former official. Nearly half of the deaths he was to review occurred on his watch.

TITLE: Bob Saget's death shows how dangerous an untreated head injury can be, experts say
SUMMARY: Actor and comedian Bob Saget's death was caused by a blow to the head that he appeared to ignore before going to bed. Medical experts say you should always seek care if you experience a head trauma.

TITLE: Star Russian skater tested positive for a banned substance before Beijing Olympics
SUMMARY: Officials with the International Testing Agency say 15-year-old Kamila Valieva tested positive for a banned heart medication in December.  It's unclear why she was cleared to compete in Beijing.

TITLE: Shaun White finishes fourth in men's halfpipe, wrapping up storied Olympic career
SUMMARY: The 2022 Beijing Olympics is White's last competition as a professional snowboarder. He is the first, and only, snowboarder to win three Olympic gold medals.

TITLE: Police solve 1964 rape and murder of girl with help of DNA and a student
SUMMARY: New technology and the help of a volunteer college student help solve what is believed to be the fourth-oldest cold case in the U.S. using genetic genealogy.

TITLE: With a 9th place finish in Beijing, Mikaela Shiffrin shows signs of bouncing back
SUMMARY: Shiffrin had previously failed to finish two qualifying runs in two separate events earlier this week.

TITLE: SpaceX's Elon Musk says 1st orbital Starship flight could be as early as March
SUMMARY: SpaceX's Elon Musk said Thursday that the first orbital flight of his towering Starship could come soon. NASA plans to use the fully reusable Starship to land astronauts on the moon as early as 2025.

TITLE: A man in upstate New York is fighting to keep his emotional support pig
SUMMARY: Wyverne Flatt says his 110-pound potbellied pig Ellie is "family." Officials in his village of Canajoharie see it very differently. To them, the pig is a farm animal Flatt is harboring illegally.

TITLE: Biden says he's done a 'deep dive' on 4 Supreme Court candidates
SUMMARY: President Biden has been spending a lot of time courting senators — from both sides of the aisle — ahead of making his decision on who to nominate for a vacant seat on the Supreme Court.

TITLE: Online betting companies are kicking off a Super Bowl ad blitz
SUMMARY: What was once a niche sector in Las Vegas has grown into a national mega-business that people can enjoy from their living rooms — and the advertising dollars have followed.

TITLE: U.K. lifts all testing requirements for vaccinated travelers starting today
SUMMARY: Residents and visitors who have had at least two doses of an approved vaccine now only need to fill out a form before entering the U.K. Unvaccinated people must test both before and after arriving.

TITLE: COMIC: Finding peace with singlehood in a society that wants everyone to partner up
SUMMARY: In a world that wants everyone partnered up, this comic by Meghan Keane and LA Johnson offers tips from the experts on how to find peace with singleness and live a full life on your own terms.

TITLE: Raveena's galactic journey back down to Earth
SUMMARY: On her new album, <em>Asha's Awakening

TITLE: Sudan's military rulers step up crackdown and arrests of activists
SUMMARY: Hundreds of activists and protest leaders have been targeted since a military coup last October removed a transitional government from power. The detentions have intensified in recent weeks.

TITLE: Why your Super Bowl chicken wings will cost more this year
SUMMARY: There's no fowl play here — just blame the supply chain, our comfort food habits and a simple fact of nature. Wings might be pricier, but there's no shortage of them, experts say.

TITLE: Biden tells U.S. citizens to leave Ukraine, saying military wouldn't rescue them
SUMMARY: "That's a world war — when Americans and Russians start shooting at one another, we're in a very different world than we've ever been in," President Biden said.

TITLE: Shaun White finishes 4th in men's halfpipe, wrapping up storied Olympic career
SUMMARY: The 2022 Beijing Olympics are White's last competition as a professional snowboarder. He is the first, and only, snowboarder to win three Olympic gold medals.

TITLE: Ian McDonald, founding member of King Crimson and Foreigner, has died
SUMMARY: The multi-instrumentalist initially came blazing onto the scene with his saxophone on the opening cut of King Crimson's first album, <em>In the Court of the Crimson King

TITLE: California sues Tesla over alleged rampant discrimination against Black employees
SUMMARY: California' Department of Fair Employment and Housing said in a lawsuit filed Wednesday that Black employees at Tesla's Fremont plant in the state have faced racism and harassment.

TITLE: Japan's Oscar-nominated 'Drive My Car' is a journey through loss, grief and art
SUMMARY: Directed by Ryusuke Hamaguchi and adapted from a 2014 short story by Haruki Murakami, the film dramatizes some of the celebrated author's trademark themes: loss, guilt, the interplay of art and life.

TITLE: Koalas are now officially an endangered species in parts of eastern Australia
SUMMARY: Australia's government declared koalas endangered in certain regions, citing the impacts of drought, bush fires and deforestation. The koala population dropped a reported 30% between 2018 and 2021.

TITLE: For travel nurses, jobs at home can't come close to pay they get on the road
SUMMARY: The pandemic pay for traveling nurses was too good to pass up for many RNs. But some are ready to settle down at home, and they're finding full-time jobs aren't keeping up with salary increases.

TITLE: The first images from NASA's new space telescope show how it's coming into focus
SUMMARY: The James Webb Space Telescope has seen its first star light, but its 18 mirror segments aren't yet perfectly aligned. As a result, the pictures it's sending back now aren't exactly cosmic eye candy.

TITLE: On 'Bloody Sunday,' Harris reflects on the current fight for voting rights
SUMMARY: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Selma, Ala., to commemorate a defining moment in the struggle for the right to vote.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 6)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: A cease-fire to evacuate civilians from the Ukrainian city of Mariupol fails again
SUMMARY: It was the second day in a row that a cease-fire to allow the evacuation of civilians from the port city fell apart.

TITLE: Thousands have been detained in anti-war protests across Russia
SUMMARY: As of Sunday, an independent monitoring group reports over 4,500 were detained across 63 cities, including Moscow and St. Petersburg.

SUMMARY: South Koreans in their 20s and 30s make up a third of voters, and candidates want to win them over. Many young voters are over the folks in power, a lot of whom are from an activist generation.

SUMMARY: What started as an art project at a California elementary school has gone viral. The free hotline offers wise advice and encouraging messages from kids to anyone who calls.

SUMMARY: Both countries are huge suppliers of grains and other essential foods. And with widespread hunger and high food prices already, the war couldn't have come at a worse time.

TITLE: Watching Ukraine, Bosnians relive the trauma of their war
SUMMARY: Bosnian Serb forces laid siege to Sarajevo in the early 1990s. Some 350,000 people were trapped, subjected to daily shelling and cut off from regular access to electricity, food and medicine.

SUMMARY: Vladimir Putin warned Saturday that Ukrainian statehood is in jeopardy and likened the West's sanctions on Russia to "declaring war" as Russian troops continued to shell encircled cities

TITLE: At least 7 are dead after a large tornado hit central Iowa
SUMMARY: Emergency management officials in Madison County said four were injured in addition to those killed when the tornado touched down southwest of Des Moines.

SUMMARY: After a coaching career spanning four decades, Coach Mike Krzyzewski  has coached his final home game with the Duke Blue Devils, a game that saw Duke upset by the North Carolina Tar Heels 94-81.

SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: The new travel advisory was issued over heightened security concerns in the country as Russian military forces carry out an "unprovoked and unjustified attack" in Ukraine.

TITLE: Nearly 1 million Ukrainians have fled. More than 40 million have stayed — for now
SUMMARY: Before the war, Ukrainian Rehina Solodovnik tutored Russian students online. The teaching has stopped, but she's still getting text messages. "I am so sorry for our government," one student said.

SUMMARY: Health care experts say that confirmed deaths represent a fraction of the true number of deaths due to COVID because of limited testing.

SUMMARY: Huckaby took third in a division of women's snowboard cross, but, despite a gold in the 2018 games, she wasn't allowed to compete until a court ruled in January she could.

SUMMARY: Speaking in Moldova, Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged Americans to leave Russia and vowed to support any American being held by Russia.

SUMMARY: A third round of talks is planned for Monday as some of the evacuation routes would funnel civilians toward Russia or its ally Belarus.

SUMMARY: The state's program of free cancer screening and treatment is reducing inequities. Key to its success is robust outreach by patient navigators who connect with those least likely to seek care.

SUMMARY: Republicans believe COVID-19 policies largely backed by Democrats are causing a schism among parents of school-age children and that will help the GOP win elections this year up and down the ballot.

SUMMARY: Negative campaigns are aggravating South Korea's already severe political divide as presidential elections approach on Wednesday.

SUMMARY: Health care experts say that confirmed deaths represent a fraction of the true number of deaths due to COVID because of limited testing.

SUMMARY: Former Attorney General William Barr spoke with NPR about his new memoir, former President Trump's election lies and why he thinks Trump shouldn't try to return to the White House.

SUMMARY: The prospect that the U.S. and its allies could impose new sanctions on Russian oil pushed energy prices sharply higher. The average price of gasoline in the U.S. hit $4.06 per gallon.

SUMMARY: Levi's is suspending commercial operations in Russia, citing its aggression in Ukraine. The company's iconic blue jeans represented freedom and capitalism during the days of the Soviet Union.

SUMMARY: Many WNBA players head overseas to play during the off-season, where they can be paid much more than they earn in the U.S. Griner, who was arrested for allegedly transporting drugs, is one of them.

SUMMARY: The reported Russian effort to find Syrians with urban combat experience is the latest indication that Russia's invasion of Ukraine is not going as planned.

SUMMARY: The NFL said Ridley placed several bets last November while he was taking a break from football. It found no evidence that Ridley had inside information or that his team knew he had placed the bets.

TITLE: It keeps getting worse for stocks. Dow sinks and enters what's called a correction
SUMMARY: Fear of higher energy prices led to a sharp selloff in Wall Street, with the Nasdaq now in what's known as a "bear market."

TITLE: The Pentagon is shutting down a facility that leaked oil into Pearl Harbor's water
SUMMARY: The tanks, built into the side of a mountain during World War II to protect them from enemy attack, had leaked into a drinking water well and contaminated water at Pearl Harbor homes and offices.

TITLE: At a Russian Restaurant in NYC, the terrors of war hit home
SUMMARY: Russian and Ukrainian workers at Russian Samovar are united in their opposition to the war.

TITLE: Pentagon asks Supreme Court to allow it to stop the deployment of unvaccinated SEALs
SUMMARY: The request comes after a federal judge in Texas blocked the Navy from halting the deployment of Navy SEALs who won't comply with the military's vaccine mandate.

SUMMARY: Many WNBA players head overseas to play during the off-season, where they can be paid much more than they earn in the U.S. Griner, who was arrested for allegedly transporting drugs, is one of them.

TITLE: Stolichnaya Vodka rebrands as 'Stoli,' trying to distance itself from Putin
SUMMARY: Company leaders explained vehement opposition to Russian President Vladimir Putin and his invasion of Ukraine. They also hope the new name will represent "Stoli's roots in Latvia."

TITLE: Russia is restricting social media. Here's what we know
SUMMARY: Russians face a confusing patchwork of online restrictions as the Kremlin cracks down on the free flow of information on social media.

TITLE: After more than a century of trying, Congress passes an anti-lynching bill
SUMMARY: Passage of the legislation to make lynching a federal crime is a major milestone after more than 200 attempts to pass such legislation failed over the course of a century.

TITLE: Gregg Popovich ties the NBA record for most coaching wins
SUMMARY: The San Antonio coach will try to set the record for most coaching wins on Wednesday.

TITLE: New Zealand changes its tack on surging COVID-19 cases
SUMMARY: Experts say New Zealand's actions have likely saved thousands of lives by allowing the nation to mostly avoid earlier, more deadly variants and buying time to get people vaccinated.

TITLE: 1 teen is dead, 2 are wounded in a shooting outside an Iowa high school
SUMMARY: A teenager was killed and two others were critically wounded after gunfire that appeared to come from a passing vehicle struck them outside an Iowa school, authorities in Des Moines said.

TITLE: What the war in Syria tells about Russia's use of humanitarian corridors
SUMMARY: Observers say Russia's use of such corridors were effective in attaining the goals of regaining control of opposition areas.

SUMMARY: The Emmett Till Anti-Lynching Act designates lynching as a federal hate crime and sets prison terms of up to 30 years for those convicted.

TITLE: Russia's invasion puts a new light on Trump's Ukraine pressure campaign
SUMMARY: With Russia's brutal invasion and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy being hailed as a hero, Trump's infamous 2019 call to Zelenskyy is put into a very different light.

TITLE: East Africa is responsible for America's favorite morning brew
SUMMARY: America owes its favorite beverage to East Africa, says a Memphis coffee shop owner whose trip to Ethiopia transformed his understanding of the beverage.

TITLE: As misinformation swirls, many N.H. towns will vote on ballot counting machines
SUMMARY: Activists contend, without proof, that New Hampshire's ballot counting machines can be hacked or rigged. So voters in more than a dozen towns will decide whether to revert to hand counts.

SUMMARY: The national average for a gallon of regular gasoline is now 4.17 according to AAA. That surpasses the previous record set in the summer of 2008, when not accounting for inflation.

SUMMARY: The Emmett Till Anti-Lynching Act, which sets prison terms of up to 30 years, has been more than a century in the making.

SUMMARY: In <em>One Damn Thing After Another,

SUMMARY: Young voters are considered a key voting bloc as the ruling Democratic Party and the conservative opposition People Power Party vie to secure the presidency. But gender issues divide South Koreans.

TITLE: Returning to the office, a moment of joy for some. Others, would rather stay home

TITLE: What the war in Syria tells us about Russia's use of humanitarian corridors
SUMMARY: Observers say Russia's use of such corridors were effective in attaining the goals of regaining control of opposition areas.

SUMMARY: At church, Ukrainians pray for an end to war. But a rift is forming: The head of the Russian Orthodox Church has defended Moscow's invasion. Some in Ukraine want to break away from his leadership.

SUMMARY: The national average for a gallon of regular gasoline is now 4.17 according to AAA. That surpasses the previous record set in the summer of 2008, when not accounting for inflation.

TITLE: 6 teens have been arrested in a shooting that killed 1 outside an Iowa school
SUMMARY: A teenager was killed and two others were critically wounded after gunfire that appeared to come from a passing vehicle struck them, authorities in Des Moines said.

TITLE: After an Alzheimer's diagnosis, her husband asked for help to die with dignity
SUMMARY: Novelist Amy Bloom talks about how, at her husband's insistence, she traveled with him to Zurich so he could legally terminate his life. Her new memoir is <em>In Love

SUMMARY: The Biden administration's new program enables high-risk patients who test positive to get antiviral pills on the spot in some pharmacies. But many pharmacies won't be able to participate.

SUMMARY: Disney employees are expressing their outrage over the entertainment company's decision not to denounce Florida's proposed 'Don't Say Gay' bill.

TITLE: In the first Jan. 6 trial, a jury found Capitol riot defendant Guy Reffitt guilty

TITLE: Ukrainian athletes are dominating the Paralympics, despite the uncertainty at home

TITLE: McDonald's temporarily closes all its Russia locations, joining the corporate exodus
SUMMARY: McDonald's is temporarily closing its 850 locations in Russia, in one of the most symbolic exits by a global corporation from the country in protest over the invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Enrique Tarrio, who led the Proud Boys, is arrested over the U.S. Capitol attack
SUMMARY: Enrique Tarrio may not have physically taken part on the Jan. 6 breach, but the Justice Department has charged him for allegedly leading the advance planning and taking credit for it on social media.

TITLE: Stalled and frustrated, Putin will likely double-down in the coming weeks, CIA says
SUMMARY: CIA Director William Burns says Russia's invasion of Ukraine has fallen far short of Vladimir Putin's expectations. Burns now predicts weeks of 'ugly fighting' for control of Ukraine's cities.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 8)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: NASA is just now opening a vacuum-sealed sample it took from the moon 50 years ago
SUMMARY: Astronauts hammered collection tubes into the lunar surface on the last Apollo mission to the moon. Now a sample is being carefully pierced open —  to be analyzed by today's latest tech.

TITLE: A Ghislaine Maxwell juror says he regrets not disclosing his sex abuse history
SUMMARY: A judge questioned the juror extensively as part of an effort to decide whether the revelation about his personal history as a sex abuse survivor will spoil the verdict in the sex trafficking trial.

TITLE: McDonald's, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Starbucks join a corporate exodus from Russia
SUMMARY: The big American companies are the latest to suspend their operations in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Georgia spaceport goes to a vote as proponents try to invalidate the election
SUMMARY: Officials who have spent a decade and $10.3 million pursuing the spaceport ask the Georgia Court of Appeals to prohibit certification of the vote until their legal challenge gets resolved.

TITLE: GM plans to test using electric vehicles as a power backup for homes
SUMMARY: General Motors and California's Pacific Gas & Electric are aiming to test the technology by this summer. Ford previously announced a similar feature on its electric F-150 Lightning  pickup.

TITLE: Stalled and frustrated, Putin will likely double down in the coming weeks, CIA says
SUMMARY: CIA Director William Burns says Russia's invasion of Ukraine has fallen far short of Vladimir Putin's expectations. Burns now predicts weeks of 'ugly fighting' for control of Ukraine's cities.

TITLE: Even in the offseason, the NFL dazzles with big quarterback news
SUMMARY: One Super Bowl-winning quarterback, Russell Wilson, appears to be switching teams. Another former NFL champion, Aaron Rodgers, is staying put after much speculation that he'd leave.

TITLE: Congress passes bill to shore up the Postal Service without cutting back on delivery
SUMMARY: Congress mustered rare bipartisan support for the Postal Service package, dropping some of the more controversial proposals to settle on core ways to save the service and ensure its future operations.

TITLE: Stalled and frustrated, Putin will likely 'double down' in the coming weeks, CIA says
SUMMARY: CIA Director William Burns says Russia's invasion of Ukraine has fallen far short of Vladimir Putin's expectations. Burns now predicts weeks of "ugly" fighting for control of Ukraine's cities.

TITLE: Sex abuse lawsuit against Prince Andrew has been formally dismissed by a judge
SUMMARY: Lawyers revealed three weeks ago that they had tentatively agreed to a settlement in which the prince would donate to Virginia Giuffre's charity and declare he didn't intend to malign her character.

TITLE: Voters reject spaceport plan long pursued by Georgia county
SUMMARY: Critics, including the National Park Service, said exploding rockets after launch could rain fiery debris onto surrounding land, including a federally protected wilderness.

TITLE: Venezuela releases 2 Americans after visit from U.S. officials
SUMMARY: A high-level delegation traveled to the South American country last weekend to in part discuss the health of detained U.S. citizens.

TITLE: Sick veterans demand medical coverage for illnesses caused by burn pits
SUMMARY: President Biden is urging Congress to send a burn-pits bill to his desk.

TITLE: Vice President Harris is going to Poland after the U.S. rejected fighter jet offer
SUMMARY: Poland offered to stage fighter jets for Ukraine on a U.S. base in Germany. The Pentagon said that wasn't tenable. It all happened the day before Vice President Harris left for Warsaw.

TITLE: Ukraine's libraries are offering bomb shelters, camouflage classes, and yes, books
SUMMARY: One bundle of homemade camouflage netting was packaged with a note reading, "Death to enemies." The libraries are also sending Ukrainian books out of the country, to refugees who have fled.

TITLE: The war in Ukraine has derailed one American family's adoption plan
SUMMARY: The Bell family has been trying to adopt Vanya and Serogzha from Ukraine for about two years.

TITLE: Ukrainians in the U.S. try to help their country. But getting aid there is difficult
SUMMARY: As Russia bombs Ukraine, many Ukrainians in the U.S. are trying to help their country, but are finding challenges as normal shipping channels are broken with dangerous roads and blocked ports.

TITLE: As U.S. COVID deaths near 1 million, advocates press for a memorial day
SUMMARY: Millions of people in the U.S. have lost someone they love to COVID-19, and advocates hope to have those losses marked each year on the first Monday in March.

TITLE: Why it's hard to know how accurate the 2020 census was
SUMMARY: COVID-19 and interference by former President Donald Trump's administration have made it harder to pinpoint the accuracy of the numbers used to redistribute political representation and federal money.

TITLE: New York City will stop collecting Social Security money from children in foster care
SUMMARY: New York City officials announced the city will no longer take all Social Security checks from children to pay for foster care. Last year NPR and The Marshall Project investigated the common practice.

TITLE: 5 ways to bounce back better from a sports injury
SUMMARY: If you are used to regular exercise and conditioning, the sudden shock of immobility or pain is both frustrating and depressing. Here are some things you can do to make your recovery easier.

TITLE: No floats or beads at this Mardi Gras, but there are chickens
SUMMARY: Faquetaigue Courir de Mardi Gras is all about chickens, mischief and gumbo. Photographer Bryan Tarnowski captured it all.

TITLE: Ukraine says the Chernobyl nuclear site has lost power
SUMMARY: Emergency diesel generators are providing power to critical safety systems at the facility, but they only have enough fuel for 48 hours.

TITLE: Researcher finds 'stunning' rate of COVID among deer. Here's what it means for humans
SUMMARY: Studies on white-tailed deer in Pennsylvania and Ontario offer evidence that the mammals are a reservoir for the virus. What are the implications for the course of SARS-CoV-2?

TITLE: Hundreds gather to honor fallen Ukrainian soldiers
SUMMARY: The first of Ukraine's fallen soldiers are starting to come home. Two men were killed on the front lines in Russia's war on Ukraine. Hundreds gathered to mourn at their funeral on Tuesday.

TITLE: As gas prices surge, here's how to get the most out of your tank
SUMMARY: As U.S. gas prices hit record highs, it's an especially good time to improve your car's fuel economy. Keeping windows closed, avoiding high speeds and getting routine tuneups can all help.

TITLE: A man who got the 1st pig heart transplant has died after 2 months
SUMMARY: David Bennett, 57, died Tuesday at the University of Maryland Medical Center. He was the first person to receive a heart transplant from a pig.

TITLE: Colorado clerk is indicted for election tampering and misconduct
SUMMARY: The indictment of Mesa County Clerk Tina Peters and her deputy on a laundry list of felony and misdemeanor charges is related to an election security breach in her office last year.

TITLE: Sandy Hook ushered in new era of conspiracy and lies, author finds
SUMMARY: Following the 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary school, journalist Elizabeth Williamson says, conspiracy theorists tormented the victims' families by accusing them of being actors.

TITLE: Ernest Shackleton's ship Endurance, lost since 1915, is found off Antarctica
SUMMARY: An expedition went where few have ever gone to locate the remnants of a ship that become trapped in the ice 106 years ago, dashing the famed explorer's ambitious mission to cross Antarctica.

TITLE: Ukraine's libraries are offering bomb shelters, camouflage classes and, yes, books
SUMMARY: One bundle of homemade camouflage netting was packaged with a note reading, "Death to enemies." The libraries are also sending Ukrainian books out of the country to refugees who have fled.

TITLE: Ukrainians in the U.S. support their country. But getting aid there is difficult
SUMMARY: As Russia bombs Ukraine, many Ukrainians in the U.S. are trying to help their country, but are finding challenges as normal shipping channels are broken with dangerous roads and blocked ports.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 9)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: The letter Z is becoming a symbol of Russia's war in Ukraine. But what does it mean?
SUMMARY: It has become a symbol of the Russian invasion, painted on military vehicles, printed on T-shirts and widely distributed through social media in support of Moscow's war.

TITLE: Violence Against Women Act reauthorization is added to a $1.5 trillion spending bill
SUMMARY: A reauthorization of the landmark 1994 law is included in an annual federal spending package moving through Congress.

TITLE: A man was arrested after hiding 52 reptiles under his clothes at the Mexican border
SUMMARY: The 30-year-old U.S. citizen was trying to smuggle 43 horned lizards and nine snakes in small bags into the United States, officials say.

TITLE: Sony halts PlayStation sales in Russia due to Ukraine invasion
SUMMARY: Along with stopping sales of its consoles, the company announced a $2 million donation to UNHCR and the international NGO, Save the Children, to support the victims in Ukraine.

TITLE: Three more Starbucks locations in Buffalo area vote to unionize
SUMMARY: The number of unionized Starbucks stores is now six after three stores in the Buffalo area voted to unionize. The vote counts at each store were close.

TITLE: MLB pushes opening day back to at least April 14 as lockout persists
SUMMARY: MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred announced that another two series of games are being canceled, as players will not be paid for the games they don't play.

TITLE: Unvaccinated Djokovic says he is out of both Indian Wells and Miami
SUMMARY: The No. 2 men's tennis player will not be allowed to enter the United States because he remains unvaccinated from COViD-19.

TITLE: House advances $13.6 billion in Ukraine aid along with government funding
SUMMARY: The House has approved a $1.5 trillion government spending package and a $13.6 billion emergency aid package for Ukraine. The Senate is expected to vote on the funding in the coming days.

TITLE: Ron Miles, cornetist who imbued modern jazz with heart and soul, dies at 58
SUMMARY: The cornetist, composer, and bandleader combined a distinctly American harmonic palette with an openhearted emotional clarity uncommon in modern jazz.

TITLE: The Senate has passed bill to save USPS billions of dollars and reform deliveries
SUMMARY: The Senate on Tuesday approved a $107 billion financial overhaul of the long-beleaguered U.S. Postal Service. It now goes to President Biden.

TITLE: One woman's 18-point survival checklist for fleeing Ukraine as Russia invades
SUMMARY: As millions flee Ukraine, one woman's checklist for surviving the train ride into Poland reveals the desperation and struggle that awaits those who leave.

TITLE: A direct Russian strike devastated a maternity hospital in Mariupol, Zelenskyy says
SUMMARY: "People, children are under the wreckage. Atrocity!" the president tweeted. The port city's deputy mayor also said Russia's military had violated a cease-fire meant to allow civilians to evacuate.

TITLE: Modi's ruling party ahead in crucial state polls in India
SUMMARY: The results are seen as a referendum on the prime minister's popularity and a resounding endorsement of his party's Hindu-first politics.

TITLE: Democratic governor who lifted mask mandate early explains why it was the right move
SUMMARY: Colorado Gov. Jared Polis says that prioritizing vaccine and testing availability over masking helped the state achieve a high rate of immunization and relatively low death rate.

SUMMARY: The meeting in Turkey is the highest-level talks between the two countries since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

SUMMARY: A new national survey raises alarms from election administrators facing constant threats. Stress and attacks by political leaders on the voting system are top forces pushing them out of their jobs.

SUMMARY: After two years of pandemic life, people have learned to cope in ways that have become stubborn, unhealthy habits. But there are positive steps we can take to reset a healthy lifestyle.

TITLE: Garland says the Jan. 6 investigation won't end until everyone is held to account
SUMMARY: In an exclusive interview with NPR, the attorney general says he won't avoid cases related to the Capitol riot probe that are political, controversial or sensitive.

SUMMARY: The Hotel Ilan in Poland has a renowned and troubled history for the country's Jewish community. Now, it has found a new purpose helping Ukrainians fleeing the war Russia has wrought on their country.

SUMMARY: The politically inexperienced president-elect's pledge to get tough on North Korea could mark a sharp break with the outgoing liberal administration's policies.

SUMMARY: The meeting in Turkey is the highest-level talks between the two countries since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

SUMMARY: The results are seen as a referendum on the prime minister's popularity and a resounding endorsement of his party's Hindu-first politics.

SUMMARY: Iraq's capital city is already seeing record heat — up to 125 degrees Fahrenheit. A report predicts more 120-plus degree days to come. And the "urban heat island" effect will make things even worse.

SUMMARY: The No. 2 men's tennis player will not be allowed to enter the United States because he remains unvaccinated against COVID-19.

SUMMARY: The former <em>Empire

SUMMARY: The monthlong extension comes as the CDC said it would work on a "revised policy framework for when, and under what circumstances, masks should be required in the public transportation corridor."

SUMMARY: Colleges are pulling students from study abroad programs in Russia, ending research partnerships and cutting investments as part of a global wave of condemnation over the invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: The new collective bargaining agreement must be approved by both sides before it becomes official. Baseball would return on April 7 if it's accepted.

SUMMARY: The entertainment exodus from Russia is continuing. Both Sony Music and the Warner Music Group announced Thursday that they would be suspending operations in Russia.

SUMMARY: An 11-year-old named Hassan traveled alone into Slovakia, with a plastic bag, a passport and a phone number for relatives. His mother had sent him to safety, unable to leave herself.

SUMMARY: During a summit in France, European Union leaders issued a statement backing Ukraine's bid for membership but stopped short of an immediate welcome. The application process typically takes years.

SUMMARY: Mayor Ivan Fedorov was abducted on Friday, according to Ukrainian officials. He was reportedly seized by approximately 10 people while in the city center, and they put a plastic bag over his head.

SUMMARY: The arbitration demand provides the fullest accounting yet of the accidental shooting of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins from Baldwin's perspective.

SUMMARY: The Justice Department is directing prosecutors to stop limiting peoples' rights to seek compassionate release from prison in plea deals, a practice that advocates called cruel.

SUMMARY: An 11-year-old named Hassan traveled alone into Slovakia with a plastic bag, a passport and a phone number for relatives. His mother had sent him to safety, unable to leave herself.

SUMMARY: Russia's top prosecutor called for Facebook and Instagram's parent company to be labeled an extremist group after Meta said it would permit some calls for violence against "Russian invaders."

TITLE: Judge says Virginia school is 'racial balancing' at the expense of Asian Americans
SUMMARY: The case has been closely watched as courts continue to evaluate the role that racial considerations can play when deciding who should be admitted to a particular school.

TITLE: Russia's wars in Chechnya offer a grim warning of what could be in Ukraine
SUMMARY: Russia unleashes a heavy bombing campaign. Cities are reduced to rubble. Thousands of civilians are killed. Russia did that twice in Chechnya in the 1990s. Is a repeat likely in Ukraine today?

SUMMARY: Hundreds of thousands of pets are estimated to have crossed into countries neighboring Ukraine since the war began.

SUMMARY: The National Weather Service said 7 to 12 inches could be expected in northern areas of Pennsylvania and New York with winds gusting as high as 45 mph.

TITLE: Saudi Arabia carries out its largest known execution in the kingdom's modern history
SUMMARY: The number of those executed on Saturday — 81 — surpassed even the toll of a January 1980 mass execution for the 63 militants convicted of seizing the Grand Mosque in Mecca in 1979.

TITLE: People in the Northeast could see a foot of snow thanks to a March storm
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service said 7 to 12 inches could be expected in northern areas of Pennsylvania and New York with winds gusting as high as 45 mph.

SUMMARY: Wilton Manors police have arrested one person related to an incident earlier this week involving six males overdosing on fentanyl. Cadets from the West Point military academy were involved.

TITLE: How a handful of metals could determine the future of the electric car industry

TITLE: Sanctions may ground Russia's planes, but the firms that own them can't get them back
SUMMARY: Russian airlines can no longer get spare parts or technical support for their Airbus and Boeing planes.

SUMMARY: Not everyone feels safe shedding COVID precautions. But it can be awkward being the only masked person in a room. Here's how to cope with the uncertainty of risk right now — and the peer pressure.

TITLE: There should be an Oscar for playing a real person
SUMMARY: Playing someone real is a completely different task than playing a fictional character.

TITLE: Black business ownership is higher than pre-pandemic. Women are driving that growth
SUMMARY: The number of Black-owned businesses is currently more than 30% above pre-pandemic levels. A Brooklyn street nicknamed "Black Girl Magic Row," exemplifies women helping one another succeed.
