TITLE: COMIC: How a computer scientist fights bias in algorithms
SUMMARY: Computer scientist Joy Buolamwini is on a mission to fight bias in algorithms. In this comic, Buolamwini discusses the way biased algorithms can lead to real world inequality — and what we can do.

TITLE: Better air in classrooms matters beyond COVID. Here's why schools aren't there yet
SUMMARY: Boosting ventilation and filtration not only lowers the risk of transmission, it's also linked to higher test scores and better health. But making upgrades is more complex than it sounds.

TITLE: Why your student loan payments may be delayed (again)
SUMMARY: Payments on federal student loans have been paused for two years, and the Biden administration appears to be considering extending the pause beyond May.

TITLE: Rebuild or leave? In a flood-prone Tennessee town, one family must decide
SUMMARY: Weather disasters displaced thousands of Americans in 2021. In one Tennessee town, a family decides whether to rebuild or leave for good after a deadly flood sparked by a catastrophic rainfall.

TITLE: New York, D.C. police open joint investigation into recent shootings of homeless men
SUMMARY: Five men who are thought to be homeless were shot in separate incidences. Two of the men died.

TITLE: China battles multiple COVID-19 outbreaks, driven by stealth omicron
SUMMARY: While the numbers are small relative to numbers reported in Europe or in the U.S., they are the highest since the first big outbreak of COVID-19 in the central city of Wuhan in early 2020.

TITLE: Pie-eating contests offer a sweet way for communities to reconnect after lockdowns
SUMMARY: Photographer Maggie Shannon spent two weeks on the road with her husband  in the summer of 2021, capturing the joy pie brings in pie-eating contests at county fairs across the country.

TITLE: Stroke rates are increasing among young people. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: Hailey Bieber's blood clot in the brain shows that young people can experience stroke-like symptoms, too. And among young people, stroke rates are on the rise.

TITLE: 7 Ukrainian refugees are taken in by a Russian immigrant in Germany
SUMMARY: Three women and four kids who fled Russia's war on Ukraine have a new temporary home in Germany after the man offered them space in his small apartment — and also took down his Russian flag.

TITLE: Australia and the Netherlands launch a new case against Russia over 2014 jet downing
SUMMARY: The case centers on Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17. The passenger jet crashed over Ukraine on its way from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur in July 2014, killing all 298 people on board.

TITLE: Squatters took over a London mansion linked to a Russian oligarch
SUMMARY: Riot police arrived after protesters entered the building and unfurled banners on the balcony, including one reading "This property has been liberated." It's linked to billionaire Oleg Deripaska.

TITLE: High gas prices present another hurdle in bringing workers back to the office
SUMMARY: Gas prices have soared just as workers who have been remote for two years return to their commutes. Some are asking for companies to wait until prices come down to bring people back.

TITLE: Sen. Joe Manchin says he'll oppose Sarah Bloom Raskin's nomination to a key Fed role
SUMMARY: The opposition of Manchin, the Democratic senator from West Virginia, likely dooms Bloom Raskin's chances to be confirmed

TITLE: Schools across Europe give shelter and fresh opportunities to Ukraine's young dancers
SUMMARY: Young Ukrainian dancers are finding safe haven at ballet schools in Europe and the U.S. Many of them planned to compete in the Youth America Grand Prix competition in Kiev which was cancelled.

TITLE: Julian Assange is dealt a legal blow as he fights extradition to the U.S.
SUMMARY: Britain's top court on Monday refused WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange permission to appeal against a decision to extradite him to the U.S. to face spying charges.

TITLE: The pregnant woman from the iconic Mariupol photo has died. Many more are at risk
SUMMARY: The woman and her baby died after Wednesday's strike, one of dozens of recent attacks on Ukraine's health system. U.N. groups warn it is running "dangerously low" on oxygen and medical supplies.

TITLE: Fox News reporter Benjamin Hall is injured while reporting from Ukraine
SUMMARY: Hall was wounded while reporting outside Kyiv and is hospitalized, Fox News Media CEO Suzanne Scott said in a statement.

TITLE: A moment with Ronaldo made Brady fans think he was coming out of retirement
SUMMARY: A quick exchange with Manchester United star Cristiano Ronaldo was enough to fuel speculation that Tom Brady might not really be retiring from the NFL.

TITLE: White House tells China of its 'deep concerns' about providing assistance to Russia
SUMMARY: U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan met with Chinese diplomats in Rome in what a senior administration adviser described as an "intense" seven-hour session.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 14)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Dolly Parton removes herself from the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame nominations
SUMMARY: The artist said that her nomination could inspire her to put out "a hopefully great rock 'n' roll album at some point in the future."

TITLE: Telegram is the app of choice in the war in Ukraine despite experts' privacy concerns
SUMMARY: The messaging app Telegram has been heavily used by both sides in the war in Ukraine. But privacy experts say people using the service should be wary of the app's level of security.

TITLE: The goal: Vaccinate 70% of the world against COVID. Scientists are proposing a reboot
SUMMARY: As the world enters the pandemic's 3rd year, some ask whether the 70% vaccination goal set by WHO and the Biden administration could in fact be detrimental. Also: See our map of global progress.

TITLE: Uber and Lyft add fuel surcharges to rides as gas prices surge nationwide
SUMMARY: As of Monday, the average cost of a gallon of regular fuel is now $4.325, according to AAA. Both rideshare companies say they're adding surcharges to deal with the spike in gas prices in the U.S.

TITLE: Jane Campion apologizes for comments made about Venus and Serena Williams
SUMMARY: The "Power of the Dog" director was apologizing for remarks made in her Sunday evening acceptance speech for best director at the Critics' Choice Awards.

TITLE: Filipina domestic workers are being fired in Hong Kong for catching COVID
SUMMARY: As an omicron wave sweeps through Hong Kong, some of the nannies and housekeepers from the Philippines who work there have been thrown out by their employers after testing positive for the virus.

TITLE: Shot 9 times at New Zealand mosque, survivor walks for peace
SUMMARY: Three years after the deadly shootings, a victim of the shootings travels more than 200 miles on foot and by bike to retrace the gunman's journey.

TITLE: India court upholds a ban on hijab in schools and colleges
SUMMARY: Some rights activists have voiced concerns that the ban could increase Islamophobia in a country where violence and hate speech against Muslims have increased in recent years.

TITLE: A surge in COVID-19 spurs new lockdowns in China's cities
SUMMARY: In the latest wave, the highly transmissible omicron variant has moved more quickly than contact tracing allows.

TITLE: Do masks in school affect kids' speech and social skills?
SUMMARY: Scientists say that for most children, masks in school aren't a major obstacle to learning or socializing. Students in classrooms find other ways to connect.

TITLE: Can states limit abortion and gender-affirming treatments outside their borders?
SUMMARY: Building on SB 8 in Texas, some Republican lawmakers are trying a new strategy: pushing bills that would attempt to<strong>

TITLE: Two years ago schools shut down around the world. These are the biggest impacts
SUMMARY: In March 2020, we asked experts in school disruptions what the long-range effects might be as COVID-19 closed schools. How did those predictions pan out?

TITLE: Wife of Justice Thomas rebuts claims of conflict of interest
SUMMARY: In an interview published Monday, Ginny Thomas said that while she did attend the Jan. 6 rally to protest President Biden's election, she left before Donald Trump took the stage.

TITLE: Shares in China fall amid strongest COVID-19 lockdown yet
SUMMARY: A second consecutive day of losses comes while China faces a surging number of COVID-19 cases across the country.

TITLE: A Russian editor protested the war on live TV and was immediately arrested
SUMMARY: The woman burst onto the set of the evening news and told viewers they were being lied to. State-run Tass says she's under "a pre-investigation check," but others say her location is unknown.

TITLE: For the first time in its history, architecture's top award goes to a Black architect
SUMMARY: The 2022 Pritzker Architecture Prize honors Diébédo Francis Kéré, who comes from a village with no school in Burkina Faso. He has designed primary schools for "many children to be happy and learn."

TITLE: Ukraine scrambles to protect artifacts and monuments from Russian attack
SUMMARY: On top of the humanitarian crisis, Ukrainians worry about Russian destruction of cultural heritage sites. In Lviv, they're wrapping statues in fireproof material to protect them from Russian bombs.

TITLE: Former Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch warns Putin will move west if he wins in Ukraine
SUMMARY: Yovanovich served as the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, but was relieved of her post following a smear campaign orchestrated by Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani. Her new memoir is <em>Lessons from the Edge.

TITLE: How to help refugees when you've become one yourself
SUMMARY: The Ukrainian refugee aid organization Right to Protection is continuing to help displaced people as much as possible, even as its own staff members are forced to relocate to safer areas.

TITLE: 2 members of the Fox News team in Ukraine were killed in an attack
SUMMARY: A veteran video journalist for Fox News, Pierre Zakrzewski, was killed outside Kyiv, Fox News said. Another member of the team, Oleksandra Kuvshinova, also died in the attack, a Fox producer said.

TITLE: New U.K. sanctions target Russian vodka, luxury vehicles, fashion and artwork
SUMMARY: The U.K. announced new economic sanctions against Russia and sanctioned more oligarchs and politicians. Government officials say they've designated more than 1,000 entities since the invasion began.

TITLE: A life in limbo for the wives and children of ISIS fighters
SUMMARY: Most of the residents of the Hassan Sham camp in northern Iraq feel like outcasts, with nowhere else to go. And conditions are getting worse as funding for food, education and health care dries up.

TITLE: A Russian who protested the war on live TV refused to retract her statement in court
SUMMARY: The woman burst onto the set of the evening news and told viewers they were being lied to about the war in Ukraine. She was fined for a video in which she called for Russians to protest the war.

TITLE: Pfizer-BioNTech will seek authorization for second COVID booster for older adults
SUMMARY: Pfizer and BioNTech are planning to ask the Food and Drug Administration to authorize a second COVID-19 booster shot for people age 65 and older.

TITLE: What Ukraine war news looks like from Russia
SUMMARY: State TV has long been Russians' top news source. Now it's becoming the only word of record, presenting stories of "surgical" attacks on Ukrainian nationalists and threats of anti-Russian bioweapons.

TITLE: Fed nominee Sarah Bloom Raskin withdraws after fight over her climate change stance
SUMMARY: Biden's pick to be the Fed's top bank regulator has withdrawn her nomination. She attracted Republican opposition after calling on bank regulators to monitor the financial risks from climate change.

TITLE: The Senate approves a bill to make daylight saving time permanent
SUMMARY: For those wishing for an end to annual clock shifting, this push in Congress is perhaps better late than never. It would still require House approval and President Biden's signature to become law.

TITLE: Without sending troops, the U.S. wages 'hybrid warfare' against Russia
SUMMARY: The U.S. and Russia have talked for years about 'hybrid war' – waging a conflict on multiple fronts beyond the battlefield. In unprecedented ways, the U.S. is now employing this against Russia.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 15)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: 2 Fox News team members in Ukraine were killed in an attack
SUMMARY: A veteran video journalist for Fox News, Pierre Zakrzewski, and freelance journalist Oleksandra Kuvshynova died when their vehicle was hit by incoming fire, the network confirmed.

TITLE: A new Selena album will be released in April, 27 years after her death
SUMMARY: The songs are part of the catalog belonging to the family's record label. Producers were able to digitally update Selena's voice in her teen songs to sound exactly as she did before her death in 1995.

TITLE: Second gentleman Doug Emhoff tests positive for COVID-19
SUMMARY: The White House hasn't indicated if the husband of Vice President Harris, Douglas Emhoff, is experiencing symptoms. Harris has tested negative but is not participating in a White House event tonight.

TITLE: Man arrested for the violent hate-crime beating of an Asian woman in N.Y., police say
SUMMARY: In a surveillance video released by police, the suspect is shown punching the victim in the face and head more than 125 times. He is being charged with attempted murder.

TITLE: Russia says it's sanctioning Biden, Hillary Clinton and top U.S. officials
SUMMARY: Russia's foreign ministry said Russia would sanction President Biden and members of his administration, banning them from entering Russia. It says the move is retaliation for U.S. sanctions.

TITLE: Russia steps up assaults as Ukraine appeals for more help
SUMMARY: The fighting across the country continues as Ukraine's president prepares to speak to the U.S. Congress.

TITLE: On Equal Pay Day, women are trying to make a dollar out of 83 cents
SUMMARY: It took women working year round full-time jobs 74 extra days to earn what men did in 2021. And the data is worse for women of color, who are disproportionately employed in low-wage jobs.

TITLE: New Zealand will open its borders to some tourists much earlier than expected
SUMMARY: The move is meant to speed up the recovery of the island nation's pandemic-battered economy, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said Wednesday.

TITLE: U.N. says military violence in Myanmar may be 'crimes against humanity'
SUMMARY: More than 12,500 people in Myanmar have been detained, at least 440,000 have been displaced and about 14 million people are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance, the report says.

TITLE: Blinken sets a standard for lifting sanctions: an 'irreversible' Russian withdrawal
SUMMARY: In an interview with NPR, Secretary of State Antony Blinken, the top U.S. diplomat, warns of the further devastation of Ukrainian cities.

TITLE: The number of Ukrainians who've fled to Poland is equal to the population of Warsaw
SUMMARY: The flood of arrivals is visible in Warsaw, where the central train station has been transformed, with information booths and volunteer translators. About 1.8 million have arrived in Poland.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve is about to raise interest rates as inflation continues to surge
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates today for the first time since 2018, in an effort to tamp down inflation. Additional rate hikes are likely in the months to come.

TITLE: Texas and other states want to 'boycott' fossil fuel divestment
SUMMARY: A Texas model law was written by the head of a group that opposes climate action and takes money from fossil fuel interests. It could shift billions away from major investment firms.

TITLE: A college student in occupied Ukraine says buying food means it's a lucky day
SUMMARY: What's daily life like in one of the recently-occupied parts of Ukraine? One college student in the southern city of Kherson steps through his new reality.

TITLE: Fears are growing that Russia will default on its debt. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: Russia owes interest payments on two dollar-denominated bonds on Wednesday. If it doesn't pay, the country could go into default.

TITLE: Facebook will block kids from downloading age-inappropriate virtual reality apps
SUMMARY: Sister app Instagram is also launching new parental controls, as the social media company faces pressure to address safety risks to kids in virtual reality.

TITLE: Multiple people died in a crash involving college golf teams in Texas
SUMMARY: A vehicle carrying students from the University of the Southwest collided head-on with a pickup truck in West Texas, authorities said.

TITLE: Watch: President Zelenskyy delivers a virtual address to Congress
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy delivers a virtual address to the U.S. Congress on Wednesday at 9 a.m. EDT. His remarks come as the Russian invasion of Ukraine enters its third week.

TITLE: Lviv takes in displaced Ukrainians but space and resources are strained
SUMMARY: Space and resources are strained in the western city of Lviv. More than 200,000 Ukrainians have temporarily settled in the city while Russian airstrikes continued this past week.

TITLE: In a virtual address, President Zelenskyy call on the U.S. to 'do more'
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy delivered a virtual address to the U.S. Congress on Wednesday at 9 a.m. EDT. His remarks come as the Russian invasion of Ukraine enters its third week.

TITLE: North Korean missile test ends in failure, as South and U.S. watch for ICBM test
SUMMARY: North Korea is reportedly working up to testing of a longer-range intercontinental ballistic missile that could reach the whole of the continental U.S.

TITLE: Starbucks CEO is stepping down. Howard Schultz returning as interim boss
SUMMARY: On the day of its annual shareholder meeting, Starbucks announced its CEO Kevin Johnson is retiring, effective April 4. Howard Schultz, who led the company for two decades, will return as interim CEO.

TITLE: 9 people died in a Texas crash involving college golf teams from New Mexico
SUMMARY: Those killed in the head-on crash in West Texas included six students and a coach from the University of the Southwest who were returning home from a golf tournament, authorities said.

TITLE: President Zelenskyy makes an impassioned call for the U.S. to 'do more'
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy delivered an address via video link to the U.S. Congress, remarks that come as the Russian invasion enters its third week.

TITLE: In Texas, thousands of mail ballots were rejected following new ID requirements
SUMMARY: Perhaps most notably, Harris County rejected a whopping 19% percent of the mail ballots it received, or 6,888 ballots in total. Four years ago the county's rejection rate was about 0.3%.

TITLE: The Coast Guard is working to free a container ship stuck in the Chesapeake Bay
SUMMARY: The vessel left Baltimore on Sunday carrying general cargo and grounded while it was on its way to Norfolk, Va.

TITLE: Starbucks plans to phase out paper cups in the U.S. and Canada
SUMMARY: As part of the company's goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030, customers will be able to bring a reusable cup to get their drinks by the end of next year.

TITLE: This burning train is a symbol of the anger of India's out-of-work youth
SUMMARY: The country is in the midst of a job crisis. The rate of unemployment is about 13% among educated youth. Those who work in the informal sector vie for jobs with no security. Why are things so bad?

TITLE: Rep. Gregory Meeks reacts to Zelenskyy's address to Congress
SUMMARY: Meeks (D-NY), the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, recently visited Ukraine's border with Poland.

TITLE: Zelenskyy calls on U.S. to 'do more' in virtual address to Congress
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy delivered an impassioned plea for additional aid and for President Biden to spearhead the world's defense of Ukraine.

TITLE: 'King Richard,' the Oscar-nominated film, authentically depicts the Williams' history
SUMMARY: King Richard is nominated for six Oscars, including Best Picture. Will Smith, Isha Price, and Aunjanue Ellis explain how faith motivated the Williams' family.

TITLE: A doctor reveals the hidden wonders of the human body
SUMMARY: In his new book, <em>The Unseen Body,

TITLE: A 7.3 magnitude earthquake hits northern Japan
SUMMARY: The powerful quake struck off the coast of Fukushima on Wednesday evening, triggering a tsunami advisory and cutting power to more than 2 million Tokyo homes. No casualties have been reported so far.

TITLE: Biden pledges $800 million to Ukraine after Zelenskyy's plea for more U.S. aid
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy delivered an impassioned plea for additional help and for President Biden to spearhead the world's defense of Ukraine. Later, Biden pledged to send more security support.

TITLE: The James Webb Space Telescope is working as well as astronomers dreamed it would
SUMMARY: Picture perfect: Mission managers say the telescope's mirror segments have been aligned and have focused on single stars, a critical milestone, and the telescope is working flawlessly.

TITLE: Iran releases 2 British Iranian citizens from prison
SUMMARY: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a charity worker, and Anousheh Ashouri, a businessman, have now left the country. A third prisoner was released on furlough. Other foreigners remain imprisoned in Iran.

TITLE: Novak Djokovic and Russian athletes are likely to compete at the French Open
SUMMARY: Organizers at Roland-Garros said Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic should be allowed to compete at the French Open thanks to loosened COVID rules in France.

TITLE: March Madness is an NCAA gold mine. This year, players can finally cash in too
SUMMARY: For the first time in NCAA tournament history, players can strike deals to profit off their names, images and likenesses. Brands have already spent millions, and some say it's just the start.

TITLE: VIDEO: A look at efforts targeting LGBTQ youth around the country
SUMMARY: Many of these laws will be challenged, but it's not just about the threat of legal action. Studies have shown that LGBTQ youth already face higher health and suicide risks.

TITLE: Dyeing the Chicago River green is a St. Patrick's Day tradition. How did it start?
SUMMARY: For 60 years, Chicago has turned its downtown river green to celebrate St. Patrick's Day. The annual tradition actually has its roots in a big problem for the city: sewage.

TITLE: Biden calls Putin a war criminal
SUMMARY: President Biden on Tuesday was asked by reporters whether he was ready to call Russian President Putin a war criminal. "I think he is a war criminal," he said.

TITLE: Russia's strike on Ukraine maternity hospital is part of a terrible wartime tradition
SUMMARY: The attack on the facility in Mariupol reflects an unfortunate trend in wars in Syria, Ethiopia and other countries. The impact on health care in the short-term and the long run is beyond devastating.

TITLE: New Ralph Lauren collection explores collegiate style on historically Black campuses
SUMMARY: A young Black designer got Ralph Lauren to dedicate a new limited collection to the swanky collegiate style of HBCUs.

TITLE: Gonzaga is coming in hot to March Madness. But what's behind the name?
SUMMARY: The first round of the NCAA tournament kicked off this week, and Gonzaga University's Bulldogs sit at the top of the rankings. Here's what's behind the school's name.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 16)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: The 'Orbeez Challenge' is causing harm in some communities, police warn
SUMMARY: Police in at least two cities are warning their communities that a new TikTok challenge is taking off and potentially causing harm in the process.

TITLE: Amir Locke would still be alive if not for no-knock warrants, Rev. Al Sharpton says
SUMMARY: Locke's death has prompted an outcry against no-knock warrants, with a push by his family and others to ban them in Minnesota and beyond.

TITLE: San Francisco DA drops charges against woman linked to crime through rape victim DNA
SUMMARY: The district attorney's office said the case violated the woman's Fourth Amendment rights and called the police department's use of the alleged victim's DNA, "illegal."

TITLE: A burning cargo ship full of Porsches and VWs is adrift in the mid-Atlantic
SUMMARY: The Portuguese navy rescued the 22-member crew from the Felicity Ace, which was scheduled to arrive in the port of Davisville, R.I., next week. None of the crew was injured.

TITLE: Amazon labor push escalates as workers at New York warehouse win a union vote
SUMMARY: Amazon will face two union elections at once. Federal officials have set a union vote for Amazon workers at a Staten Island warehouse, coinciding with the ongoing re-do election in Bessemer, Ala.

TITLE: Former L.A. Angels employee found guilty of providing drugs that killed Tyler Skaggs
SUMMARY: The Major League pitcher died in 2019 after being found unresponsive in a hotel room while the team was in Texas to play a series against the Rangers.

TITLE: The Senate avoids a government shutdown, punting a spending deadline into March
SUMMARY: Lawmakers hope to finalize a longer-term spending bill before the new shutdown deadline on March 11.

TITLE: The 'Candy Bomber' who dropped sweets during the Berlin airlift has died at age 101
SUMMARY: "Halvorsen's deeply human act has never been forgotten," Berlin Mayor Franziska Giffey said in a statement.

TITLE: As COVID restrictions ease, the full Congress is invited to attend State of the Union
SUMMARY: For President Biden's 2021 address to Congress, attendance was capped at about 20%. This year's shift reflects the federal government's push to get closer to some form of normalcy.

TITLE: Will Activision Blizzard workers unionize? Microsoft's deal complicates things
SUMMARY: The video game industry has long been resistant to organizing. But quality assurance testers at video game giant Activision Blizzard hope to change that.

TITLE: Here's how to decide if you're safe to go out when you're recovering from omicron
SUMMARY: The CDC says you can end isolation after five days. But emerging research shows with omicron, many people could be infectious for several days past that. So how do you determine if you're good to go?

TITLE: Remembering 'Small,' the funeral singer who made joyful music in the face of death
SUMMARY: The Ghanaian singer would vocalize and dance all night long to send off the departed. On the verge of his long awaited first trip to perform abroad, he has died, reportedly of COVID.

TITLE: N.Y. Supreme Court justice orders the Trumps to testify under oath
SUMMARY: Trump calls the ruling "a continuation of the greatest Witch Hunt in history."

TITLE: Why we'll probably see avocado prices rise soon in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Earlier this week, the U.S. Department of Agriculture put a temporary suspension on avocados from Mexico after an inspector received a threat. Experts say it might lead to a change in supply and cost.

TITLE: The future of U.S. democracy hangs in the balance as states battle over voting rights
SUMMARY: Michael Waldman, president of the Brennan Center for Justice, says lawmakers in 27 states are considering hundreds of bills designed to limit voting or undermine the integrity of the election process.

TITLE: Iraq has enough doses of COVID vaccine for everyone. But many Iraqis don't trust it
SUMMARY: The vaccination rate is only 17%. People are scared and skeptical for many reasons. Now government health workers are trying to up the numbers. One strategy: vaccination booths in the mall.

TITLE: Thousands of Russians have fled, afraid a new Iron Curtain will fall
SUMMARY: <em>New Yorker

TITLE: For the first time, victims of the opioid crisis formally confront the Sackler family
SUMMARY: The Sacklers, who own Purdue Pharma, maker of Oxycontin, have maintained they did nothing wrong. People who lost loved ones and years of their lives to opioid addiction believe otherwise.

TITLE: Jussie Smollett returns to court for sentencing for lying about an attack on him
SUMMARY: The former <em>Empire

TITLE: TSA extends the travel mask mandate through April 18
SUMMARY: The monthlong extension comes as the CDC said it would work on a "revised policy framework for when, and under what circumstances, masks should be required in the public transportation corridor."

TITLE: Florida lawmakers back the creation of an election crimes investigative office
SUMMARY: Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis, who's expected to sign the legislation, had called for the formation of an election police force in a speech last year.

TITLE: The 2020 census had big undercounts of Black people, Latinos and Native Americans
SUMMARY: The Census Bureau has released its first report on the accuracy of the latest national head count that's used to distribute political representation and federal funding for the next decade.

TITLE: Goldman Sachs is the 1st major Wall Street bank to pull out of Russia
SUMMARY: The investment bank says it's "winding down its business in Russia in compliance with regulatory and licensing requirements," two weeks after the country first invaded Ukraine.

TITLE: Inflation hits another 40-year high. The war in Ukraine could make it worse
SUMMARY: Annual inflation climbed to a new four-decade high in February, with consumer prices up 7.9% from a year ago. The increase does not reflect most of the recent jump in gasoline prices.

TITLE: The U.K. sanctions Roman Abramovich, halting his plan to sell Chelsea Football Club
SUMMARY: The Russian billionaire faces an asset freeze and travel ban, just a week after he announced plans to sell the club. The U.K. government aims to shield players and fans from the sanctions' impact.

TITLE: Why Baghdad will be one of the cities hardest hit by global warming
SUMMARY: Iraq's capital city is already seeing record heat — up to 125 degrees Fahrenheit. A report predicts more 120-plus degree days to come. And the "urban heat island" effect will make things even worse.

TITLE: South Koreans vote political conservative as new president
SUMMARY: The politically inexperienced Yoon Suk Yeol's pledge to get tough on North Korea could mark a sharp break with the outgoing liberal administration's policies.

TITLE: Democratic governor who lifted mask mandate early explains why it was the right move
SUMMARY: Colorado Gov. Jared Polis says that prioritizing vaccine and testing availability over masking helped the state achieve a high rate of immunization and relatively low death rate.

TITLE: High-level talks between Russia and Ukraine end with no breakthrough
SUMMARY: The meeting in Turkey is the highest-level talks between the two countries since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

TITLE: Nurses are waiting months for licenses as hospital staffing shortages spread
SUMMARY: Almost 1 in 10 nurses who were issued new licenses last year waited six months or more, an NPR analysis found. Nurses say patient care suffers as these delays make staffing shortages even worse.

TITLE: 1 in 5 local election officials say they're likely to quit before 2024
SUMMARY: A new national survey raises alarms from election administrators facing constant threats. Stress and attacks by political leaders on the voting system are top forces pushing them out of their jobs.

TITLE: Deepfake video of Zelenskyy could be 'tip of the iceberg' in info war, experts warn
SUMMARY: A fake video of the Ukrainian president claiming defeat spread on social media on Wednesday.

TITLE: Court orders Jussie Smollett released from jail during appeal
SUMMARY: Jussie Smollett was ordered released from jail Wednesday by an appeals court.

SUMMARY: The Department of Justice said the settlement "does not amount to an admission of fault by the United States" in its statement.

SUMMARY: Millions of years ago and thousands of feet below the ocean's murky surface lived the oldest relative of the octopus and vampire squid.

SUMMARY: Even if you don't have long COVID, it can still take weeks to recover — much longer than the isolation period implies. Millions of Americans are finding that this still majorly disrupts their lives.

SUMMARY: A glimmer of good news has emerged in Mariupol, where people are being pulled out of a theater that was being used as a shelter.

SUMMARY: The package by the White House includes missiles to take out tanks and bring down Russian aircraft — as well as drones that the U.S. hasn't provided previously.

TITLE: Russian court finds jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny guilty in fraud case
SUMMARY: Navalny, who is already serving a 2.5-year sentence for parole violations, was sentenced to an additional nine years in a high-security prison. He has vowed to keep fighting.

TITLE: Roll over sourdough. Italian scientists develop a new way rise pizza crust
SUMMARY: Bread geeks, take note! The new technique, developed in a lab in Naples, involves the smart application of materials science and physics to make airy, bubbly dough without fermentation.

SUMMARY: The long-time drummer for the mega-platinum band has died. In an online post late Friday, the band led by Dave Grohl did not release a cause, but called Hawkins' passing a "tragic and untimely loss."

TITLE: CDC drops its COVID-19 risk advisory for cruise ship travel
SUMMARY: While the agency has lifted its travel health notice two years after putting it in place, officials say it's up to travelers to determine their own health risks before going aboard a ship.

TITLE: GameStop's stock is on fire once again and here's why
SUMMARY: A year after the "meme stock" phenomenon, GameStop continues to perform far above investment experts' predictions.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 30)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Arizona Republicans enact a controversial new proof-of-citizenship voting law
SUMMARY: Critics warn that the measure will jeopardize the voter registrations of thousands of the state's residents.

TITLE: Ivermectin does not prevent COVID-19 hospitalization, a new study says
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration has long warned against using the cow and horse dewormer to fight COVID-19, warning it can cause serious, adverse effects.

TITLE: Chris Rock says he's still processing the slap in his first appearance since Oscars
SUMMARY: Chris Rock performed in Boston just days after getting slapped by Will Smith on the Oscars stage.

TITLE: Britain withdraws its judges from Hong Kong's top court
SUMMARY: The two British judges resigned after citing concerns about the court being as endorsing "an administration that has departed from values of political freedom, and freedom of expression."

TITLE: Handshakes and hugs as U.S., in loss, returns to the World Cup
SUMMARY: The U.S. will learn on Friday which three nations it will face in the group stage of the World Cup, which starts Nov. 21.

TITLE: China holds espionage trial of Chinese Australian journalist
SUMMARY: China has not provided any specifics about what offenses Cheng Lei is accused of committing, who has been held for 19 months on suspicion of relaying state secrets abroad.

TITLE: How tensions between the police and media boiled over one chaotic night in LA
SUMMARY: The LAPD detained at least 16 journalists covering a protest in March 2021, a low point in a year of increasing mistrust and hostilities between police departments and the media.

TITLE: This toy maker wanted to help Ukrainian refugees. The response stunned him
SUMMARY: A custom LEGO store in a Chicago suburb has raised more than $145,000 for Ukraine relief by selling figurines of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Molotov cocktails.

TITLE: Europe has designs on making the 'fast fashion' industry more sustainable
SUMMARY: Under the proposal, the European Commission would set new durability standards and require companies to include how sustainable and recyclable a clothing item is on its label.

TITLE: Understanding aphasia, the condition impacting Bruce Willis' acting career
SUMMARY: While details of Willis' diagnosis are unknown, medical experts stress the importance of the brain condition and how its specifically treated — depending on its severity.

TITLE: A nurse's death raises the alarm about the profession's mental health crisis
SUMMARY: After nearly two years of grueling shifts treating COVID patients, a group of nurses lost one of their closest friends to suicide. They're determined not to let others fall through the cracks.

TITLE: Private funding saved the 2020 election. Now, some GOP-led states are banning it
SUMMARY: One study found that the U.S. government spends as much maintaining parking facilities across the country as it does running elections.

TITLE: From kid gloves to rubber bullets: How the LAPD's ties to news media unraveled
SUMMARY: Decades of tensions between police and journalists in Los Angeles led to a night of chaos last year in which officers detained at least 16 journalists covering a protest at the city's Echo Park.

TITLE: Russia's war in Ukraine reminds Georgians of what they survived in 2008
SUMMARY: In Georgia, people living on the frontlines of Russia's 2008 invasion say they worry about what Putin's war in Ukraine will mean for them.

TITLE: Biden is considering tapping oil reserves to control gas prices
SUMMARY: The consideration to tap the strategic reserve comes as prices have spiked since the U.S. and allies have imposed steep sanctions on Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: World is seeing the greatest number of conflicts since the end of WWII, U.N. says
SUMMARY: Guterres said the world is grappling with the most conflict since 1945, and proposed a New Agenda for Peace to bring stability to places such as Yemen, Myanmar, Syria, Sudan and Ukraine.

TITLE: Will skiing survive? Resorts struggle through a winter of climate and housing woes
SUMMARY: In the West, ski resorts are banking on a Spring Break surge after a rough winter of prolonged drought, labor and housing shortages and frustrated customers.

TITLE: Fentanyl's lethal toll continues. Police seized nearly 10 million pills last year
SUMMARY: A study by the National Institutes of Health said pills are the most common form of the drug, with a nearly 50-fold increase in law enforcement seizures.

TITLE: The U.S. men's soccer team qualifies for the World Cup despite its loss to Costa Rica
SUMMARY: The U.S. will learn on Friday which three nations it will face in the group stage of the World Cup, which starts Nov. 21. The men's team returns after a 2018 loss that broke its qualifying streak.

TITLE: Ukrainians navigate a perilous route to safety out of besieged Mariupol
SUMMARY: "It is either die or leave. We had no other way," says one woman who arrived in Zaporizhzhia after three attempts at escape. Officials say nearly 100,000 people are still trapped in the besieged city.

TITLE: A secretive LA group has a new mission: paint untouched crosswalks
SUMMARY: "We've been met with delays, excuses, and inaction from our city government," says the Crosswalk Collective LA. Now, the group has taken matters into its own hands and hopes to spread a DIY message.

TITLE: Biden plans a major withdrawal from the country's oil reserves to control gas prices
SUMMARY: The decision comes as prices have spiked since the U.S. and allies have imposed steep sanctions on Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Biden will release more oil to fight high prices
SUMMARY: Gas prices have been soaring. President Biden is announcing he will release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

TITLE: Women are still missing in the music industry, especially behind the scenes
SUMMARY: According to a new study, fewer than 4% of producers making songs on the Billboard Top 100 last year were women — a number that hasn't changed much over the past decade.

TITLE: Russian troops leaving Kyiv area as Moscow focuses more on eastern Ukraine
SUMMARY: The Russians are pulling some troops away from Ukraine's capital Kyiv. But what exactly does this mean? U.S. and Ukrainian officials suspect Moscow may just be pausing before another big offensive.

TITLE: What to know about the U.S. emergency oil stash as Biden gears up to tap the reserves
SUMMARY: The U.S is planning its largest-ever release from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Here's what to know about the country's emergency oil stash.

TITLE: On Transgender Day of Visibility, White House announces moves to expand trans rights
SUMMARY: The administration's announcement comes as several Republican-led states have passed anti-trans legislation in the last few months, which the White House calls "un-American."

TITLE: These kids' authors are telling the stories of trans youth. Book bans won't stop them
SUMMARY: As lawmakers push forward with efforts to curb the rights of queer and trans youth, authors who've written about gender expansive and trans identities say storytelling is crucial.

TITLE: Americans have more confidence in Zelenskyy than Biden when it comes to world affairs
SUMMARY: Some 72% of Americans have confidence in the Ukrainian president's handling of world affairs, a Pew Research Center survey finds. Meanwhile, just 48% say the same about U.S. President Biden.

TITLE: A toymaker raised $145,000 for Ukraine by creating a Lego-based Zelenskyy figurine
SUMMARY: A custom LEGO store in a Chicago suburb has raised more than $145,000 for Ukraine relief by selling figurines of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Molotov cocktails.

TITLE: Citing race, a federal judge strikes down parts of a 2021 Florida election law
SUMMARY: The judge says the state's Republican-led government was using subtle tactics to suppress Black voters. An appeal of the ruling is expected.

TITLE: A container ship named Ever Forward has been stuck in the Chesapeake Bay for 18 days
SUMMARY: The ship ran aground after it apparently missed a turn leaving Baltimore. The vessel is owned by the same company that owns the Ever Given, the ship that blocked the Suez Canal last year.

TITLE: Ukraine is inventing a new way to fight on the digital battlefield
SUMMARY: <em>Time

TITLE: Georgia's South Ossetia region might vote on joining Russia
SUMMARY: Leaders of Georgia's breakaway region of South Ossetia say they're planning a referendum to join the Russian Federation.

TITLE: From rom-com lead to action star, Bruce Willis leaves behind an expansive career
SUMMARY: The actor's family announced Wednesday he's stepping away from acting. He was recently diagnosed with aphasia, which affects language and communication.

TITLE: Fentanyl's lethal toll continues. Nearly 10 million pills were seized last year
SUMMARY: A study by the National Institutes of Health said pills are the most common form of the drug with a nearly 50-fold increase in law enforcement seizures.

TITLE: Ukraine mayor says Russian soldiers who kidnapped him knew nothing about his country
SUMMARY: Melitopol Mayor Ivan Fedorov was held by Russian forces for five days. They told him they wanted to free his town from Nazis. "I told them in my 30 years in this town I've never seen a single Nazi."

TITLE: Washington is the first state to create an alert system for missing Indigenous people
SUMMARY: It's a system similar to Amber Alerts and silver alerts, which are used respectively for missing children and vulnerable adults in many states.

TITLE: House passes bill to cap insulin prices
SUMMARY: The chamber voted on a bill that caps the price of insulin at $35 a month but fate for the legislation in the Senate is unclear.

TITLE: Food prices are going up — and at levels Americans haven't seen in decades
SUMMARY: The USDA's latest report found that nearly all major food groups are going up in price.

TITLE: The Patagonia vest endures in San Francisco tech circles, despite ridicule
SUMMARY: Flyers around San Francisco are urging tech workers to give up the quintessential Silicon Valley uniform: the fleece vest. It's just the latest flashpoint in the city's class battle.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (March 31)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Do-over union election at Amazon's Bessemer warehouse is too close to call
SUMMARY: The no votes edged out the yes votes in the do-over election in Bessemer, Alabama, but more than 400 challenged ballots remain. A hearing will determine whether those ballots will be counted.

TITLE: Recall issued for thousands of Skippy Peanut Butter cases due to steel fragments
SUMMARY: The specific jars impacted include Skippy Reduced Fat Creamy Peanut Butter Spread, Skippy Reduced Fat Chunky Peanut Butter Spread and Skippy Creamy Peanut Butter Blended With Plant Protein.

TITLE: COVID-19 infection increases your risk for diabetes, a new study says
SUMMARY: Researchers found that people who had COVID-19 were about 40% more likely to develop diabetes within a year after recovering, compared to participants in a control group.

TITLE: Jared Leto is Marvel's bat-man in the vampiric 'Morbius'
SUMMARY: An ailing biochemist aims to cure himself of a debilitating illness, but ends up infecting himself with vampirism in the Marvel movie <em>Morbius.

TITLE: The LAPD was ready to arrest Will Smith after the slap, Will Packer says
SUMMARY: In an interview with "Good Morning America," Will Packer says the LAPD was ready to take action against Will Smith. But Chris Rock declined to press charges.

TITLE: Jared Kushner provided 'helpful' details to the Jan. 6 committee, a panel member says
SUMMARY: Donald Trump's son-in-law and a former senior White House adviser substantiated information and provided his own take on different reports on the Jan. 6 attack, Democratic Rep. Elaine Luria said.

TITLE: Meteorologist pauses weather report on live TV to call family about a tornado warning
SUMMARY: A meteorologist for NBC Washington paused his live weather report Thursday to call his family about a tornado warning near their home.

TITLE: Amazon staff reject union in Alabama yet lean toward it in NYC
SUMMARY: One labor and employment observer said the New York vote was "shocking," since Amazon workers there had no support from an established union.

TITLE: Labor groups close in on Amazon in 2 tight union elections
SUMMARY: One labor and employment observer said the New York vote was "shocking," since Amazon workers there had no support from an established union.

TITLE: Rocket launchers were found in a trash can near a California middle school
SUMMARY: Grenades and rocket launchers are federally classified as firearms, and are therefore legal with proper registration. But states have the power to outlaw the weapons in their jurisdictions.

TITLE: Solomon Islands says China security deal won't include military base
SUMMARY: The Solomon Islands said that despite a recent pact with China, it won't allow the major power to build a military base, and the two are only collaborating on security and naval refueling.

TITLE: 2 South Korean air force planes collide and crash, killing 4
SUMMARY: Two South Korean KT-1 trainer aircraft planes collided in mid-air during training and crashed near their base on Friday, killing all four people aboard the aircraft, officials said.

TITLE: After 2 years of empty airports, the demand for travel is at a high. So are airfares
SUMMARY: Domestic air travel demand this spring is back to pre-pandemic levels. But airlines see headwinds as the war in Ukraine drives up jet fuel prices and air fares and has international travel lagging

TITLE: Trump is struggling again in Georgia, with 2022 endorsements driven by his 2020 loss
SUMMARY: Donald Trump is embracing longshot candidates and seeking to oust incumbents that did not overturn his defeat. Many of his chosen GOP candidates are struggling in Georgia and other states.

TITLE: Odds are your NCAA bracket has already been busted, but that's half the fun
SUMMARY: Don't feel bad if your NCAA men's basketball tournament bracket has already been vaporized. The odds of predicting a perfect March Madness bracket are one in 9.2 quintillion.

TITLE: Sleeping with even a little bit of light isn't good for your health, study shows
SUMMARY: Just a night or two of exposure to faint light is enough to raise your pulse and increase insulin resistance — factors that increase the risk of heart disease and diabetes, researchers find.

TITLE: The far-right and environmentalism overlap is bigger than you think — and growing
SUMMARY: The modern environmental movement and the far-right movement might appear to be on opposing sides of the political ideology spectrum. But overlap does exist and researchers say it's growing.

TITLE: Philadelphia set a homicide record in 2021. Now police hope a new tactic deters crime
SUMMARY: Police hope to lower the city's raging homicide rate by focusing more resources on shootings that don't kill." We're modeling a lot of our things on what homicide does," says Lt. Dennis Rosenbaum.

TITLE: New Mexico launches cannabis sales, within Texans' reach
SUMMARY: New Mexico is making the sale of up to 2 ounces of recreational marijuana legal, bringing legalization to the doorstep of Texas, the largest prohibition state.

TITLE: Exclusive: How the student loan safety net has failed low-income borrowers
SUMMARY: Income-driven repayment plans were intended to help low-income student loan borrowers, and eventually cancel their debt. New documents paint a breathtaking picture of the program's failure.

TITLE: Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot proposes gift cards to help residents pay for gas
SUMMARY: The proposal also includes transit cards that will help Illinois residents paying an average of $4.46 per gallon at the pump, compared to a national average of $4.23.

TITLE: Ukraine top of agenda as China, EU prepare to meet at summit
SUMMARY: The European Union is seeking China's assurances that it won't assist Russia in circumventing economic sanctions for invading Ukraine and cooperation on ending the war at today's virtual meeting.

TITLE: Nearly 300 Texas defendants were released after a computer glitch delayed hearings
SUMMARY: The computer system used for law enforcement in the Houston area crashed on March 24, preventing defendants from getting an initial court hearing within the legal timeframe.

TITLE: 5 fetuses were found inside an anti-abortion activist's home in D.C.
SUMMARY: Lauren Handy was separately indicted this week on federal charges alleging that she was part of a group that blocked access to a Washington, D.C., reproductive health center.

TITLE: Employers continue hiring spree even as war in Ukraine ratchets up economic fears
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added 431,000 bs in March, as the unemployment rate fell to 3.6% from 3.8% in February. The tight job market is putting upward pressure on both wages and prices.

TITLE: Qatar hosts Friday's draw for the Middle East's 1st World Cup
SUMMARY: The day began with a protest outside FIFA headquarters in Zurich drawing attention to the conditions of migrant workers in Qatar who worked on the World Cup infrastructure.

TITLE: LGBTQ groups sue Florida over the so-called 'Don't Say Gay' law
SUMMARY: The challenge against Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis aims to block a new law that forbids classroom instruction on sexual orientation and gender identity in kindergarten through third grade.

TITLE: Famed fashion photographer Patrick Demarchelier dies at age 78
SUMMARY: A close friend of Princess Diana, Patrick Demarchelier was one of the leading fashion photographers of his era.

TITLE: The pope apologizes for abuse of Indigenous children in Canada's residential schools
SUMMARY: Pope Francis met with Indigenous leaders and survivors of Canada's residential schools this week. He had expressed sorrow in the past on behalf of the church, but this is the first formal apology.

TITLE: Landowners in Iowa resist companies' plans to create carbon-capture pipelines
SUMMARY: Three carbon capture pipelines have been proposed through five midwest states, but activists say proponents' claims of helping the ethanol industry and curbing climate change are wrong.

TITLE: The U.S. is ending its pandemic border rules. It could mean a surge in migration
SUMMARY: The Biden administration is moving to end sweeping pandemic border restrictions known as Title 42 on May 23. The controversial public health order was used to quickly expel migrants at the border.

TITLE: In a stunning victory, Amazon workers on Staten Island vote for a union
SUMMARY: Warehouse workers at an Amazon fulfillment center on Staten Island have voted to join the upstart Amazon Labor Union, making it the first Amazon facility in the U.S. to unionize.

TITLE: Shanghai locks down, but experts ask how else China could combat COVID
SUMMARY: Battling its biggest COVID surge in two years, Shanghai has instituted rigorous lockdowns — again — that are frustrating residents.

TITLE: Jen Psaki leaving the White House for MSNBC this spring
SUMMARY: The White House press secretary is expected to serve as a pundit and host a show on the network's streaming platform. She's the second Biden administration official jumping to MSNBC recently.

TITLE: Zelenskyy calls 2 Ukrainian generals traitorous and strips them of their rank
SUMMARY: Zelenskyy did not elaborate on what prompted the removal of the intelligence officers, one of whom has ties to the fallen Ukrainian city of Kherson. But he vowed traitors would "all be punished."

TITLE: 3 takeaways from NPR's investigation into a troubled student loan repayment program
SUMMARY: Many of the lowest-income federal student loan borrowers have had their hopes of debt cancellation delayed or derailed as a result of mismanagement, NPR found.

TITLE: A naturalist traces the astounding flyways of migratory birds
SUMMARY: Scott Weidensaul has spent decades studying bird migration. "There is a tremendous solace in watching these natural rhythms play out again and again," he says. <em>Originally broadcast March 29, 2021.

TITLE: Russia threatens to fine Wikipedia if it doesn't remove some details about the war
SUMMARY: Russia's communications regulator says it will fine Wikipedia up to $47,000 for not complying with requests to take down information. It has made similar warnings to Google about YouTube videos.

TITLE: 'Russian mutants lost this round,' Ukraine says after troops leave Chernobyl
SUMMARY: Ukraine's defense ministry cited two reasons for the Russian exit: military losses and radiation exposure. They likely disturbed polluted soil in the Chernobyl zone's contaminated Red Forest.

TITLE: The oldest park ranger, who told the stories of Black women in WWII, retires at 100
SUMMARY: "What gets remembered is a function of who's in the room doing the remembering," Betty Reid Soskin has said. She shaped World War II history exhibits to highlight the segregation Black people faced.

TITLE: Coronavirus FAQ: Our mini-zine has advice on when & how to dial down COVID precautions
SUMMARY: Cases are surging in some regions but dropping in many places. If you're in the latter situation, is it OK to go back to living as you did pre-pandemic? Print our handy zine with advice from experts.

TITLE: California is getting a very dry start to spring, with snowpack far below average
SUMMARY: Without a heavy dose of April and May showers, the state's drought will deepen. That could lead to stricter rules on water use and another devastating wildfire season.

TITLE: A federal judge dismisses a lawsuit that claimed Pop-Tarts aren't strawberry enough
SUMMARY: The lawsuit was originally filed in September 2020 by Kelvin Brown, who argued that the strawberry Pop-Tarts box is "misleading" because the pastries also contain apples and pears in their filling.

TITLE: Bipartisan bill to address supply chain kinks moves closer to the president's desk
SUMMARY: The Ocean Shipping Reform Act, which was approved unanimously in the Senate after a version was approved in the House late last year, aims to ease shipping backlogs at U.S. ports.

TITLE: 27 years to the day: UConn and Stanford meet again in the NCAA Women's Final Four
SUMMARY: The Women's Final Four Tournament is taking place in Minneapolis Friday night. South Carolina and Louisville play at 7:30 p.m. ET. UConn and Stanford play second at 9:30 p.m. ET.

TITLE: Suave antiperspirants are recalled because benzene was found in some samples
SUMMARY: The recall covers lots of two Suave 24-Hour Protection  aerosol antiperspirants with expiration dates through September 2023. It's the latest recall of consumer products linked to the carcinogen.

TITLE: Rep. Cawthorn's sordid tales of life in Congress frustrate GOP leadership
SUMMARY: The GOP freshman accused his colleagues of drug use and hosting orgies, without offering any evidence or specific details. It triggered a swifter response from party leaders than past controversies.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 1)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Navy will name ship after the late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
SUMMARY: The ship is part of the John Lewis class of replenishment oilers, which are named in honor of people who fought for civil and human rights, the Navy says.

TITLE: Will Smith resigns from the Academy, says he will accept additional consequences
SUMMARY: In a statement, Will Smith acknowledged that his actions overshadowed other winners at the 94th Academy Awards.

TITLE: Sarah Palin files to run for the late Alaska Rep. Don Young's seat
SUMMARY: The former vice presidential candidate filed with the <a href="https://docquery.fec.gov/cgi-bin/forms/C00811323/1577459">Federal Election Commission

TITLE: He was fired by Amazon 2 years ago. Now he's the force behind the company's 1st union
SUMMARY: Chris Smalls didn't rely on traditional labor groups for funding or organizing power. Instead he raised money through GoFundMe and talked to former coworkers at their bus stop and over S'mores.

TITLE: Rich companies are using a quiet tactic to block lawsuits: bankruptcy
SUMMARY: Companies that aren't bankrupt are using controversial maneuvers in U.S. bankruptcy court to block tens of thousands of suits. A woman suing Johnson & Johnson died while her case was in legal limbo.

TITLE: Biden is the latest president to go off script on Russia
SUMMARY: Biden was far from the first U.S. president to say what he thought about Russia or its leaders — or to pay a price for it.

TITLE: 27 years to the day: UConn defeats Stanford in the NCAA Women's Final Four
SUMMARY: The University of Connecticut knocked out defending champions Stanford, 63-58, Friday night. Earlier in the night, top-seeded Louisville fell to South Carolina, 72-59. The championship game is Sunday.

TITLE: Opinion: Grammy's 'global music' category ignores musicians from much of the globe
SUMMARY: This year, the Grammys has not 1 but 2 "global" categories. But 7 of the nominees come from just 2 countries: Benin and Nigeria. It's part of a Grammy pattern of focusing on a short list of nations.

TITLE: Opinion: The weightlessness of peace
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon remarks on the cooperation between Americans and Russians working with the International Space Station, despite tensions on Earth over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Another chapter in a historic rivalry will be written in tonight's Final Four matchup
SUMMARY: North Carolina will face Duke for the first time in the NCAA tournament as famed Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski hopes to end his career on a high note. And lone No. 1 seed Kansas will face Villanova.

TITLE: Opinion: Grammy's 'global music' categories ignore musicians from much of the globe
SUMMARY: This year, the Grammys has not 1 but 2 "global" categories. But 7 of the nominees come from just 2 countries: Benin and Nigeria. It's part of a Grammy pattern of focusing on a short list of nations.

TITLE: Young women earn more than young men in several U.S. cities
SUMMARY: In 22 of 250 metro areas, women under the age of 30 earn as much or more than their male counterparts, a Pew Research Center report found.

TITLE: Eleanor Roosevelt, Bessie Coleman and others to be featured on U.S. quarters
SUMMARY: The U.S. Mint has announced the next five women to be featured starting in 2023 as part of its American Women Quarters Program.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 2)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: UNESCO says 53 cultural sites in Ukraine have been damaged since the Russian invasion
SUMMARY: The damaged sites include churches, historic buildings, museums and monuments. A UNESCO spokesperson said they fear more sites will be added to the list as the group works to verify the destruction.

TITLE: Kansas knocks out Villanova to reach title game, as fate of historic rivalry awaits
SUMMARY: The Jayhawks beat the Wildcats 81-65, setting up a final matchup between Kansas and the winner of the first NCAA tournament showdown between rivals Duke and UNC.

TITLE: Opposition vows end to Orban's autocratic rule in Hungary
SUMMARY: A coalition of opposition parties made an appeal to voters before Hungary's election on Sunday, which decides whether nationalist Prime Minister Viktor Orban will win a fourth consecutive term.

TITLE: Kansas and UNC will face off in the title game, and Coach K's career comes to an end
SUMMARY: The Jayhawks and the Tar Heels advance to the final of the men's NCAA basketball tournament. Duke head coach Mike Krzyzewski had announced he would retire at the end of the season.

TITLE: Generations sing to Joni Mitchell in pre-Grammys tribute
SUMMARY: 81-year-old jazz giant Herbie Hancock, Meryl Streep, Cyndi Lauper and John Legend were among stars to celebrate Mitchell in an event ahead of the Grammys on Sunday night.

TITLE: Pakistan's PM Imran Khan faces tough challenge with no-confidence vote
SUMMARY: Pakistan's embattled prime minister Imran Khan faces a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Sunday and the opposition says it has the numbers to win after in a fragile coalition abandoned him.

TITLE: Kim's sister in North Korea enraged by Seoul's preemptive strike comments
SUMMARY: The influential sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un called the South Korean defense minister a "scum-like guy" for talking about preemptive strikes on the North, and made a "serious threat"

TITLE: Lawyers hope new evidence can stop Texas woman Melissa Lucio's execution
SUMMARY: Lawyers say an ambiguous statement by Lucio during questioning was wrongly interpreted by prosecutors as a murder confession, during the investigation into her daughter Mariah's 2007 death.

TITLE: Pakistan's PM Imran Khan disolves Parliament before no confidence vote
SUMMARY: Pakistan's politics was thrown into dissarray on Sunday after PM Khan asked the president to dissolve parliament, interrupting a session where he had been expected to lose a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: Pakistan's PM Imran Khan attempts to dissolve Parliament before confidence vote
SUMMARY: Pakistan's politics was thrown into dissarray on Sunday after PM Khan asked the president to dissolve parliament, interrupting a session where he had been expected to lose a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski's career ends, UNC and Kansas will play final game
SUMMARY: Krzyzewski announced he would retire at the end of the season. His Duke were beaten by UNC, while the Kansas Jayhawks beat the Villanova Wildcats to reach the final of the NCAA basketball tournament.

TITLE: Ukraine: Russian strikes on Odesa, Kyiv mayor says Russia committing genocide
SUMMARY: The Russian military says it has struck an oil processing plant near the Black Sea port of Odesa, while Kyiv mayor Vitali Klitschko spoke of "cruel war crimes" by Russians retreating from Bucha.

TITLE: Pakistan's PM Imran Khan dissolves Parliament before confidence vote
SUMMARY: Pakistan's politics was thrown into dissarray on Sunday after PM Khan asked the president to dissolve parliament, interrupting a session where he had been expected to lose a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: New laws let visitors see loved ones in health care facilities, even in an outbreak
SUMMARY: To contain the spread of COVID, hospitals and nursing homes barred visits, but the separation and isolation took a toll on patients and families. Now, some states are trying to ensure access.

TITLE: Estelle Harris, whose acting credits include 'Seinfeld' and 'Toy Story,' has died
SUMMARY: Harris hollered her way into TV history as George Costanza's short-fused mother on "Seinfeld" and voiced Mrs. Potato Head in the "Toy Story" franchise. She was 93.

TITLE: 6 people are dead and 10 are hospitalized in a shooting in Sacramento
SUMMARY: Police Chief Kathy Lester is asking for the public's help in identifying those responsible.

TITLE: Russia hits an oil processing plant near the port city of Odesa
SUMMARY: Meanwhile, Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko spoke of "cruel war crimes" by Russians retreating from the nearby city of Bucha.

TITLE: Pakistan is heading to early elections after Imran Khan dissolves Parliament
SUMMARY: Pakistan's politics was thrown into disarray when the prime minister asked the president to dissolve parliament, interrupting a session where he had been expected to lose a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: The opposition in Hungary vows end to Orban's autocratic rule
SUMMARY: A coalition of opposition parties made an appeal to voters before Hungary's election on Sunday, which decides whether nationalist Prime Minister Viktor Orban will win a fourth consecutive term.

TITLE: Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski's career ends as UNC and Kansas head to the season finale
SUMMARY: Krzyzewski had announced he would retire at the end of the season. His players were beaten by UNC, while Kansas beat Villanova to reach the final of the men's NCAA basketball tournament.

TITLE: California's law mandating corporate boards to diversity was ruled unconstitutional
SUMMARY: The decision granted a summary judgment to a conservative legal group that sought a permanent injunction against the landmark law. The ruling didn't explain the judge's reasoning.

TITLE: Pakistan is thrown into crisis after the prime minister dissolves parliament
SUMMARY: The nation's politics was thrust into disarray after Prime Minister Imran Khan dissolved parliament ahead of a vote on a no-confidence motion in which he was widely expected to lose.

TITLE: 6 people are dead and 12 injured in a shooting in Sacramento
SUMMARY: Police Chief Kathy Lester is asking for the public's help in identifying those responsible.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 3)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Hungary's Viktor Orban claims a 4th term, extending his autocratic rule
SUMMARY: The prime minister declared victory in the national elections, claiming a mandate for another term as a partial vote count predicted a strong lead for his right-wing party.

TITLE: President Zelenskyy appears at Grammys in video from Kyiv bunker
SUMMARY: The appearance comes as Russian forces continue pressing ahead with their invasion in Ukraine.

TITLE: South Carolina beats UConn to win 2022 NCAA women's championship
SUMMARY: The Gamecocks finished up the tournament with a 64-49 victory over the UConn Huskies.

TITLE: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam says she won't seek second term
SUMMARY: Lam's five years as the territory's chief executive was marked by widespread protests against her government.

TITLE: Jon Batiste and Silk Sonic take home major prizes at 2022 Grammys
SUMMARY: In a year of particularly wide-ranging nominees and competitive fields, bandleader Jon Batiste and the duo Silk Sonic came away with big prizes. Ukrainian president Zelenskyy also made an appearance.

TITLE: Louis C.K. crawls out of cancellation, wins a Grammy and triggers a backlash
SUMMARY: The 54-year-old comedian was canceled after admitting to sexual misconduct almost five years ago. But his most recent album brought home a Grammy for best comedy album.

TITLE: Democrats are expected to advance SCOTUS nominee Ketanji Jackson Brown to floor vote

SUMMARY: More than 12% of mail ballots were rejected for the primary. That's a far higher rejection rate than in previous contests.

SUMMARY: The 10 winners of this year's Whiting Awards have been announced; the $50,000 prize honors emerging writers, with the hope of allowing them to concentrate full-time on their work.

SUMMARY: A multistate outbreak of norovirus illnesses linked to raw oysters from Canada is under investigation in 13 states by the FDA.

SUMMARY: The ruling comes as human rights groups warn that turning the case of the killing of <em>Washington Post

SUMMARY: Higher mortgage rates and home prices have pushed the monthly payment to buy the median-priced home in the U.S. up more than 50% since the start of last year. Many first-time buyers can't afford it.

SUMMARY: A new report on gig worker deaths found that more than 50 people were killed while working for Uber, Lyft and DoorDash. Often the families receive no compensation in the wake of the killings.
