SUMMARY: The Georgia Bureau of Investigation says they have arrested a suspect in the triple homicide at a Georgia gun range earlier this month. As many as 40 guns were stolen.

TITLE: Authorities lift some evacuation orders after a fire breaks out in New Mexico
SUMMARY: So far, the McBride Fire has killed two people and destroyed more than 200 homes. Elsewhere in the U.S., crews have been battling large fires this week in Texas, Oklahoma and Colorado.

TITLE: The U.S. designates Temporary Protected Status to Cameroon for 18 months
SUMMARY: The designation comes amid extreme violence between Cameroon's forces and separatists as well as a significant rise in attacks from Boko Haram, according to the Department of Homeland Security.

TITLE: 10 people were shot at a mall in Columbia, S.C.
SUMMARY: Ten people were shot and two others injured in a shooting at a shopping mall. Police say the shooting was not random. Three people were detained.

TITLE: Israel police enter flashpoint Jerusalem holy site, arrest 2
SUMMARY: Israeli police have entered the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound, a sensitive Jerusalem holy site, two days after clashes with Palestinians.

TITLE: North Korea says it tested new tactical guided weapon
SUMMARY: North Korea has test-fired a new type of tactical guided weapon designed to boost its nuclear fighting capability, state media reported Sunday, days after it passed its biggest state anniversary.

TITLE: Police arrest suspect in South Carolina mall shooting
SUMMARY: Police have arrested a 22-year-old male in connection with a shooting at a busy shopping mall in South Carolina's capital Columbia on Saturday that left 14 people injured.

TITLE: Russia strikes Ukraine's big cities, bears down on Mariupol
SUMMARY: Russian forces renewed missile strikes on Kyiv and intensified shelling of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, in preparation for what is expected to be a full-scale Russian assault in the east.

TITLE: Washington state retools a first-in-nation payroll tax plan for long-term care costs
SUMMARY: The WA Cares Fund would help alleviate the financial burden of long-term care by providing workers a lifetime benefit of $36,500. The program was delayed while lawmakers addressed equity issues.

TITLE: Police: 2 dead, several injured in East Allegheny shooting
SUMMARY: Two people are dead and several more people are injured after a shooting during a party at an Airbnb property in Pittburgh's North Side early Sunday morning, police said.

TITLE: Young playwrights confront gun violence with their art and say #Enough
SUMMARY: Across the country, theaters and civic organizations  commemorate the 23rd anniversary of the Columbine school shootings by presenting readings of eight short plays by teenagers.

TITLE: Pope makes Easter plea for Ukraine peace, cites nuclear risk
SUMMARY: On what is supposed to be Christianity's most joyful day, Pope Francis made an anguished Easter Sunday plea for peace in the "senseless" war in Ukraine and in other armed conflicts in the world.

TITLE: PHOTOS: How this Bolivian all-female skate crew is celebrating their indigenous roots
SUMMARY: The young women skateboard while wearing polleras, colorful, layered skirts worn by their country's indigenous Aymara and Quechua women. They want to show girls and women it's OK to be themselves.

TITLE: Clashes erupt again near flashpoint Jerusalem holy site
SUMMARY: Israeli police on Sunday entered the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem's Old City to secure the way for Jewish visitors to the holy site, fueling clashes that left 17 Palestinians wounded.

TITLE: War crystalizes young Ukrainian leaders' calls for a future aligned with Europe
SUMMARY: These young politicians have few memories of life under Soviet rule — and they say the war has accelerated their efforts to push for a more Europe-focused future.

TITLE: The pope makes an Easter plea for peace in Ukraine, citing a nuclear risk
SUMMARY: On what is supposed to be Christianity's most joyful day, Pope Francis made an anguished Easter Sunday plea for peace in the "senseless" war in Ukraine and in other armed conflicts in the world.

TITLE: 2 people are dead and several others injured in a Pittsburgh shooting on Easter
SUMMARY: The shooting took place during a party at an Airbnb property in the city's North Side, police said. There is no information on any suspects at this time.

TITLE: Clashes erupt again near the Al-Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem
SUMMARY: Israeli police entered the compound in the Old City to secure the way for Jewish visitors to the holy site, fueling clashes that left 17 Palestinians wounded.

TITLE: 2 people are dead in a Pittsburgh shooting on Easter
SUMMARY: At least nine more people were wounded. The shooting took place during a party at an Airbnb property in the city's North Side, police said.

TITLE: North Korea says it tested a new tactical guided weapon
SUMMARY: North Korea has test-fired a new type of tactical guided weapon designed to boost its nuclear fighting capability, state media reported Sunday, days after it passed its biggest state anniversary.

TITLE: Police arrest a suspect in the South Carolina mall shooting
SUMMARY: A 22-year-old male was taken into custody in connection with a shooting at a busy mall in the state's capital city that left 14 people injured.

TITLE: The Ever Forward is finally free from the Chesapeake Bay — one month later
SUMMARY: The Ever Forward had just loaded up with cargo in Baltimore and was heading south to Norfolk, Va., when it ran aground on March 13. It had been stuck ever since — until Sunday morning.

TITLE: It's time to screen all kids for anxiety, physicians' task force recommends
SUMMARY: In light of the growing kids' mental health crisis, the group says it's crucial to identify kids who are struggling. The advice doesn't call for suicide screening, which many experts think is needed.

TITLE: 2 people are dead, 8 others shot in a Pittsburgh shooting on Easter Sunday
SUMMARY: The shooting took place during a party, attended by many underage people, at an Airbnb property in the city's North Side, police said.

TITLE: 2 people are dead, 8 others shot and injured at a house party in Pittsburgh
SUMMARY: The shooting took place during a party, attended by many underage people, at an Airbnb property in the city's North Side, police said. There were at least 90 rounds fired.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 17)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Shanghai reports 1st deaths from current COVID-19 outbreak
SUMMARY: Authorities reported the first COVID-19 deaths of the latest outbreak in China's most populous city and said all three  were elderly, had underlying conditions and had not been vaccinated.

TITLE: Why Philadelphia is bringing back its mask mandate
SUMMARY: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Dr. Leana Wen about Philadelphia's decision to reinstate a citywide mask mandate

TITLE: Keep screwing up egg fried rice. It makes Uncle Roger happy
SUMMARY: The YouTube hit is the brainchild of stand up comic Nigel Ng, who's in the middle of a world tour. But can he stand out beyond his character?

TITLE: Missile strikes in western Ukraine kill 6 as country braces for new assault in east
SUMMARY: Russian missile strikes on the western Ukrainian city of Lviv killed six people and wounded at least eight, the regional governor said, which appeared to target military infrastructure facilities

TITLE: Riots erupt in Sweden over rallies by an anti-Islam group
SUMMARY: Swedish police said they fired warning shots during a riot in an eastern city to disperse protesters angry about the far-right rallies. Three people were slightly injured during the clashes.

TITLE: Sarah Palin is attempting a comeback in Alaska, but her star has dimmed at home
SUMMARY: The former GOP vice presidential candidate resigned as Alaska governor in 2009. Even around her hometown of Wasilla, many Republicans soured as she gained a national following as a culture warrior.

TITLE: InfoWars files for bankruptcy in the face of lawsuits over Sandy Hook shooting denial
SUMMARY: Founder Alex Jones, who's repeatedly called the 2012 shooting in a Connecticut elementary school a hoax, has been sued several times by the victims' families for defamation and emotional distress.

TITLE: The Boston Marathon kicks off in its first spring race since the pandemic started
SUMMARY: The prestigious race is returning to its springtime spot for the first time since the pandemic began, after a cancelation in 2020 and a postponement to the fall in 2021.

TITLE: Hip hop pioneer DJ Kay Slay dies of COVID-19 at age 55
SUMMARY: Pioneering hip hop artist Keith Grayson, who performed as DJ Kay Slay, has died of complications from COVID-19. He worked with stars such as Nas, Kendrick Lamar, Jadakiss and Busta Rhymes.

TITLE: Israeli troops wound 2 Palestinians during new Israeli-Palestinian violence
SUMMARY: Israel has carried out a wave of arrest raids after Palestinian assailants killed at least 14 people inside Israel. At least 25 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli forces in recent weeks.

TITLE: Harrison Birtwistle, an influential English composer, has died at age 87
SUMMARY: Known for his sonic brashness and unyielding artistic vision, Birtwistle was awarded a British knighthood in 1988. He was one of the U.K.'s most prominent composers for decades.

TITLE: Hip-hop pioneer DJ Kay Slay dies of COVID-19 at age 55
SUMMARY: Pioneering hip-hop artist Keith Grayson, who performed as DJ Kay Slay, has died of complications from COVID-19. He worked with stars such as Nas, Kendrick Lamar, Jadakiss and Busta Rhymes.

TITLE: What Russians think of the war in Ukraine, according to an independent pollster
SUMMARY: Denis Volkov acknowledges that public opinion polling in Russia has its challenges and pitfalls, but says the findings still hold valuable information.

TITLE: GE Appliances recalls refrigerators with handles that can detach and pose a fall risk
SUMMARY: GE Appliances received reports of 37 injuries, including three injuries from serious falls. It is offering consumers a free in-home repair.

TITLE: A Florida judge overturns the CDC's mask mandate for planes and other public transit
SUMMARY: The mask-wearing requirement had been initially imposed in early 2021, shortly after President Joe Biden took office.

TITLE: Sweden links riots to criminal gangs that target police
SUMMARY: Swedish police said riots that have shaken several cities are extremely serious crimes and suspect some protesters are linked to criminal gangs that intentionally target police.

TITLE: Cristiano Ronaldo's newborn son has died
SUMMARY: Soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo and his partner Georgina Rodriguez said their newborn son had died.

TITLE: Ukraine crisis raises question: Does food aid go equally to 'Black and white lives'?
SUMMARY: That's what Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus of the World Health Organization and others ask in the wake of the outpouring of money to help Ukrainian victims of the war amid record levels of global hunger.

TITLE: A charity kitchen in Ukraine linked to chef José Andrés was destroyed by a missile
SUMMARY: The celebrity chef's nonprofit World Central Kitchen has been serving meals to families fleeing Ukraine. A restaurant that was partnering with the organization was destroyed by a Russian missile.

TITLE: The House and Senate are far apart on their bills to address computer chip shortage
SUMMARY: Both bodies have passed legislation on the matter, and the effort is one of their last opportunities before the November elections to show voters they are addressing strained supply chains.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 18)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Olympic champion Peres Jepchirchir wins the 50th women's Boston Marathon
SUMMARY: On the 50th anniversary of the first official women's race,  reigning Olympic champion Peres Jepchirchir came out on top.

TITLE: TSA will no longer enforce travel mask mandate after a federal judge strikes it down
SUMMARY: The mask-wearing requirement had been initially imposed in early 2021, shortly after President Joe Biden took office.

TITLE: Radu Lupu, celebrated Romanian pianist, dies at age 76
SUMMARY: A pianist widely admired by his fellow artists, Radu Lupu was known for his interpretations of Brahms, Schubert, Mozart and Beethoven, among others. Lupu retired from performing in 2019.

TITLE: Some major U.S. airlines are dropping mask mandates for travelers
SUMMARY: Delta, United, Southwest, American and Alaska Airlines say that masks are now optional for travelers on their aircraft.

TITLE: Global finance meeting focuses on war-driven food insecurity
SUMMARY: Russia and Ukraine produce roughly 14% of the world's wheat supply, according to the United Nations, and the war has resulted in soaring food prices and fears about food security globally.

TITLE: Federal judge says Georgia voters can challenge Greene's reelection run
SUMMARY: Monday's ruling means a group of Georgia voters can proceed with efforts seeking to disqualify U.S Rep Marjorie Taylor Greene from running for reelection.

TITLE: US officials off to Solomon Islands amid concern over draft security pact with China
SUMMARY: National Security Council Indo-Pacific corrdinator Kurt Campbell will lead the U.S. delegation after the Solomons and China initialed a draft agreement of a security pact last month.

TITLE: Republicans confront (or sidestep) abuse accusations against midterm candidates
SUMMARY: Candidates such as Herschel Walker, Eric Greitens and Max Miller have been accused of abusing partners and, in some cases, children. But some party leaders aren't convinced voters will reject them.

TITLE: Despite effective treatments, HIV drags on. Experts warn COVID may face the same fate
SUMMARY: HIV remains a problem in the U.S. because people don't use life-saving prevention and treatments. COVID is heading down the same path. Here are insights from people fighting on the frontlines of HIV.

TITLE: Poison pills, white knights, 'Love Me Tender': What's next for Elon Musk and Twitter?
SUMMARY: Elon Musk is trying to buy Twitter in a $43 billion takeover, which the company's board is attempting to resist. What's at stake, and where is all this going?

TITLE: A Ukrainian family finds solace in America but cannot escape heartbreak
SUMMARY: When Russia invaded Ukraine, Eka Koliubaieva and her two daughters fled to the U.S., where a Virginia couple took them in after learning about the family's plight from a Facebook post.

TITLE: Russian invasion upends young, flourishing Ukrainian publishing industry
SUMMARY: After the Crimea invasion, a backlash against Russian books filled with propaganda led to the growth of Ukraine's own book industry. But Russia's latest attacks and Covid have created major obstacles.

TITLE: Better ventilation would create a healthier workplace — but companies have to invest
SUMMARY: The research is clear that air exchange and filtration curb the spread of COVID and other diseases, but upgrading systems is expensive, and there is little federal authority over indoor air quality.

TITLE: How a love of sci fi drives Elon Musk and an idea of 'extreme capitalism'
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has been in headlines for trying to buy Twitter, but one Harvard historian says his brand of capitalism goes back to his teen years and a particular reading of science fiction stories.

TITLE: U.S. team is off to Solomon Islands amid concern over draft security pact with China
SUMMARY: National Security Council Indo-Pacific corrdinator Kurt Campbell will lead the U.S. delegation after the Solomons and China initialed a draft agreement of a security pact last month.

TITLE: These airlines are dropping mask mandates after a federal judge's ruling
SUMMARY: Delta, United, Southwest, American and Alaska Airlines say that masks are now optional for travelers on their aircraft.

TITLE: What's next for Elon Musk and Twitter? Poison pills and 'Love Me Tender'
SUMMARY: Elon Musk is trying to buy Twitter in a $43 billion takeover, which the company's board is attempting to resist. What's at stake, and where is all this going?

TITLE: Ukraine says Russia's offensive in Donbas has begun. Here's what we know
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Russian forces have begun their new offensive against cities in the east and south and that a "substantial part" of the Russian army is taking part.

TITLE: Yemen's Houthi rebels will stop using child soldiers, the U.N. says
SUMMARY: Child soldiers have fought by the thousands during the country's war. The Houthis signed what the U.N. described as an "action plan" to end and prevent recruiting or using children in armed conflict

TITLE: 'Love Me Tender' and poison pills: Unpacking the Elon Musk-Twitter saga
SUMMARY: Elon Musk is trying to buy Twitter in a $43 billion takeover, which the company's board is attempting to resist. What's at stake, and where is all this going?

TITLE: Biden administration restores environmental reviews for major infrastructure projects
SUMMARY: The move restores regulations guiding environmental reviews of big projects such as highways and pipelines that were scaled back by the Trump administration in a bid to fast-track the projects.

TITLE: NASA advisors call for a visit to Uranus, plus more science during Moon landings
SUMMARY: NASA should send probes to the ice giant planet of Uranus and to a moon of Saturn where conditions could be right for life. Those are some of the recommendations in a new report  to the space agency.

TITLE: How a love of sci-fi drives Elon Musk and an idea of 'extreme capitalism'
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has been in headlines for trying to buy Twitter, but one Harvard historian says his brand of capitalism goes back to his teen years and a particular reading of science fiction stories.

TITLE: Delta updates its statement calling COVID a 'seasonal virus' after a backlash
SUMMARY: The airline chpnged its announcement about the end of the federal mask mandate after a firestorm of criticism from public health experts who called it inaccurate and misleading.

TITLE: DeSantis wants to end Disney World's special status in Florida
SUMMARY: Florida's Republican governor, Ron DeSantis, has asked lawmakers to consider a bill that would halt Disney World's exemptions to state regulations that were established more than 50 years ago.

TITLE: Moderna says its new 'bivalent' vaccine shows promise against COVID variants
SUMMARY: The company says this version targets both the original coronavirus and the beta variant, and appears to provide broader and longer-lasting protection against different strains, including omicron.

TITLE: NASA advisers call for a visit to Uranus, plus more science during Moon landings
SUMMARY: NASA should send probes to the ice giant planet of Uranus and to a moon of Saturn where conditions could be right for life. Those are some of the recommendations in a new report  to the space agency.

TITLE: Student loan borrowers will get help after an NPR report and years of complaints
SUMMARY: The U.S. Department of Education unveils a plan to help millions of borrowers who have been hurt and held back by its troubled income-driven repayment plans.

TITLE: What to know about Judge Kathryn Mizelle, who struck down the travel mask mandate
SUMMARY: Mizelle was nominated by former President Donald Trump in 2020 at age 33. The American Bar Association said at the time she wasn't qualified because she hadn't been practicing law for long enough.

TITLE: NASA advisers call for a visit to Uranus, plus more science during moon landings
SUMMARY: NASA should send probes to the ice giant planet of Uranus and to a moon of Saturn where conditions could be right for life. Those are some of the recommendations in a new report  to the space agency.

TITLE: Patrick Lyoya's family wants to know the name of the officer who shot him
SUMMARY: Police departments across the U.S. have faced scrutiny for withholding identities of officers in cases where Black people were wounded or killed during interactions with police.

TITLE: An autopsy shows Patrick Lyoya was shot in the back of the head by a Michigan cop
SUMMARY: The finding by a former medical examiner matches what was seen last week on video released by the Grand Rapids police chief. The official autopsy report hasn't been released to the public.

TITLE: A Mariupol native has created a site for residents to find missing loved ones
SUMMARY: Dmitriy Cherepanov, a lifelong Mariupol native, created MRPL.life, a site dedicated to helping residents locate missing loved ones in the besieged Ukrainian city.

TITLE: A late spring storm leaves thousands in the Northeast in the dark
SUMMARY: Some local officials say it could be some time before power is restored in hard-hit Broome County, New York.

TITLE: Climate change fueled extreme rainfall during the record 2020 hurricane reason
SUMMARY: Human-induced climate change fueled one of the most active  hurricane seasons on record in 2020, with rainfall totals up to 10% higher than in the pre-industrial era, according to a new study.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 19)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: The judge who tossed mask mandate misunderstood public health law, legal experts say
SUMMARY: Judge Kathryn Kimball Mizelle's decision hinged on a definition of the word 'sanitation' that public health experts and legal scholars say missed the mark.

TITLE: Johnny Depp in court says he has never struck any woman in his life
SUMMARY: Depp says in court: "Never did I myself reach the point of striking Ms. Heard in any way, nor have I ever struck any woman in my life."

TITLE: A university pays $400K to professor who refused to use a student's pronouns
SUMMARY: Nick Meriwether, a philosophy professor at Shawnee State University, sued the college in 2018 after he was disciplined for not using she/her pronouns to refer to a transgender student.

TITLE: To fight climate change, and now Russia, too, Zurich turns off natural gas
SUMMARY: Zurich, Switzerland, is shutting down the gas supply to some neighborhoods. Originally aimed at fighting climate change and saving money, it's also a step to cut gas imports from Russia.

TITLE: As Biden plans to lift Title 42, Democrats want details on how he'll address influx
SUMMARY: Some key Senate Democrats and candidates have come out this week and expressed reservations about the Biden administration's decision to lift Title 42 by May 23.

TITLE: Students with disabilities have a right to qualified teachers — but there's a shortage
SUMMARY: When schools can't find a licensed special education teacher, they hire people who are willing to do the job, but lack the training. It's a practice that concerns some special education experts.

TITLE: Ukrainian band DakhaBrakha deliver an urgent message to U.S. audiences
SUMMARY: This "ethno-chaos" group brings sophisticated music and strong anti-Putin messages to their listeners at home and abroad, as "ambassadors of free Ukraine." They're currently on a U.S. tour.

TITLE: It's planting season in Ukraine, and that means problems for global food supply
SUMMARY: Russia's invasion of Ukraine sent ripples beyond the immediate conflict zone, breaking supply chains and creating food shortages as two of the world's biggest food exporters went to war.

TITLE: Taylor Swift was the inspiration for the name of a new millipede species
SUMMARY: The Swift Twisted-Claw Millipede, or <em>Nannaria swiftae,

TITLE: Ukrainian band DakhaBrakha delivers an urgent message to U.S. audiences
SUMMARY: This "ethno-chaos" group brings sophisticated music and strong anti-Putin messages to their listeners at home and abroad, as "ambassadors of free Ukraine." They're currently on a U.S. tour.

TITLE: Shanghai eases COVID rules and allows 4 million more people out of their homes
SUMMARY: An official says the virus is under control in some parts of the city. Meanwhile, the IMF cut its forecast of Chinese economic growth and warned the global flow of industrial goods might be disrupted.

TITLE: Julian Assange is one major step closer to extradition to the U.S.
SUMMARY: A British judge on Wednesday formally approved the extradition of Julian Assange to the United States to face spying charges. The case will now go to Britain's interior minister for a decision.

TITLE: Netflix lost viewers for the 1st time in 10 years, says password sharing is to blame
SUMMARY: The entertainment company estimates there are now 100 million households using someone else's account. Last month, it announced plans to start charging for password sharing.

TITLE: Wimbledon bans Russian and Belarusian players — including No. 2 Medvedev
SUMMARY: The British tournament becomes one of the first tennis events to suspend players from the two countries since Russia invaded Ukraine, and excludes several highly ranked players from competition.

TITLE: Meet Patron, a bomb-sniffing Jack Russell terrier who has become a Ukrainian hero
SUMMARY: Two-year-old Patron works with rescuers in the northern city of Chernihiv, where he sniffs out Russian bombs (in addition to warming laps, nipping sleeves and generally being a good boy).

TITLE: A New Jersey Catholic diocese agrees to pay $87.5M to settle sex abuse lawsuits
SUMMARY: The Diocese of Camden agreed to settle claims involving clergy sex abuse with some 300 alleged victims in one of the largest cash settlements involving the Catholic Church in the United States.

TITLE: Montpelier's fight with descendants of the enslaved brings employee firings
SUMMARY: Problems at Montpelier, years in the making, reached a boiling point this week when a number of employees who had supported descendants of the enslaved were fired.

TITLE: Migrant workers in China find new jobs — and precarious conditions — in COVID control
SUMMARY: China's economic downturn has left thousands of migrant workers unemployed. They're pivoting to work in COVID control — and have strong concerns about how they are being treated.

TITLE: Online conspiracy theories are bleeding into all parts of Georgia's politics
SUMMARY: Conspiracy theories are having an impact on non-controversial aspects of politics, including a bipartisan mental health bill in Georgia.

TITLE: Ukrainians wait in line for hours to buy commemorative Snake Island postage stamps
SUMMARY: The stamps honor the Snake Island soldiers who answered a Russian calls to surrender with "Russian warship, go f*** yourself!" Ukraine's postal service had to limit purchases to six stamps apiece.

TITLE: A key Texas bridge lost $1 billion per week during governor's slowdown
SUMMARY: Gov. Greg Abbott's rule imposing safety inspections at the border did "nothing to stop the flow of illegal immigration or illegal drugs," Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller told NPR.

TITLE: A mental health bill in Georgia shows how conspiracy theories are affecting politics
SUMMARY: A bipartisan mental health reform bill in Georgia was briefly sidelined after far-right Republican groups spread disinformation about its purpose, including false claims of decriminalizing pedophilia.

TITLE: A$AP Rocky is arrested in Los Angeles in connection with a 2021 shooting
SUMMARY: Police said they arrested the rapper at the Los Angeles International Airport "for assault with a deadly weapon" tied to a November shooting.

TITLE: The number of people fleeing Ukraine has surpassed 5 million
SUMMARY: The U.N. had initially estimated that 4 million Ukrainians would flee Russia's war — a number that was exceeded last month. Overall, more than 10 million people have been displaced by the conflict.

TITLE: New Mexico fines 'Rust' movie producers $139,793 for firearms safety failures
SUMMARY: State regulators said Rust Movie Productions must pay the maximum possible fine for safety failures on the set where a cinematographer was fatally shot in October by actor and producer Alec Baldwin.

TITLE: South Carolina's planned execution by firing squad is on hold for now
SUMMARY: The state Supreme Court is temporarily blocking what was set to be South Carolina's first-ever firing squad execution. The planned April 29 execution of Richard Bernard Moore is now on hold.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 20)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Alex Jones' trial to determine payments to Sandy Hook families is delayed
SUMMARY: A Texas judge pushed back the first jury trial over how much the conspiracy theorist should pay the families of Sandy Hook victims. Jones' Infowars company sought bankruptcy protection this week.

TITLE: Pot shop robberies are fueling calls for a U.S. banking bill
SUMMARY: A surge in robberies at licensed cannabis shops is helping fuel a renewed push for federal banking reforms that would make the cash-dependent stores a less appealing target.

TITLE: Amid high gas prices, N.J. weighs lifting its self-service gas ban
SUMMARY: Gas station owners argue the move would help ease a labor shortage and bring prices down, but drivers and politicians are wary of changing the practice.

TITLE: A Connecticut trooper who shot a Black driver to death is charged with manslaughter
SUMMARY: Trooper Brian North fired seven gunshots into a car, killing 19-year-old Mubarak Soulemane in 2020 after a high-speed chase. North said he feared Soulemane would attack other officers with a knife.

TITLE: Janet Yellen and other finance ministers walk out of G20 meeting as Russia speaks
SUMMARY: Yellen's counterparts from the U.K. and Canada joined the walkout to protest Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: The DOJ will appeal the recent mask ruling by a federal judge
SUMMARY: This decision to appeal comes just two days after U.S. District Judge Kathryn Kimball Mizelle ruled against the federal mask mandate.

TITLE: Wildfires are increasingly contributing to unhealthy air
SUMMARY: The rising number of fires hamper decades of environmental efforts, and over 40% of Americans — more than 137 million people — live in places with poor air quality, a new report says.

TITLE: Israel, Gaza militants trade fire as Mideast tensions mount
SUMMARY: Palestinian militants fired several rockets into southern Israel from the Gaza Strip early Thursday and Israeli aircraft hit militant targets in Gaza.

TITLE: Macron attacks Le Pen on Russia, Muslim headscarf ban pledge
SUMMARY: French President Emmanuel Macron tore into his far-right challenger Marine Le Pen in a debate for her ties to Russia and wanting to strip Muslim women of their right to cover their heads in public.

TITLE: Employees at an Atlanta mall become the first Apple retail workers to unionize
SUMMARY: Communications Workers of America, the retail workers' union, said big tech companies like Apple fail to give employees who don't work in an office equal standing and respect.

TITLE: Some civilians leave as Russians tighten noose on Mariupol
SUMMARY: Only four buses with civilians managed to escape from Mariupol after several unsuccessful attempts, Ukrainian officials said Thursday, as thousands more remained trapped under Russian attacks.

TITLE: Gaza violence intensifies as Jerusalem clashes resume
SUMMARY: Israel's air force and Palestinian militants traded fire across the Gaza frontier early Thursday as clashes erupted again at Jerusalem's most sensitive holy site.

TITLE: Syracuse police officers are under scrutiny after a video went viral
SUMMARY: The Syracuse Police Department says they are reviewing the officers' actions and body-worn cameras

TITLE: Wind will be a force to reckon with on Southwest wildfires
SUMMARY: Fire managers across the Southwest are reckoning with strong winds that forecasters say could lead to explosive growth in wildfires this week.

TITLE: Polish women band together to give Ukrainian women car rides to safe refuge
SUMMARY: Spooked by reports that traffickers are waiting at the Ukraine-Poland border, a Polish woman started an all-women car service to drive Ukrainian refugee women and children to homes or shelters.

TITLE: Ex-Honduran President Hernández will be extradited to the U.S. on drugs charges
SUMMARY: A plane from the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration is scheduled to arrive in Honduras early Thursday to take former President Juan Orlando Hernández to the U.S. to face drug and weapons charges.

TITLE: 'Navalny' documentary spotlights the Russian who dared to take on Putin
SUMMARY: Daniel Roher's film about Russian dissident Alexei Navalny offers intimate, sometimes amazing access to the bravery — and human cost — of opposing a despot.

TITLE: Trump's endorsement of Oz reframes the Pennsylvania GOP Senate contest
SUMMARY: For the state's open U.S. Senate seat, the two top Republican contenders are David McCormick and Mehmet Oz. And, as in so many GOP races this year, there's another major player — Donald Trump.

TITLE: A civil rights memorial in Alabama expands to document lynching victims' stories
SUMMARY: The Equal Justice Initiative addresses America's history of racial violence at a time when state lawmakers nationwide have been trying to limit teaching about divisive topics in public schools.

TITLE: Schools are struggling to hire special education teachers. Hawaii may have found a fix
SUMMARY: In Hawaii, hiring qualified special education teachers became a lot easier after schools started offering a $10,000 pay bump.

TITLE: Putin tells forces not to storm Ukraine holdout in Mariupol
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered his forces not to storm the last remaining Ukrainian stronghold in the city of Mariupol, but instead to block it 'so that not even a fly comes through'.

TITLE: Transit riders are worried about safety. Police in Philly are trying a new approach
SUMMARY: Homelessness and drug use became more visible on public transit during the pandemic, worrying commuters. Philadelphia is now pairing cops with social workers to help those in need.

TITLE: Michelle Obama's brother and his wife sue Milwaukee school for alleged racial bias
SUMMARY: Craig and Kelly Robinson say the University School of Milwaukee ended their sons' enrollment after they raised concerns about the school's treatment of students of color and other alleged biases.

TITLE: Putin tries to claim Mariupol win but won't storm holdout
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin tried to claim victory in the strategic port of Mariupol on Thursday, even as he ordered his troops not to storm the last pocket of Ukrainian resistance.

TITLE: Drug overdose deaths are at a record high. Here's what the White House plans to do
SUMMARY: Harm reduction is one of four policies the Biden administration says must be immediately implemented in order to address the record high number of overdose deaths.

TITLE: Syracuse police are under scrutiny after video shows officers detaining a crying boy
SUMMARY: The Syracuse Police Department says they are reviewing the officers' actions and body-worn cameras

TITLE: Apple workers in Atlanta become company's 1st retail workers to file to unionize
SUMMARY: Communications Workers of America, the retail workers' union, said big tech companies like Apple fail to give employees who don't work in an office equal standing and respect.

TITLE: Tony award winner and 'Mad Men' star Robert Morse dies at 90
SUMMARY: Robert Morse, who starred in How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying as a young actor and, decades later, returned to the corporate world with TV's Mad Men

TITLE: Elon Musk says he has secured the money to buy Twitter

SUMMARY: She briefly mentioned her husband's Academy Awards outburst, telling viewers of her talk show that the family is "focused on deep healing."

TITLE: Control of the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol eludes the Russian invaders

TITLE: Anastasia thinks about leaving Russia. Here's what her life looks like today

TITLE: U.S. Capitol Police say an 'extremely unusual' oversight triggered Capitol evacuation
SUMMARY: The evacuation was prompted after a plane tied to a planned flyover of nearby Nationals Park entered restricted airspace. The Capitol Police had not been given advance notice of the approved flight.

SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: Russia is still making billions of dollars on oil exports since invading Ukraine. That crude is still flowing abroad thanks in part to a controversial group of oil traders.

SUMMARY: Voters and a supporting legal group are seeking to knock the controversial Republican off the ballot for her role prior to the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol.

SUMMARY: In China, for example, not only are masks required on planes but gloves are recommended — and passengers are urged not to touch their face during the flight. Here's what you'll find around the globe.

SUMMARY: In China, for example, not only are masks required on planes but gloves are recommended — and passengers are urged not to touch their face during the flight. Here's what you'll find around the globe.

SUMMARY: Reentry plans should begin as soon as a person is incarcerated and no later than 18 months before a person's sentence is complete, Biden's office said.

TITLE: Florida man asks schools to ban the Bible following the state's efforts to remove books
SUMMARY: Activist Chaz Stevens says the book isn't age appropriate and contains references to rape and bestiality. It's a not-so-subtle dig at Florida's recent efforts to ban books.

TITLE: Russia's invasion of Ukraine heats up cooking oil prices in global squeeze
SUMMARY: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has further fueled already high food and energy costs, hitting the poorest people hardest.

TITLE: A rattlesnake bit Cary Elwes. Here's what to do if it happens to you
SUMMARY: Don't apply a tourniquet or try to suck out the poison. Instead, call 911 and do your best to stay calm.

TITLE: Kyiv will dismantle a Soviet-era monument and rename streets linked to Russia
SUMMARY: The People's Friendship Arch was gifted to Ukraine by the Soviet government in the 1980s. Kyiv's mayor says the statue underneath is being dismantled, and the arch will be renamed and repainted.

TITLE: Biden takes his first actions on clemency with 3 pardons and 75 commutations
SUMMARY: Tuesday's pardons and commutations are part of a broader White House effort to make the criminal justice system more fair – a goal Biden made part of his 2020 presidential campaign.

TITLE: Florida man asks schools to ban Bible following the state's efforts to remove books
SUMMARY: Activist Chaz Stevens says the book isn't age appropriate and contains references to rape and bestiality. It's a not-so-subtle dig at Florida's recent efforts to ban books.

TITLE: Police release a trove of videos in the probe of the Alec Baldwin film-set shooting
SUMMARY: Police in Santa Fe, N.M., say they will release all files in the investigation into the fatal shooting in October of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins by Baldwin on the set of <em>Rust

TITLE: Vice President Harris has tested positive for COVID-19
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris has tested positive for COVID-19 and has exhibited no symptoms, the White House announced on Tuesday. She's not considered a close contact to President Biden or the first lady.

TITLE: The U.N. now projects more than 8 million people will flee Ukraine as refugees
SUMMARY: The number is more than double what the U.N.'s refugee agency projected in February when Russia invaded the country. The vast majority of those who have already left are women and children.

TITLE: Fidelity will start offering bitcoin as an investment option in 401(k) accounts
SUMMARY: Fidelity said it has signed up one employer that will add the offering to its plan later this year. The U.S. government has warned the industry to exercise extreme care when offering cryptocurrencies.

TITLE: In a lawsuit, a group of Texas library patrons says a book ban amounts to censorship
SUMMARY: Llano County officials said they wanted to remove "pornographic" material from libraries but actually censored books based on political and religious grounds, the library patrons' lawsuit says.

TITLE: How does Ukraine keep intercepting Russian military communications?
SUMMARY: Russia had a reputation for being highly skilled in secretive military communications. That notion has been largely shattered by the bumbling way it has been operating in Ukraine.

TITLE: Most Americans have been infected with the COVID-19 virus, the CDC reports
SUMMARY: So many people caught the omicron variant over the winter that almost 60% of everyone in the U.S. — including most children — now have antibodies to the virus in their blood, the CDC said Tuesday.

TITLE: Russian-occupied area of Moldova blames Ukrainian militants for explosions
SUMMARY: Trans-Dniester doesn't usually get much attention. But European leaders are watching it closely because it hosts about 1,500 Russian troops and shares a 250-mile border with Ukraine.

TITLE: The pandemic erased a decade of public preschool gains
SUMMARY: An annual review of state-based preschool programs found big drops in enrollment and state funding in the 2020-2021 school year.

TITLE: Delta will begin paying flight attendants for flight boarding time
SUMMARY: Pay for flight attendants typically starts when all the passengers are seated and the plane's doors close. The change is expected to increase wages by several thousand dollars a year.

TITLE: Corvette is the next big name in cars to roll out an electric
SUMMARY: An "electrified" Corvette is coming next year, with a "fully electric" model to follow, GM's president says. The automaker faces heavy competition in an electric vehicle market dominated by Tesla.

TITLE: Bad Bunny will be the first Latino to lead a live-action Marvel movie
SUMMARY: Puerto Rican musician Bad Bunny will play the title character in the Spider-Man spinoff<em> El Muerto

TITLE: U.S. speeds up phaseout of incandescent light bulbs in favor of energy-efficient ones
SUMMARY: Rules finalized by the Energy Department will accelerate an industry practice to use compact fluorescent and LED bulbs. Consumers could save $3 billion a year on utility bills, the agency said.

TITLE: Putin wanted a militarily weaker Ukraine. He got the opposite
SUMMARY: The longer Ukraine's army fends off the Russian invasion, the more it absorbs the advantages of Western weaponry and training — exactly the transformation Vladimir Putin wanted to prevent by invading.

TITLE: Tesla shares sink, wipe out over $125 billion in value, as Musk scores Twitter deal
SUMMARY: Tesla shares dropped 12.2%, wiping out more than $125 billion off its market value, over worries about how it would be impacted  as Elon Musk looks to completes his takeover of Twitter.

TITLE: Pfizer asks FDA to authorize booster shots for kids ages 5 through 11
SUMMARY: Data show that a third dose can help boost kids' immunity. Some experts are skeptical that another shot is needed for younger kids.

TITLE: Poland and Bulgaria say Russia is suspending their natural gas supplies
SUMMARY: The governments of the two European countries said Tuesday that Russian energy giant Gazprom informed them it was halting gas supplies starting Wednesday.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 26)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Vaccine-derived polio is on the rise. A new vaccine aims to stop the spread
SUMMARY: Countries in Africa, the Middle East and parts of Asia are counting more cases of vaccine-derived polio. One reason for this, say experts, is that vaccination efforts have lapsed during the pandemic.

TITLE: Shares continue to slump as fears about the economy and earnings grip Wall Street
SUMMARY: The Dow dropped by more than 800 points as investors deal with a slew of concerns, including disappointing earnings and the prospect of sharply higher interest rates.

TITLE: Older adults shouldn't start a routine of daily aspirin, task force says
SUMMARY: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force says people 60 and older should not start taking aspirin to prevent heart attacks and strokes. People ages 40 to 59 should consult their doctor.

TITLE: The LA sheriff is investigating a reporter who broke a story on a department cover-up
SUMMARY: Sheriff Alex Villanueva said he was investigating leaked materials, including a video published by the <em>Los Angeles Times

TITLE: Myanmar court sentences Suu Kyi to 5 years for corruption
SUMMARY: Her supporters and independent legal experts consider her prosecution an unjust move to discredit Suu Kyi and legitimize the military's 2021 seizure of power.

TITLE: Singapore executes disabled Malaysian convicted in drug case
SUMMARY: Supporters and lawyers of the man said he had an IQ of 69 and was intellectually disabled, and that the execution of a mentally ill person was prohibited under international human rights law.

TITLE: U.N. takes step to put veto users under global spotlight
SUMMARY: For the first time, the General Assembly will be required "to hold a debate on the situation" that sparks a veto in the Security Council within 10 working days.

TITLE: Danica Roem did opposition research on herself. It's one way she reclaimed her story
SUMMARY: The Virginia lawmaker is the first openly transgender U.S. state legislator. In her new memoir, she embraces the idea of using what was written about her to empower her to tell her story.

TITLE: Can we trust rapid COVID tests against BA.2? This is what the experts say
SUMMARY: With the BA.2 subvariant of omicron pushing infection rates up, many are reaching for at-home rapid tests. Here's what experts say on how best to use them.

TITLE: Hit with $7,146 for two hospital bills, a family sought health care in Mexico
SUMMARY: A dad's COVID-19 and a mom's fainting spell cost thousands, so when their son dislocated his shoulder, they drove him to Mexicali, where facilities rival those in the U.S., and had him treated for $5.

TITLE: Lawyers call sheriff's remark about shooting home intruders as 'wildly irresponsible'
SUMMARY: Santa Rosa, Florida, Sheriff Bob Johnson says homeowners should take shooting lessons so they can ultimately "save the taxpayers money."

TITLE: Harvard releases report detailing its ties to slavery, plans to issue reparations
SUMMARY: A committee formed by Harvard President Lawrence Bacow found that Harvard faculty and staff enslaved 70 people from the school's founding in 1636 to the banning of slavery in Massachusetts in 1783.

TITLE: From CNN+ to Fyre Festival: This collector seeks swag from companies with epic ends
SUMMARY: Christina Warren collects T-shirts, mugs and other items from companies that promised huge changes, but failed to deliver — often in spectacular ways.

TITLE: Immigration advocates warn of midterm risks for Democrats if Title 42 isn't lifted
SUMMARY: With voter enthusiasm among Democrats already lagging going into the midterms, immigration advocates say they will dampen it more by not calling for the 2020 public health order to be lifted.

TITLE: Lawyers say sheriff's remark about shooting home intruders was 'wildly irresponsible'
SUMMARY: Santa Rosa, Florida, Sheriff Bob Johnson says homeowners should take shooting lessons so they can ultimately "save the taxpayers money."

TITLE: U.S. Marine veteran Trevor Reed is released from Russia in a prisoner swap
SUMMARY: Reed had been held in Russia since 2019. He was exchanged for pilot Konstantin Yaroshenko, who was serving a 20-year sentence for conspiring to import cocaine into the U.S.

TITLE: More than 120,000 pounds of ground beef is recalled over possible E. coli concerns
SUMMARY: There have been no confirmed reports of illnesses or adverse reactions related to consumption of the ground beef, which was shipped to stores nationwide, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said.

TITLE: Russia halts gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria, hitting back at Europe over sanctions
SUMMARY: The move was widely seen as an effort to prop up the ruble and strike back at Europe amid an onslaught of Western penalties levied against Russian banks.

TITLE: Oklahoma bans nonbinary gender identities on birth certificates
SUMMARY: Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt signed a bill explicitly prohibiting the use of nonbinary gender markers on state birth certificates, a ban experts say is the first of its kind in the nation.

TITLE: Here's why Dr. Fauci says the U.S. is 'out of the pandemic phase'
SUMMARY: Vaccinations and residual immunity are among the reasons, President Biden's chief medical adviser Dr. Anthony Fauci said Tuesday, as the number of deaths drop and hospitalizations rise only slightly.

TITLE: U.S. officials say more weapons will help Ukraine hand Russia a strategic defeat
SUMMARY: The White House is rushing more weapons to Ukraine to try to ensure "a strategic defeat" for Russia. Aims shifted partly because of Ukrainian battlefield successes with U.S. provided weapons.

TITLE: A Kansas lawmaker complains about sharing a bathroom with a trans colleague
SUMMARY: LGBTQ rights advocates call for state Rep. Cheryl Helmer to be formally censured after she publicly said she didn't want to share the women's restrooms at the Statehouse with a transgender colleague.

TITLE: U.S. war aims shift in Ukraine — and bring additional risks
SUMMARY: The U.S. now believes Ukraine can win, a significant change in thinking, and is rushing in weapons. This raises the risk of widening the conflict, analysts say, and may destabilize the global economy.

TITLE: Derek Chauvin appeals his conviction for George Floyd's murder
SUMMARY: A year after his conviction, the former Minneapolis police officer is asking a state court to send his case back to Hennepin County; order a new trial elsewhere; or order him to be resentenced.

TITLE: New York's top court rejects congressional maps drawn by Democrats
SUMMARY: The state's highest court rejected new maps widely seen as favoring Democrats. The court largely agreed with Republican voters who argued the district boundaries were unconstitutionally gerrymandered.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 27)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: The death rate for children has dropped dramatically. Yet there's cause for alarm
SUMMARY: A new report confirms a deep decrease in the world's childhood death rate. But it takes note of what the authors call an "astronomically high" rate of death after hospitalization.

TITLE: Drought triggers water restrictions for 6 million Southern California residents
SUMMARY: Outdoor watering will be restricted to one day a week in parts of Los Angeles, Ventura and San Bernardino counties.

TITLE: Facebook shrugs off fears it's losing users
SUMMARY: More people used Facebook in the first quarter than analysts expected, easing concerns about competition from TikTok.

TITLE: A version of Dorothy's dress from 'Oz' goes up for sale
SUMMARY: A version of the dress Judy Garland wore in <em>The Wizard of Oz

TITLE: A political reckoning in Sri Lanka as economic crisis grows
SUMMARY: The ongoing protests highlight the dramatic fall of Sri Lanka's most powerful political dynasty in decades to a family grasping to retain power.

TITLE: Employees at a Starbucks store in Minnesota become the first in the state to unionize
SUMMARY: Twenty Starbucks stores have now unionized. Around 220 Starbucks stores have sought elections, with more added every day.

TITLE: He's running to be Colombia's 1st left-wing president. Here's what he plans to do
SUMMARY: Colombian presidential candidate Gustavo Petro sits down with NPR and talks about his time in a guerrilla group and proposals to tackle poverty and climate change.

TITLE: DHS Secretary Mayorkas faces a partisan divide over Title 42 in Capitol Hill hearings
SUMMARY: Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas testifies today before the House Judiciary Committee where he's expected to face another heated round of questioning on Title 42.

TITLE: What Russia cutting off energy to Poland and Bulgaria means for the world
SUMMARY: It was seen as a way for Russia to prop up its currency and retaliate for Western sanctions, but it could cause global energy prices to spike. One analyst sees it as a warning to the rest of Europe.

TITLE: The masks, the CDC and the judge — a battle brewing since 1944
SUMMARY: Masks are now optional in many airports, subways and buses. But to understand why, you have to go back to 1944 when the Public Health Service Act was passed.

TITLE: Why this economy may be sturdier than it looks
SUMMARY: U.S. GDP growth likely slowed sharply in the first few months of the year, but the economy may be sturdier than it looks.

TITLE: LeVar Burton will receive a Lifetime Achievement Award at the new children's Emmys
SUMMARY: Reading Rainbow, a program dedicated to children's literacy, aired on PBS for 23 years. LeVar Burton has won 12 Daytime Emmys and a Peabody Award for his work on the show.

TITLE: Albuquerque police release footage of a school bus crash
SUMMARY: The crash occurred in February. The school bus was carrying 23 children at the time, according to police.

TITLE: Sen. Orrin Hatch's legacy tracks the GOP's evolution on health
SUMMARY: The man who forged successful alliances with Democratic health giants, such as Sen. Kennedy and Rep. Waxman, fell back on his deep conservative roots as opposition grew to the Affordable Care Act.

TITLE: Two Democratic progressives plot new ways to fight back against Republican gains
SUMMARY: Reps. Khanna and Raskin say Democrats should reclaim issues of patriotism, stay out of the political correctness business and improve their dialogue on racial divisions to reach out to all Americans.

TITLE: Moderna asks FDA to authorize first COVID-19 vaccine for very young children
SUMMARY: The company says a low-dose version of its vaccine triggers an immune response in children ages 6 months to less than 6 years equivalent to what has protected older children and adults.

TITLE: Biden asks Congress for $33 billion in aid for Ukraine as war drags on
SUMMARY: The amount is more than double the $14 billion in support authorized so far to respond to the Russian invasion, a senior administration officials told reporters Thursday.

TITLE: Not even water? And other things not to say to your Muslim friends during Ramadan
SUMMARY: Over 3.45 million Americans celebrate the Islamic holy month - here are a few tips to get you acquainted!

TITLE: Canada's House backs a motion recognizing Russia's actions in Ukraine as genocide
SUMMARY: The non-binding declaration doesn't require the Canadian government to take any action —  but the lawmaker who proposed it says she hopes it will have that effect.

TITLE: Disney says Florida would have to pay nearly $1 billion to dissolve special district
SUMMARY: The Walt Disney World complex's governing board says that when Florida created its special district, the state pledged not to alter that status unless all its debts are paid off.

TITLE: University of California will waive tuition and fees for many Native American students
SUMMARY: The program applies to undergraduate and graduate students who are members of federally recognized Native American, American Indian and Alaska Native tribes and will begin in the fall.

TITLE: Former U.S. Surgeon General Jerome Adams calls for masking 'compassion'
SUMMARY: The U.S. needs to ensure everyone has an equitable chance to protect themselves, and if people don't have that opportunity, they need to be able to rely on others to be compassionate, he says.

TITLE: What a U.N. team has seen while documenting possible war crimes in Ukraine
SUMMARY: "Unfortunately, the longer this conflict goes on, the more violations we're finding," says the head of a U.N. team documenting possible human rights abuses in Ukraine.

TITLE: How social-emotional learning became a target for Ron DeSantis and conservatives
SUMMARY: Florida officials recently rejected a slew of math textbooks, claiming they included "prohibited topics." Journalist Dana Goldstein theorizes the objections related to social-emotional learning.

TITLE: The FDA is proposing a ban on menthol cigarettes
SUMMARY: The agency says the proposal has the potential to significantly reduce disease and death from tobacco by "reducing youth experimentation and addiction."

TITLE: California is investigating Big Oil for allegedly misleading the public on recycling
SUMMARY: California's attorney general is investigating oil and gas companies for allegedly deceiving the public that most plastic can be recycled, citing NPR and PBS Frontline's investigation of the industry.

TITLE: Boston breaks ground on a Martin Luther King memorial of its own
SUMMARY: More than seven decades after the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. lived, studied and preached in Boston, the city will soon have a memorial honoring him and Coretta Scott King, who met each other there.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 28)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Anchor Sage Steele is suing ESPN over free speech claims
SUMMARY: Steele's lawyers accuse ESPN and Disney of violating her First Amendment rights and breaching her contract after she made comments on a podcast last September.

TITLE: Hollywood and tyrants: How filmmakers take on the powerful
SUMMARY: A look at how Hollywood has depicted authoritarians, from Duck Soup to The Last King of Scotland

TITLE: Your dog is a good boy, but that's not necessarily because of its breed
SUMMARY: A new study based on thousands of DNA sequences and owner surveys finds that less than 10% of a dog's behavior — like howling, herding or retrieving — can be explained by its breed.

TITLE: Italian children should not automatically receive their father's surname, court says
SUMMARY: Italy's Constitutional Court ruled that newborns that are automatically assigned the father's surname at birth is unconstitutional and damaging to a child's identity.

TITLE: U.S. soldiers 'return' cake to Italian woman for 90th birthday
SUMMARY: A woman was 13 years old when U.S. soldiers grabbed her birthday cake from a windowsill.

TITLE: This goat and lentil stew is a beloved Ramadan tradition in Hyderabad, India
SUMMARY: The Ramadan fast is usually followed by a feast. In Hyderabad, India, that feast is dominated by haleem, a meat and lentil stew pounded into paste and flavored with rose petals, cinnamon and cardamom.

TITLE: Oyster reefs in Texas are disappearing. Fishermen there fear their jobs will too
SUMMARY: Texas closed most public oyster reefs for harvesting, dealing a blow to the fishing industry. "It's taken a big toll on me," says Johny Jurisich, whose family has worked in the business for decades.

TITLE: Why many Missouri Republicans fear Eric Greitens could win the state's Senate primary
SUMMARY: Some Republicans worry that if the scandal-plagued former governor were to win the primary, it would place a Senate seat considered to be safely GOP in jeopardy.

TITLE: How the tobacco industry targeted Black Americans with menthol smokes
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration has announced plans to ban menthol cigarettes, which the tobacco industry has aggressively marketed toward African Americans since 1964.

TITLE: Rachel Levine calls state anti-LGBTQ bills disturbing and dangerous to trans youth
SUMMARY: The U.S. assistant secretary for health, who will speak at Texas Christian University, says physicians need to be more vocal in fighting politically motivated attacks on vulnerable trans youth.

TITLE: The education culture war is raging. But for most parents, it's background noise
SUMMARY: By wide margins, parents across the political spectrum are satisfied with how their children's schools teach about race, gender and history. That's according to a new national poll by NPR and Ipsos.

TITLE: Inside the world of process serving: Explaining what happened to Olivia Wilde
SUMMARY: Actor Jason Sudeikis says he never meant for his former fiancée to be served papers in front of thousands of spectators. But how did that happen? A process server explains the mechanics of the system.

TITLE: Michigan man faces hate crime charges after threatening BLM supporters, DOJ says
SUMMARY: The case is currently being investigated by the FBI and the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division is prosecuting the case.

TITLE: U.S. officials arrest British Virgin Islands premier on drug charges
SUMMARY: The premier, Andrew Fahie, was charged with conspiracy to import cocaine and conspiracy to launder money, according to a criminal complaint.

TITLE: Texas stumbles in its effort to punish green financial firms
SUMMARY: A new Texas law that penalizes financial institutions trying to go green is full of loopholes, and is straight up ignored. But other states are following Texas's punitive approach all the same.

TITLE: A partial solar eclipse is happening soon. Here's who will be able to see it
SUMMARY: During a partial solar eclipse, the moon is not perfectly aligned with the Earth and sun, so it will not completely cover the sun.

TITLE: 'Carpool Karaoke' king James Corden will leave his late-night show in 2023
SUMMARY: The British actor and writer announced his decision during the taping of Thursday's <em>The Late Late Show

TITLE: Republicans have the advantage with voters in 2022 elections, poll finds
SUMMARY: Of voters surveyed, 47% said they are more likely to vote for the Republican in their district, as opposed to 44% who said Democrats. The GOP is also favored on a raft of issues.

TITLE: Wimbledon champion Boris Becker gets 2 1/2 years in prison for bankruptcy offenses
SUMMARY: The 54-year-old German tennis great was sentenced for illicitly transferring large amounts of money and hiding assets after he was declared bankrupt.

TITLE: States sue the U.S. Postal Service over its decision to buy gas-powered trucks
SUMMARY: The lawsuits contend that purchases of thousands of fossil fuel-powered delivery vehicles will cause environmental harm for decades to come. The Postal Service says it conducted a thorough review.

TITLE: Why Russia's rocket attack on Kyiv is seen as an insult to the U.N.
SUMMARY: "It is a war zone but it is shocking that it happened close to us," Saviano Abreu, a spokesman for the U.N.'s humanitarian office, was quoted saying. The attack killed one person: a journalist.

TITLE: Russia sharpens warnings as the U.S. and Europe send more weapons to Ukraine
SUMMARY: Russian criticism of Western military aid to Ukraine is not new. But recent rhetoric reflects efforts to build public consensus for the need of a protracted — if not existential — war with the West.

TITLE: The first human case of avian flu in the U.S. is reported in Colorado
SUMMARY: The patient is an inmate involved in the culling of poultry that was presumptively infected with H5N1 bird flu at a commercial farm. The virus, while deadly for birds, poses a low risk to humans.

TITLE: A writer lost his singing voice, then discovered the gymnastics of speech
SUMMARY: John Colapinto developed a vocal polyp when he began "wailing" with a rock group without proper warmup. He talks about the frailty and feats of the human voice. <em>Originally broadcast Jan. 26, 2021.

TITLE: A Russian naval base is defended by dolphins. It's not as unusual as it sounds
SUMMARY: Citing satellite imagery, a submarine analyst says Russia's navy is deploying dolphins to defend a crucial base off Crimea. Russia and the U.S. have run marine mammal training programs for decades.

TITLE: A second Oath Keeper pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy in the Jan. 6 riot
SUMMARY: Brian Ulrich pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy and obstruction, and agreed to cooperate with government investigators.

TITLE: 19 cannons believed from the Revolutionary War are found in the Savannah River
SUMMARY: The mud- and rust-encrusted guns were discovered by accident as the Georgia riverbed was being dredged. Researchers suspect they came from British ships scuttled to the river bottom in 1779.

TITLE: Here are 3 reasons why stocks are tanking
SUMMARY: Stocks were pummeled on Friday with the Nasdaq slumping more than 4% to post its worst month since 2008. Why things have gotten so bad in Wall Street.

TITLE: The ACLU says Amber Heard has paid less than half of her $3.5 million donation pledge
SUMMARY: The actor made the pledge as she ended her marriage to Johnny Depp, saying she would split $7 million between the ACLU and a children's hospital. Depp's defamation case against Heard is ongoing.

TITLE: A winning $473M Powerball ticket was sold in Arizona. Here's what happens if you win
SUMMARY: The odds of winning the jackpot are 1 in 292.2 million. But it never hurts to be prepared.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 29)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Netflix promised secure jobs at Tudum. Now, one of its teams has been laid off
SUMMARY: Yesterday, Netflix laid off some of its staff, many of them recently hired women of color. They were working on its new fan-focused website.

TITLE: Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Trevor Bauer is suspended over sexual assault allegations
SUMMARY: Bauer is suspended for two seasons after a San Diego woman alleged that he beat and sexually abused her last year. He denies violating MLB's domestic violence and sexual assault policy.

TITLE: A former U.S. Marine was killed fighting in Ukraine, his family says
SUMMARY: An American citizen was killed while fighting alongside the Ukrainian military, according to his family. He is believed to be the first American to be killed while fighting in the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Netflix promised good jobs at Tudum. Now, one of its teams has been laid off
SUMMARY: Yesterday, Netflix laid off some of its staff, many of them recently hired women of color. They were working on its new fan-focused website.

TITLE: The L.A. Riots, 30 years later
SUMMARY: After Los Angeles exploded three decades ago, some things have changed and so much remains the same.

TITLE: When this Shanghai building went into COVID lockdown, my WeChat message group blew up
SUMMARY: For nine years, I lived in a giant apartment complex called the Summit with hundreds of other people in the city of Shanghai. Now my old neighbors are entering week six stuck inside.

TITLE: A new Iron Curtain is eroding Norway's hard-won ties with Russia on Arctic issues
SUMMARY: The countries share a border. Along the frontier, residents say a new barrier has disrupted everything from Arctic climate action and nuclear waste control to trade and cross-border sports leagues.

TITLE: Texas got a sex ed update, but students and educators say there's still a lot missing
SUMMARY: The last time Texas updated its sex education curriculum, was in the '90s. Students will now learn about contraception and STIs — but not gender or consent. And the classes are all optional.

TITLE: USC settles lawsuits with 80 men who say a former school doctor sexually abused them
SUMMARY: Attorneys for the alleged victims say the cases date back to as early as 1997, with the latest occurring in 2018. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

TITLE: We asked, you answered: Have you taught your children to run errands on their own?
SUMMARY: Nearly 100 NPR readers gave their views on encouraging kids to do tasks on their own at home and in the community. Some are opposed to the practice for safety reasons. Others shared personal stories.

TITLE: A suspected tornado in Kansas injured several people and damaged multiple buildings
SUMMARY: More than 6,500 people were left without power, and a fire chief said some homes were destroyed.

TITLE: A judge again upholds Ghislaine Maxwell's sex trafficking conviction
SUMMARY: Earlier this month, the judge refused to toss out her conviction after a juror disclosed during deliberations that he had been sexually abused as a child.

TITLE: Rape has reportedly become a weapon in Ukraine. Finding justice may be difficult
SUMMARY: Widespread allegations of rape at the hands of Russian soldiers have been coming out of Ukraine. Experts say rape in conflict is often used to pursue strategic aims.

TITLE: What is May Day? For the most part, the opposite of capitalism
SUMMARY: What springs to mind when you hear May Day? In the U.S. and abroad, the day has grown to encompass a spectrum of meanings. But the themes have remained the same: worker unity, suppression and rebirth.

TITLE: 'American Idol' winner Laine Hardy is accused of bugging an ex-girlfriend's dorm
SUMMARY: His ex allegedly found a listening device — which resembled a phone charger — under her futon, according to a warrant. Hardy faces a felony charge over the allegation.

TITLE: Ozzy Osbourne has been diagnosed with COVID-19
SUMMARY: Sharon Osbourne, who revealed the diagnosis, said she is taking off time from work to care for her 73-year-old husband, a rock music legend. "I am very worried about Ozzy right now," she said.

TITLE: British lawmaker Neil Parish to resign after watching porn in the House of Commons
SUMMARY: The member of Parliament says he watched pornography twice in the House of Commons in a "moment of madness." The Conservative Party suspended him Friday over the allegations.

TITLE: Airbnb will let its employees live and work anywhere
SUMMARY: Many people began working from Airbnbs during the pandemic. Now the company is shifting to a remote work model, allowing its employees to be located anywhere in the country they currently work in.

TITLE: McCarthy embodies House GOP's post-Trump dilemma and post-Gingrich history
SUMMARY: Shakespeare observed that "uneasy lies the head that wears a crown." Something similar seems to apply to the title of Republican leader in the U.S. House of Representatives.

TITLE: The LA Riots, 30 years later
SUMMARY: Since Los Angeles exploded three decades ago, some things have changed and so much remains the same.

TITLE: An Alabama prison official and the inmate she was escorting are missing
SUMMARY: Vicky White left a detention center with an inmate Friday morning and neither has been seen since. White was escorting the inmate, held on capital murder charges, to a courthouse for a hearing.

TITLE: British lawmaker Neil Parish resigning after watching porn in the House of Commons
SUMMARY: The member of Parliament says he watched pornography twice in the House of Commons in a "moment of madness." The Conservative Party suspended him Friday over the allegations.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (April 30)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Naomi Judd, country music matriarch of The Judds, is dead at 76
SUMMARY: Naomi Judd recorded and performed with daughter Wynonna. She was also the mother of actress Ashley Judd.

TITLE: Neal Adams, comic book legend and defender of artists' rights, dies at 80
SUMMARY: Neal Adams revolutionized the comic book industry with his hyper-realistic style for characters such as Batman, Superman, the Green Lantern and the X-Men.

TITLE: Bill Murray says his behavior led to a complaint and a pause on 'Being Mortal'
SUMMARY: In his first comments about the halt of his latest film, the actor described the incident as a difference of opinion. "I did something I thought was funny and it wasn't taken that way," he said.

TITLE: A tornado in Kansas injured several people and damaged multiple buildings
SUMMARY: In addition to wreckage from the tornado itself, three meteorology students traveling back from storm chasing in Kansas were killed in a crash. The twister knocked out power for over 15,000 people.

TITLE: Some Ukrainians evacuated from ruins of Mariupol steel plant
SUMMARY: Some women and children were evacuated from a steel plant that is the last defensive stronghold in the bombed-out ruins of the port city of Mariupol, but hundreds are believed to remain trapped.

TITLE: President Biden mocks Trump at White House Correspondents' Dinner
SUMMARY: Joe Biden addressed the White House Correspondents' Association dinner on Saturday night, the first time a president has spoken at the event in six years.

TITLE: Nancy Pelosi meets with Ukraine president Zelenskyy in Kyiv

SUMMARY: This averages out to about 10 such attacks a week.
