TITLE: After 329 years, a woman accused of being a witch in Salem has been exonerated
SUMMARY: Massachusetts lawmakers formally exonerated Elizabeth Johnson Jr., clearing her name three centuries after she was convicted of witchcraft in 1693 at the height of the Salem Witch Trials.

SUMMARY: The Deputy Attorney General told Congress last year that prosecutors would review new evidence about FBI failures in the investigation of Larry Nassar.

SUMMARY: The National Rifle Association begins its annual convention Friday, and its leaders are gearing up to "reflect on" — and deflect any blame for — the deadly shooting earlier this week in Uvalde, Texas.

TITLE: As her testimony ends, Amber Heard says she wants Johnny Depp to leave her alone

TITLE: 2 major league teams use their social media to raise awareness about gun violence

TITLE: A brokenhearted husband dies after his wife is killed in the Texas school shooting
SUMMARY: Joe Garcia had dropped off flowers at his wife's memorial on Thursday, The New York Times reported. He "pretty much just fell over" after returning home and died of a heart attack, his nephew said.

SUMMARY: The deadly fire comes a year after four other newborns died in a hospital fire in Senegal, a nation known for having some of the best hospitals in the region.

SUMMARY: Law enforcement is still investigating the shooting at Robb Elementary School. But accounts from officials have offered a confusing look at the timeline of Tuesday's shooting.

SUMMARY: These two tragedies share similarities, including certain aspects of the suspects and how the weapons were accessed.

TITLE: The real COVID surge is (much) bigger than it looks. But don't panic

TITLE: Political realties have stopped legislative action after school shootings

SUMMARY: The federal government plans to build several hydrogen hubs around the country. The goal is to find a cleaner replacement for fossil fuels. But there are challenges in how hydrogen is produced.

SUMMARY: The political climate has changed drastically since a 10-year assault weapons ban passed in 1994. The lack of political will and other barriers stand in the way of it even coming to a vote today.

TITLE: Do restrictive abortion laws actually reduce abortion? A global map offers insights
SUMMARY: Click to see how restrictive or liberal local abortion laws are — and to look at the rate of abortion. The data offers a sense of whether stricter abortion laws reduce the number of abortions.

SUMMARY: This isn't the first time the NRA has held its convention days after a nearby mass shooting. Some politicians and musicians are dropping out, and gun control advocates are preparing protests.

TITLE: 12 stats to help inform the gun control debate
SUMMARY: The debate over stricter gun control laws intensifies as details emerge from the Robb Elementary School shooting in Uvalde, Texas.

TITLE: Cómo hablar con los niños cuando las noticias dan miedo. Una guía bilingüe
SUMMARY: Cuando ocurren tiroteos u otras tragedias, ¿cómo podemos hablar con los niños sobre lo que ha pasado? Tenemos consejos de expertos sobre cómo apoyar emocionalmente a los pequeñitos.

TITLE: It was 'wrong' not to confront the Uvalde school shooter sooner, an official says
SUMMARY: "From the benefit of hindsight, where I'm sitting now, of course it was not the right decision. It was the wrong decision. Period," said Steven McCraw of the Texas Department of Public Safety.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (May 27)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott says he was 'misled' about the Uvalde shooting police response
SUMMARY: Abbott says the information that he provided at a press conference two days ago was a recitation of what law enforcement had told him in a room beforehand.

TITLE: Jurors in the Depp-Heard trial hear closing arguments and begin deliberations
SUMMARY: The seven-person civil jury began its deliberations at 3 p.m. Friday and finished for the day about two hours later. They will resume Tuesday.

TITLE: What some gun owners are saying in the wake of America's latest mass shooting
SUMMARY: The mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, has again raised the question "What should we do about gun violence?" NPR asked gun owners from across the U.S. about their stance.

TITLE: Senators are continuing talks during recess to find a compromise on gun legislation
SUMMARY: Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy says he's optimistic that something can be done to address mass shootings like the one at a Texas elementary school that killed 19 children.

TITLE: Like The Linda Lindas, this teen girl band in Benin makes you dance — and think
SUMMARY: The 7-member band hails from a conservative part of the country. They sing about female genital cutting, child marriage and gender equality. And they rock.

TITLE: What does a black hole sound like? NASA has an answer
SUMMARY: NASA began "sonifying" its famous photos of outer space to help people who are visually impaired enjoy the images. Recently, it recreated the sound of a black hole 240 million light-years away.

TITLE: Ethiopia set a world record for displacements in a single year: 5.1 million in 2021
SUMMARY: The war there is responsible — and makes it difficult just to assess the scale of displacement. Details are in a new report from the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre.

TITLE: Teachers, how are you coping in the aftermath of the Texas shooting in Uvalde?
SUMMARY: NPR would like to hear from teachers around the country about how they are feeling in the aftermath of the latest school shooting. We may contact you for an upcoming story.

TITLE: As a jury weighs if a lawyer lied to the FBI, Durham's legacy hangs in the balance
SUMMARY: Michael Sussmann faces one charge of lying to the FBI ahead of the 2016 presidential election. It's the first courtroom test for special counsel John Durham, appointed by the Trump administration.

TITLE: The U.S is uniquely terrible at protecting children from gun violence
SUMMARY: The massacre in Uvalde, Texas, was yet another grim reminder that in the U.S., children are more likely to die from gun violence than in any other wealthy nation. And it's getting worse.

TITLE: Asian founders work to steer the narrative as beauty trends pull from their cultures
SUMMARY: The latest obsessions in America's wellness craze are rooted in South Asian practices. Industry leaders who grew up with those rituals are caught between joy and a battle against cultural erasure.

TITLE: The Uvalde shooting renews questions about school security
SUMMARY: Texas has tightened security at schools considerably over the past four years. But the new protective measures came up short earlier this week in Uvalde.

TITLE: Russia says it has test-fired another hypersonic missile
SUMMARY: The Russian navy on Saturday conducted another test of a prospective hypersonic missile, a demonstration of the military's long-range strike capability amid the fighting in Ukraine.

TITLE: More baby formula shipments arrive from overseas in an effort to ease the shortage
SUMMARY: Australia is sending the equivalent of more than 27 million 8-ounce bottles of goat's milk and other baby formulas, as the U.S. government works to replenish store shelves during the shortage.

TITLE: The U.S. is uniquely terrible at protecting children from gun violence
SUMMARY: The massacre in Uvalde, Texas, was yet another grim reminder that in the U.S., children are more likely to die from gun violence than in any other wealthy nation. And it's getting worse.

TITLE: Ukrainians say they're badly outgunned by Russia in the battle for the Donbas
SUMMARY: While many Ukrainians are still basking in the successful defense of Kyiv, the battle in the Donbas is a punishing grind that poses different challenges.

TITLE: Harris calls for unity as Buffalo lays the last shooting victim to rest
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris spoke during the memorial service for Ruth Whitfield, the last of 10 Black people killed in a racist attack at a Buffalo supermarket to be laid to rest.

TITLE: UN human rights chief asks China to rethink Uyghur policies
SUMMARY: The top U.N. human rights official said Saturday that she raised concerns with Chinese officials about the impact of measures on the rights of Uyghurs in China's Xinjiang region.

TITLE: 'Triangle of Sadness' wins Palme d'Or at Cannes Film Fest
SUMMARY: Swedish director Ruben Ostlund's class warfare comedy "Triangle of Sadness" won the Palme d'Or at the 75th Cannes Film Festival, giving Ostlund the prize for the second time.

TITLE: In Uvalde, tragedy brings a community together
SUMMARY: Two women in Uvalde are spearheading an effort to soothe their community with food. Because Uvalde's resident's lives are so intertwined, everyone knows someone affected by the massacre.

TITLE: Champions League final marred by delays and use of tear gas on fans
SUMMARY: The soccer Champions League final in Paris was marred as Liverpool fans were sprayed with tear gas as they tried to enter the stadium, delaying the start of the match by 35 minutes.

TITLE: Children among 31 killed at church fair stampede in Nigeria
SUMMARY: A stampede Saturday at a church charity event in southern Nigeria left 31 people dead and seven injured at a program that aimed to offer hope to the needy.

TITLE: Unrest erupts at Jerusalem site ahead of nationalist march
SUMMARY: Jewish pilgrims visited early Sunday ahead of a nationalist parade through the Old City, prompting Palestinians to throw rocks and fireworks.

TITLE: In Uvalde, tragedy and food bring a community together
SUMMARY: Two women in Uvalde are spearheading an effort to soothe their community with food. Because Uvalde's resident's lives are so intertwined, everyone knows someone affected by the massacre.

TITLE: A former pastor grieves the loss of his great-granddaughter in Uvalde
SUMMARY: Julián Moreno is the retired pastor of a Baptist church in Uvalde. Members of the congregation gathered to remember his great-granddaugher and another girl who was killed in the shooting.

TITLE: How a Facebook page for Irish setter lovers helped Ukrainians flee with their dogs
SUMMARY: A Russian woman living in Burgundy wanted to help pet dogs of Ukraine and their human companions get to safety. She turned to a Facebook group for lovers of a famous dog breed to find them.

TITLE: U.S. House loses more 'swing' in 2022
SUMMARY: Only a small fraction of U.S. House seats are now considered "swing" seats that could be won by either party.

TITLE: Voices from Uvalde: How a community mourns and comprehends 21 lives lost
SUMMARY: Here's how community members in Uvalde are remembering, processing and reflecting  —  in their own words.

TITLE: The Justice Department says it will review the police response in Uvalde
SUMMARY: The department announced it would conduct a review of the  response to the Uvalde shooting at the request of the city's mayor, Don McLaughlin.

TITLE: The front pages of Uvalde's local paper capture darkness and the lives lost
SUMMARY: The independent paper published the faces of the victims on Sunday in a powerful homage to the 21 lives lost.

TITLE: Uvalde shooting survivors seek comfort anywhere, including in the arms of bikers
SUMMARY: Nine-year-old Aubriella Melchor said

TITLE: Biden visits Uvalde, as DOJ announces review of how police responded to the attack
SUMMARY: As President Biden visited Uvalde on Sunday, federal officials said they would investigate how law enforcement responded to the massacre that left 19 fourth-grade students and two teachers dead.

TITLE: Ahead of this week's EU summit, France and Germany urge Putin to meet Zelenskyy
SUMMARY: The EU will meet Monday to discuss how to handle the ongoing conflict as Russia intensifies its efforts to capture Severodonetsk, the largest eastern city that remains in Ukrainian hands.

TITLE: Biden visits Uvalde as DOJ announces review of how police responded to the attack
SUMMARY: As President Biden visited Uvalde on Sunday, federal officials said they would investigate how law enforcement responded to the massacre that left 19 fourth-grade students and two teachers dead.

TITLE: Days after the Uvalde shooting, the NRA convention went on as planned
SUMMARY: Thousands gathered inside of the George R. Brown Convention Center in Houston for the NRA convention while swaths of others convened outside in protest, advocating for gun control legislation.

TITLE: After Uvalde, mass shootings continue over the weekend across the U.S.
SUMMARY: At least eight people were killed and another 45 wounded in mass shootings across the United States since Wednesday.

TITLE: A leftist will face a businessman as Colombia's presidential race heads to a runoff
SUMMARY: The results represent a major shift in the Latin American country's presidential politics that conservatives and moderates had long dominated.

TITLE: U.N. human rights chief asks China to rethink Uyghur policies
SUMMARY: The top U.N. human rights official said Saturday that she raised concerns with Chinese officials about the impact of measures on the rights of Uyghurs in China's Xinjiang region.

TITLE: China falls short on big deal in South Pacific but finds smaller wins
SUMMARY: Beijing's hopes to developing a marine plan for fisheries holding police training fell short over some countries' concerns over increasing geopolitical tensions and threatening regional stability.

TITLE: A plane carrying 22 passengers was found crashed on a mountain in central Nepal
SUMMARY: Photos of the crash, released by the army, show the plane's parts scattered across a mountainside.

TITLE: 1 billion pills: The number of seized drugs reaches ominous record in Asia
SUMMARY: A U.N. official calls for new policies across East Asia to halt the soaring production of methamphetamines.

TITLE: Jamie was lost in LA and his anxiety was growing. Then a stranger stepped in
SUMMARY: Jamie Spurway left his hometown in Scotland for a semester abroad in California in 1998. When he got there he had trouble getting to his final destination until a friendly stranger offered him help.

TITLE: 'My heart is in Arlington': What Memorial Day means to one Gold Star family
SUMMARY: Vikki and Mark Pier used to regularly travel to Arlington National Cemetery to visit their son's final resting place. But due to health issues, they have been unable to visit for the past four years.

TITLE: The baby formula shortage is prompting calls to increase support for breastfeeding
SUMMARY: As parents scramble to find scarce baby formula and the government races to boost production and imports, some advocates say the U.S. should do more to encourage breastfeeding.

TITLE: Students protest against a Seattle university's ban on hiring LGBTQ employees
SUMMARY: Seattle Pacific University Board of Trustees Chair Cedric Davis says the trustees made their decision based on what they believed was most in line with the college's mission, according to a statement.

TITLE: Schools around the U.S. increase security after the Uvalde shooting
SUMMARY: In the aftermath of the elementary school massacre in Uvalde, Texas, schools around the U.S. have brought in additional security staff and restricted visitors as they deal with copycat threats.

TITLE: Pelosi's husband was arrested on suspicion of DUI in California
SUMMARY: The 82-year-old husband of U.S. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi was taken into custody late Saturday in Napa County north of San Francisco, according to a sheriff's office online booking report.

TITLE: The FDA is investigating a hepatitis A outbreak potentially linked to strawberries
SUMMARY: The FDA is investigating a hepatitis A outbreak potentially linked to strawberries sold at a number of retailers, including Trader Joe's, Kroger, Safeway, Aldi and Walmart.

TITLE: A man in a wig was detained after throwing a piece of cake at the Mona Lisa
SUMMARY: A man who was apparently disguised as an old woman in a wheelchair was detained after throwing a piece of cake at the Mona Lisa.

TITLE: There's a chance of a meteor shower Monday night
SUMMARY: Those in North America have the best shot at seeing the shower at about 1 a.m. on the East Coast or 10 p.m. on the West Coast.

TITLE: More than $2.7 million has been raised for the children of a Uvalde teacher
SUMMARY: Irma Garcia was one of two teachers killed at Robb Elementary last week. Then, two days later, her husband of 24 years died of a heart attack, leaving their four children without parents.

TITLE: EU leaders agree on a partial Russian oil embargo
SUMMARY: The watered-down embargo covers only Russian oil brought in by sea, allowing a temporary exemption for imports delivered by pipeline.

TITLE: Canada's new bill would freeze handgun sales and imports
SUMMARY: The government said the bill would also allow for the removal of gun licenses from people involved in acts of domestic violence or criminal harassment, such as stalking.

TITLE: Indian rapper Sidhu Moose Wala was shot dead at 28
SUMMARY: Shubhdeep Singh Sidhu, also known around the world by his stage name Sidhu Moose Wala, was killed Sunday evening while driving his car in Mansa, a district in northern India's Punjab state.

TITLE: Canada to cap the market for handguns with new legislation
SUMMARY: The regulations to halt the growth of personally owned handguns is expected to be enacted this fall.

TITLE: EU leaders agree to ban 90% of Russian oil by the end of 2022
SUMMARY: The embargo covers Russian oil brought in by sea, allowing a temporary exemption for imports delivered by pipeline, a crucial move to bring Hungary on board a decision that required consensus.

TITLE: A $2 million relic was stolen and an angel statue was beheaded at a Brooklyn church
SUMMARY: The incident happened between 6:30 p.m. Thursday and 4 p.m. Saturday at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, known as the "Notre Dame" of Brooklyn's Park Slope neighborhood.

TITLE: Medical respite offers refuge for homeless people recovering from illness
SUMMARY: A growing number of private insurance companies are starting to invest in medical respite — a decades-old way of caring for homeless people. Here's what's driving the trend.

TITLE: Shanghai eases into gradually reopening from its COVID-19 lockdown
SUMMARY: China's largest city and global financial hub plans to restore mass transit and gradually reopen schools

TITLE: Cancer screenings like colonoscopies are supposed to be free. Hers cost $2,185
SUMMARY: Preventive care, like screening colonoscopies, is supposed to be free of charge to patients under the Affordable Care Act. But some hospitals haven't gotten the memo.

TITLE: Progressives take a leaf out of the conservative playbook to target school boards
SUMMARY: There has been a groundswell of conservative enthusiasm around school politics in the last few years. Progressives are hoping to have their own source of organization to counter that enthusiasm.

TITLE: Neighboring florists step in to help provide flowers for Uvalde funerals
SUMMARY: A local florist says she's putting aside sunflowers for one of the victims, the daughter of one of her high school classmates. "Their baby's favorite was sunflowers," Kelly Baker said.

TITLE: Denmark will hold a referendum on EU defense amid Ukraine war
SUMMARY: Danish voters are being asked to choose whether to abandon the country's decision three decades ago to opt out of the bloc's common defense policy.

TITLE: Five things to know about one of the deadliest federal prisons
SUMMARY: Federal prisoners said to be the most dangerous are sent to a special unit at a prison in Illinois. NPR and the Marshall Project uncovered violence, abuse and deaths there. Here are five takeaways.

TITLE: How the newest federal prison became one of the deadliest
SUMMARY: Federal prisoners said to be the most dangerous are sent to a special unit at an Illinois penitentiary. NPR and The Marshall Project have uncovered violence, abuse and a string of inmate deaths there.

TITLE: Self-defense classes help Asian and Pacific Islander women feel safer in New York
SUMMARY: The classes are taught by Jess Ng, a Muay Thai fighter who grew up in Queens. Ng decided to start the classes when Asian women at a recent community event indicated they feel endangered when outside.

TITLE: VIDEO: Amid the rise in anti-Asian hate, these pairs feel safer walking together
SUMMARY: In response to an increase in violence against people of Asian descent, some people have started regularly walking with loved ones due to safety concerns. Watch our latest NPR short documentary.

TITLE: Arizona Cardinals player Jeff Gladney has been killed in a car crash at age 25
SUMMARY: Gladney played for Texas Christian University before being selected as a first-round NFL draft pick for the Minnesota Vikings in 2020.

TITLE: Canada's government moves to make selling or importing handguns illegal
SUMMARY: The laws to freeze Canada's total number of handguns likely will be enacted this fall. Other new rules strengthen "red flag" laws and require all rifles be modified to hold no more than five rounds.

TITLE: Australia's new prime minister appoints a record 10 women to his Cabinet
SUMMARY: Australia's new government will look more like its country, as Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has named 10 women to his incoming Cabinet.

TITLE: The EU will block most Russian oil imports as Hungary's Orbán fights off a total ban
SUMMARY: Pipeline deliveries, which are critical to Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic, won't be affected by the ban. The much more complicated issue of Russian natural gas remains unresolved.

TITLE: In two photos, see how Bucha is erasing the scars of Russia's invasion
SUMMARY: First came the battle for Bucha. Now there's the battle to rebuild Bucha. This town was a scene of devastation in the early days of the war. Today you hear pounding hammers and screeching buzzsaws.

TITLE: A Uvalde coroner is haunted by identifying the bodies of children and an old friend
SUMMARY: Because Uvalde is so small, a local Justice of the Peace had the horrible task of identifying slain kids after the deadly shooting at Robb Elementary School. He says the images will stick with him.

TITLE: DeLorean is back (to the future) with an electric car, and some caveats
SUMMARY: The DeLorean Motor Company — the latest corporate iteration of the brand and not the creator behind the iconic 1980s model — is previewing an electric vehicle that will debut at a car show in August.

TITLE: A tabernacle was stolen and an angel statue was beheaded at a Brooklyn church
SUMMARY: The incident happened between 6:30 p.m. Thursday and 4 p.m. Saturday at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, known as the "Notre Dame" of Brooklyn's Park Slope neighborhood.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (May 31)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: These Belarusians join the fight against Russia, defying their Moscow-backed regime
SUMMARY: Belarusians who see their country's fate as linked to Ukraine's victory are joining an anti-Kremlin resistance that includes activists, ex-spies and a Belarusian brigade fighting for Ukraine.

TITLE: Supreme Court blocks Texas social media law from taking effect
SUMMARY: In a 5-to-4 vote, the court granted a request from Big Tech industry trade groups, which argued the law would unleash a flood of racist, hateful and other extremist content on social media platforms.

TITLE: Uvalde locals grapple with the school police chief's role
SUMMARY: Uvalde residents struggle to reconcile what they know of the well-liked lawman, Pete Arredondo.

TITLE: Texas authorities say a teacher closed a propped-open door before the attack
SUMMARY: Police initially said the gunman entered through a door that was propped open by a teacher. Now they say the teacher had actually shut the door, but it didn't lock.

TITLE: Canceled flights over Memorial Day weekend offer travelers a peek of the summer
SUMMARY: U.S. airlines canceled more than 2,800 flights from Thursday through Monday, or about 2% of their schedules, according to tracking service FlightAware.

TITLE: The National Spelling Bee returns to its usual venue for the first time in 3 years
SUMMARY: Spellers were greeted with a new preliminary-round format that gave them no time to get comfortable. They had to get through three words in one turn at the microphone to continue in the bee.

TITLE: DOJ asks federal appeals court to reverse order lifting travel mask mandate
SUMMARY: The Justice Department argues that the order issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in early 2021 "falls easily within the CDC's statutory authority."

TITLE: A Spotify publisher was down Monday night. The culprit? A lapsed security certificate
SUMMARY: Megaphone, the podcast advertising and publishing platform, experienced an expired security certificate Monday, a Spotify spokesperson said.

TITLE: Girl Scout posthumously honors 10-year-old Uvalde victim for heroism
SUMMARY: The honor was presented to Amerie Jo Garza's family. The organization additionally gave a presentation of colors at Amerie's funeral Tuesday, it said.

TITLE: Traveling this summer? Here are book picks for all 50 states (and then some)
SUMMARY: Poets laureate and other literary luminaries from all 50 states plus D.C. and Puerto Rico recommend quintessential reads that illuminate where they live.

TITLE: Should Robb Elementary be rebuilt? Here's what other school shooting sites did
SUMMARY: In Newtown, Conn., a new Sandy Hook Elementary opened in 2016, four years after the shooting there. In other places, some have said that leaving buildings in place can offer survivors a way to heal.

TITLE: In Uvalde, a woman in clown colors makes kids smile
SUMMARY: A few yards from the central memorial for the shooting victims, a clown hands out snow cones and toys for free to all. She says it's her way to give back — and she wants the gun violence to stop.

TITLE: 3 years after being leveled by Hurricane Michael, Mexico Beach is coming back
SUMMARY: The high cost of rebuilding drove some residents out. But there are many newcomers. A real estate agent says, "It used to be called the Forgotten Coast. I don't think it's so forgotten anymore."

TITLE: Sex Pistols aim to give Queen Elizabeth's jubilee a touch of punk
SUMMARY: A certain anti-authoritarian anthem linked to the punk rock pioneers and the British monarch, is being re-released as Queen Elizabeth II celebrates her platinum jubilee.

TITLE: In Britain, it took just one school shooting to pass major gun control
SUMMARY: After the Dunblane massacre in Scotland left 16 students dead, parents organized to make sure it could never happen again. What can the U.S learn from them as we struggle to combat gun violence?

TITLE: Tribal leaders sound the alarm after fentanyl overdoses spike at Blackfeet Nation
SUMMARY: After 17 overdoses — including four deaths — this spring, Indigenous leaders in Montana and surrounding states look for ways to stop the fentanyl crisis and provide more treatment and care.

TITLE: Philly's Pride March returns this week with new organizers and focus
SUMMARY: A new group of mostly Black and brown LGBTQ organizers are throwing the Pride March in Philadelphia on June 5, trying to rebuild the event into something more welcoming — and more revolutionary.

TITLE: The U.S. is sending long-range rockets to Ukraine
SUMMARY: President Biden said in a guest essay in <em>The New York Times

TITLE: Girl Scouts posthumously honor a 10-year-old Uvalde victim for heroism
SUMMARY: The honor was presented to Amerie Jo Garza's family. The organization additionally gave a presentation of colors at Amerie's funeral Tuesday, it said.

TITLE: A bison gored a woman who got too close to it in Yellowstone National Park
SUMMARY: The 25-year-old Ohio woman got within 10 feet of the bison before the animal gored her and tossed her 10 feet into the air. She sustained a puncture wound and other injuries.

TITLE: Abortion bans with no exceptions may be politically risky
SUMMARY: Some conservative states pressing for abortion bans with no exceptions for rape, incest or the life of the mother. But public opinion polls suggest those limits could cause blowback.

TITLE: To fight the opioid crisis, Canada tests decriminalizing possession
SUMMARY: Overdose deaths have risen sharply across Canada in the past five years, with deaths linked to fentanyl doubling. Officials hope decriminalization will make more users willing to seek medical care.

TITLE: The story about how the Uvalde gunman entered the school is shifting
SUMMARY: Texas officials had said a teacher propped door open at Robb Elementary just before a gunman entered and carried out a mass shooting — but they now acknowledge that the woman closed the door.

TITLE: The U.S. is sending advanced rocket systems to Ukraine, but not to be shot into Russia
SUMMARY: President Biden said in a guest essay in <em>The New York Times

TITLE: Investigators say the Uvalde school district police chief isn't talking to them
SUMMARY: Pete Arredondo and his department have been under new scrutiny since DPS Director Steven McCraw said the incident commander — later confirmed to be Arredondo — made a critical error.

TITLE: No more Elvis-themed weddings for Las Vegas chapels, a licensing company says
SUMMARY: The company that controls the name and image of Elvis Presley is ordering Sin City chapel operators to stop using "The King" in themed ceremonies. Some say the move could decimate their businesses.

TITLE: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says she was wrong about the risks of inflation
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen tells CNN she was wrong about the trajectory of inflation during interviews a year ago.

TITLE: A victim of the Brooklyn subway shooting is suing the gun maker Glock
SUMMARY: Ilene Steur, who was one of 10 people injured in the April attack, says in the lawsuit that Glock's marketing practices made it possible for the shooting suspect to buy one of the company's guns.

TITLE: Short-term profits and long-term consequences — did Jack Welch break capitalism?
SUMMARY: The General Electric CEO wowed investors and mingled with celebrities. But <em>New York Times

TITLE: This secretive network helps Ukrainian refugees find abortions in Europe
SUMMARY: Ukraine has very liberal abortion laws. In Poland, it is almost entirely illegal. Millions of Ukrainians discovered this when they fled the war in their home country and crossed the Polish border.

TITLE: Depp-Heard jury has reached a verdict in multimillion-dollar libel case
SUMMARY: Johnny Depp sued Amber Heard over a 2018 op-ed she wrote about abuse against women. It didn't mention Depp by name.

TITLE: Buffalo shooting suspect is charged with domestic terrorism
SUMMARY: The suspect is charged with domestic terrorism motivated by hate and 10 counts of first-degree murder.

TITLE: In surprise move, Sheryl Sandberg leaves Facebook after 14 years
SUMMARY: Over a 14 year career at Facebook, Sandberg was a pivotal figure in helping the social network become one of the most dominant social media platforms in the world.

TITLE: The Biden administration has announced new funding to help food supply chains
SUMMARY: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack on Wednesday unveiled $2 billion in new funding to strengthen food supply chains hard hit by the pandemic.

TITLE: A rare visit by Pakistanis to Israel has caused furor in Islamabad
SUMMARY: Pakistan doesn't recognize Israel. After a delegation visited Israel and even met with its president, Pakistani senators were outraged and one visitor got fired.

TITLE: Jury awards Depp $15M in defamation case against Heard and also awards her $2M
SUMMARY: Johnny Depp had sued Amber Heard for $50 million over a 2018 op-ed she wrote about abuse against women. The jury also awarded Heard $2 million in damages in her countersuit.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (June 1)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: How did your opinion about abortion change as a result of a particular experience?
SUMMARY: NPR's Morning Edition would like to know if you have had an experience that changed your mind regarding abortion.

TITLE: Buffalo shooting suspect is indicted on a domestic terrorism charge
SUMMARY: The suspect is charged with domestic terrorism motivated by hate and 10 counts of first-degree murder.

TITLE: Depp is awarded more than $10M in defamation case against Heard and she gets $2M
SUMMARY: Johnny Depp had sued Amber Heard for more than $50 million over a 2018 op-ed she wrote about abuse against women. Because of a limit set by state law, Depp's award will be $10.35 million.

TITLE: How can California provide reparations? A new report suggests several ways
SUMMARY: The report recommends ways to address the "lingering negative effects" of slavery — from policing reforms to housing grants to increased voting access to free tuition.

TITLE: Mourners say goodbye to a Uvalde teacher and her husband
SUMMARY: Mourners gathered Wednesday at a funeral for teacher Irma Garcia — who died in the shooting at Robb Elementary School — and her husband, Joe — who died two days later from a heart attack.

TITLE: GOP lawsuit halts most migration from Mexico. Yet, desperate people continue to cross
SUMMARY: A Tucson, Ariz. shelter for migrant asylum seekers crossing into the US is seeing record capacity, despite a federal judge's order upholding Trump-era public health border restrictions.

TITLE: 4 people dead at Okla. medical building, in the 233rd mass shooting of 2022
SUMMARY: Tulsa police Capt. Richard Meulenberg says multiple people were wounded and that "some unfortunately were killed."

TITLE: Elon Musk tells employees to return to the office 40 hours a week — or quit
SUMMARY: In leaked emails reported by Electrek, Musk says he will review and directly approve any requests for employees who wish to be exempt from the company's return-to-work policy.

TITLE: 5 people dead at Tulsa medical building, in the 233rd mass shooting of 2022
SUMMARY: "Four innocents and one shooter" are dead, says Jonathan Brooks of the Tulsa police department at a news conference on Wednesday.

TITLE: California cracks down on water use as it sees its most severe drought ever
SUMMARY: Water departments had the option to choose between an outdoor watering limit of one day per week or by volume of water used.

TITLE: California lawmakers ramp up efforts to become a sanctuary state for abortion rights
SUMMARY: California lawmakers are considering 13 bills that would expand access to abortion and welcome women from states where abortion is being banned or restricted.

TITLE: Abortion rights might soon be gone. Activists worry same-sex marriage is next
SUMMARY: Jim Obergefell was the named plaintiff in the Supreme Court case that legalized same-sex marriage in 2015. He says if <em>Roe v. Wade

TITLE: If Roe v. Wade is overturned, what happens next? Your questions answered
SUMMARY: After the leak of the draft opinion in which the Supreme Court appears ready to overturn <em>Roe

TITLE: As senators seek common ground on guns, 'red flag' laws become a focus
SUMMARY: Early negotiations have found bipartisan support for incentivizing states to pass laws that let authorities seize guns from individuals found to be a danger to themselves or others.

TITLE: Former Estonian president speaks about the war in Ukraine and the way forward
SUMMARY: Former Estonian President Toomas Hendrik Ilves wasn't surprised Russia invaded Ukraine. In an interview on his family's farm, he says he hopes the world is waking up to the dangers Russia poses.

TITLE: U.S. will forgive $5.8 billion of loans to Corinthian Colleges students
SUMMARY: Students affected do not have to take any further action to secure their funds, and the Department of Education will begin notifying those students soon, the agency said.

TITLE: Nightclub needle attacks puzzle authorities across Europe
SUMMARY: Targeted individuals in France, the U.K., Belgium and the Netherlands and who are mostly women, show visible marks of injection, often bruises, and report symptoms like feeling groggy.

TITLE: Some Ukrainian refugees find new homes in Maine with help from a fellow expat
SUMMARY: Without help from a resettlement agency, many Ukrainians rely on family or volunteers. Oleg Opalnyk, who has lived in Maine since 2001 and owns rental property, is supporting 11 Ukrainian evacuees.

TITLE: Demand at food banks is way up again. But inflation makes it harder to meet the need
SUMMARY: High food and gas prices are squeezing working families, sending some to food pantries for the first time. But providers are struggling with high costs, fewer donations and supply chain woes.

TITLE: Volodymyr vs. Vladimir: How rival statues explain the Russia-Ukraine conflict
SUMMARY: Ukrainians call a legendary 10th-century ruler Volodymyr the Great. Russians call him Vladimir the Great. NPR correspondents report on dueling statues - and historical narratives - in Kyiv and Moscow.

TITLE: Michigan prisons ban Spanish and Swahili dictionaries to prevent inmate disruptions
SUMMARY: Spanish and Swahili dictionaries are banned in Michigan prisons. An official says the ban is to prevent prisoners from being disruptive.

TITLE: OPINION: Media coverage of monkeypox paints it as an African virus. That makes me mad
SUMMARY: Dr. Ifeanyi Nsofor is a physician in Nigeria, which has seen a monkeypox outbreak over the past few years. He does not like the way the media is covering the current outbreak in Western countries.

SUMMARY: In the Dallas Cowboys' record books, only three players have scored more than Barber's 47 rushing touchdowns. But he faced severe struggles after his playing days.

SUMMARY: John Hinckley Jr., who shot President Ronald Reagan in 1981, is saying thank you to the people who helped him win freedom from court oversight.

TITLE: Turkey will now be known as Türkiye (at least at the U.N.)
SUMMARY: Turkey's rebranding campaign, which began in December, is characterized as an effort to better represent its culture abroad. It also distances the country from some less-flattering associations.

SUMMARY: The shooter had complained multiple times about pain following back surgery and sought additional treatment days before the attack, which left five people dead, including the gunman, police said.

SUMMARY: The move comes months after Russia's Kamila Valieva, then 15, was caught in a storm of controversy at the Beijing Winter Olympics.

TITLE: The U.S. is hosting the Summit of Americas for the first time since 1994
SUMMARY: President Biden is hosting Latin American leaders in Los Angeles this week. The Summit of the Americas is drawing attention to the weakened influence the administration wields in the region.

TITLE: In California, Newsom runs for reelection 9 months after defeating a recall attempt
SUMMARY: In 2021, the GOP forced Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom into a recall election. After a decisive victory, he's seeking another four years in office while facing high inflation and chronic homelessness.

TITLE: A British writer and a Brazil Indigenous official are missing in the Amazon
SUMMARY: Dom Phillips, who has been a regular contributor to the British newspaper the Guardian, and Bruno Araújo Pereira were last seen early Sunday.

TITLE: Three Arizona police officers are placed on leave after looking on as a man drowned
SUMMARY: Sean Bickings, 34, drowned after beginning to swim in Tempe Town Lake. Officers watched from the shore as Bickings struggled in the water.

TITLE: With Cubans leaving en masse, much of Cuba's real estate is up for sale
SUMMARY: Cubans are fleeing because of a steep economic downturn. Immigration is a big issue as leaders meet at this week's Summit of the Americas — but communist-controlled Cuba isn't invited.

TITLE: 1985 hit 'Running Up That Hill' sprints up the charts, thanks to 'Stranger Things'
SUMMARY: Kate Bush's song <em>Running Up That Hill

TITLE: Inflation is raising prices on almost everything, except rotisserie chicken
SUMMARY: Prices at grocery stores are going up, up, up. But there's one item you can still grab at a bargain basement price: rotisserie chicken.

TITLE: A mother is arrested after police say her 2-year-old shot her husband
SUMMARY: Investigators had initially suspected a death by suicide in the east Orlando, Fla., case. Then a five-year-old said his brother had shot his dad.

TITLE: Remembering Dave Smith, inventor of MIDI and the Prophet-5 synthesizer
SUMMARY: Dave Smith, a pioneer of the synthesizer, revolutionized pop music in the 1980s. David Bowie and Madonna are among the legions who used his Prophet 5 synthesizer. Smith died last week at age 72.

TITLE: This experimental drug could change the field of cancer research
SUMMARY: A small trial using the drug dostarlimab yielded an unprecedented success rate in eliminating tumors.

TITLE: Advisers to the FDA back Novavax COVID vaccine
SUMMARY: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration overwhelmingly voted to recommend that it authorize Novavax's two-dose vaccine against COVID-19.

TITLE: #SwedenGate sparks food fight: Why some countries share meals more than others
SUMMARY: A Reddit user claimed that while visiting a friend's house in Sweden, he had to sit in another room while the family ate dinner. The story ignited a conversation about how the rest of the world eats.

TITLE: Senate gun law negotiators working toward a deal by the end of the week
SUMMARY: Negotiations have narrowed proposals to address school safety, standards for safe gun storage, federal support for mental health programs and incentives for states to create red flag laws.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (June 7)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: A big 32-hour workweek test is underway. Supporters think it could help productivity
SUMMARY: A pilot of more than 3,300 workers in the U.K. is testing a theory about work. Can people in various industries remain as productive if they just work 32 hours a week with the same pay as 40 hours?

TITLE: The story of a Uvalde victim's green shoes captures the White House's attention
SUMMARY: Maite Rodriguez, a lover of animals and the environment, dreamed of being a marine biologist. She was killed during the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.

TITLE: FBI seizes retired general's data related to Qatar lobbying
SUMMARY: The seizure of data from the former leader of U.S. and NATO forces in Afghanistan is part of a probe that has ensnared a former ambassador who pleaded guilty to charges of illegal foreign lobbying.

TITLE: Democrat Gavin Newsom to face Republican Brian Dahle in California race for governor
SUMMARY: After swiftly grabbing the top spot in the "top two" primary on Tuesday, California Gov. Gavin Newsom is favored to win reelection in November over Republican state Sen. Brian Dahle.

TITLE: Russia's Lavrov in Turkey to discuss plan to ship Ukrainian grain
SUMMARY: The talks scheduled for Wednesday aim to unlock an estimated 22 million tons of grains sitting in silos in Ukraine.

TITLE: Beefalo, a bison-cattle hybrid, is being touted as the healthy meat of the future
SUMMARY: Supporters cite the beefalo's hardiness, ease of breeding and the leaner, protein-rich healthier meat, but others say the costly crossbreed weakens the genetic line of the bison.

TITLE: Jan. 6 committee Chair Bennie Thompson says the U.S. came close to losing democracy
SUMMARY: Fighting for civil rights and three decades in the House have primed Mississippi's Bennie Thompson for the most high-profile moment of his career — leading this month's hearings on Jan. 6.

TITLE: A deadly church shooting exposes the complexities of Taiwanese and Chinese identities
SUMMARY: A deadly shooting at a Taiwanese church in California exposes rising tensions between Taiwan and China.

TITLE: FDA advisors recommend the Novavax COVID vaccine
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommends the agency authorize another COVID-19 vaccine in the hopes it might entice more people to get vaccinated.

TITLE: How law enforcement could be affected by bipartisan gun reform laws
SUMMARY: What impact would bipartisan proposals for gun reform have on law enforcement? NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Art Acevedo, a former police chief of Austin, Houston and Miami.

TITLE: Retired General investigated in illegal foreign lobbying investigation
SUMMARY: An FBI probe into illegal foreign lobbying has reportedly targeted a retired four-star general who led U.S. and NATO forces in Afghanistan and is now president of a Washington think tank.

TITLE: These Russian couples didn't plan to get married. The Ukraine war changed their minds
SUMMARY: More couples — including those who stayed in Russia and those who fled — are urgently marrying, for reasons both practical and deeply emotional.

TITLE: A car drove into a crowd in Berlin, reportedly killing 1 person
SUMMARY: Emergency responders have kept the man who was driving the vehicle at the scene, according to the Berlin police department.

TITLE: Moderna says its new vaccine booster shows 'superior' response to Omicron
SUMMARY: The "bivalent" vaccine — meaning it targets two different antigens — is Moderna's leading candidate to have an effective booster ready for fall of 2022, the company said.

TITLE: Simone Biles and other Olympic gymnasts will sue the FBI over Larry Nassar
SUMMARY: There's no dispute that FBI agents in 2015 knew Nassar was accused of molesting gymnasts, but they failed to act, leaving him free to continue to target young women and girls for more than a year.

TITLE: Republicans turn to military veterans to help flip control of House in midterms
SUMMARY: GOP candidates with military experience are competing in swing districts. After seeing Democrats pick up seats with a similar strategy in 2018 and fielding veterans in 2020, the party sees an opening.

TITLE: A car drove into a crowd in Berlin, killing 1 person, police say
SUMMARY: Emergency responders have kept the man who was driving the vehicle at the scene, according to the Berlin police department.

TITLE: A U.S. woman pleads guilty to leading an all-female ISIS battalion
SUMMARY: Allison Fluke-Ekren admitted to operating an all-female ISIS military group and training women and girls on how to use explosive devices.

TITLE: Parents of recent mass shooting victims urge Congress to act on gun control
SUMMARY: Parents of children killed and wounded in shootings in Buffalo and Uvalde testified before Congress on Wednesday, imploring members to act quickly on gun control measures.

TITLE: Police arrested an armed man outside Justice Kavanaugh's house
SUMMARY: "The man was armed and made threats against Justice Kavanaugh," the court said in a statement. He was arrested early Wednesday morning near Kavanaugh's home, the Supreme Court said.

TITLE: Police arrest an armed man outside Justice Kavanaugh's house
SUMMARY: An armed man arrested near Kavanaugh's home was charged with "attempts to kidnap or murder, or threatens to assault, kidnap or murder" the justice, according to a charging document in the case.

TITLE: Understanding the complaints from Simone Biles and others seeking $1B from the FBI
SUMMARY: The group of women and girls say the bureau failed to properly follow up on credible claims against the sports doctor Larry Nassar in 2015, which allowed him to continue abusing victims.

TITLE: 'Shrinkflation' accelerates globally as manufacturers quietly shrink package sizes
SUMMARY: Shrinkflation isn't new, experts say. But it proliferates in times of high inflation as companies grapple with rising costs for ingredients, packaging, labor and transportation.

TITLE: Have you faced a bidding war trying to rent an apartment?
SUMMARY: In an incredibly tight rental market, more people are finding themselves outbid in the kind of competition usually only seen with buying houses. If you've experienced this NPR wants to hear from you!

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (June 8)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Moderna says its new vaccine booster shows 'superior' response to omicron
SUMMARY: The "bivalent" vaccine — meaning it targets two different antigens — is Moderna's leading candidate for an effective booster this fall. If the data pan out, it could lead to a yearly booster.

SUMMARY: The site — comparable in size to the Grand Canyon — is about a hundred miles off the coast of New York City. It's home to a number of sensitive species including sperm whales and sea turtles.

TITLE: After a man drowns in Arizona, officials say police aren't trained in water rescues
SUMMARY: Tempe police officers receive no training in water rescues and don't have the equipment necessary to help drowning victims, according to the Tempe Officers Association.

TITLE: Trump is set to undergo questioning in July in N.Y. civil probe

TITLE: The House passes a gun control bill in response to the Buffalo and Uvalde shootings
SUMMARY: It has almost no chance of becoming law as the Senate pursues negotiations focused on improving mental health programs, bolstering school security and enhancing background checks.

TITLE: Thailand decriminalizes marijuana, but not the strong stuff
SUMMARY: Thailand's government says it is promoting cannabis for medical use only, warning that lighting up recreationally in public could still considered to be a nuisance subject to a potential fines.

TITLE: Key questions the Jan. 6 committee will tackle in its hearings
SUMMARY: It's been nearly a year of gathering information - via depositions, subpoenas, hearings, document dumps and court challenges - for the House select committee investigating the siege of the Capitol.

TITLE: A Florida man is accused of $2.5 million COVID-19 relief fraud

SUMMARY: Abortion has been legal in Italy for more than 40 years. But most doctors refuse to perform them, making it difficult to find a provider. As in America, women in Italy fear this right will go away.

SUMMARY: Michael Lowe says he is still suffering from trauma following a 17-day experience in a New Mexico jail, according to a lawsuit filed Monday.

TITLE: Complex Taiwanese and Chinese identities are exposed after gunman enters church
SUMMARY: A gunman who killed one man and shot others exposes the complex identities of Taiwanese and Chinese people.

TITLE: Group aiming to defund disinformation tries to drain Fox News of online advertising
SUMMARY: A group of activists who have taken on some of the biggest right-wing personalities online have now launched a campaign to try to defund Fox News' online operation.

TITLE: A young man in rural Idaho was holding on to a secret. One weekend, something changed

SUMMARY: As a splashy new series begins, the PGA Tour says 17 golfers playing in it "are suspended or otherwise no longer eligible to participate in PGA TOUR tournament play."

SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: The suspect is no longer a threat to the community, officials say. Multiple federal agencies, including the FBI and ATF, have responded to assist local police.

SUMMARY: Ivanka Trump reacted to then-Attorney General William Barr saying that the 2020 election was not stolen.

SUMMARY: "It was carnage, it was chaos. I can't even describe what I saw," says U.S. Capitol Police officer Caroline Edwards.

TITLE: New revelations and 3 other takeaways from the first Jan. 6 committee hearing

SUMMARY: While a growing number of states are trying to address the increasing mental health crisis among youths, many schools are woefully short of therapists and the budget to hire them.

SUMMARY: The iconic Golden Arches have been replaced with two bold orange backslashes and a red circle, representing a tiny burger and a pair of large fries.

SUMMARY: The woman says a man infected her with HPV when they had unprotected sex in his 2014 Hyundai Genesis. She's now trying to enforce a large arbitration award.

SUMMARY: Temperatures will rise into the triple digits across the Southwest and western U.S. this weekend. Daytime temps will be 10 to 20 degrees hotter than normal, according to the National Weather Service.

SUMMARY: The woman says a man infected her with HPV when they had unprotected sex in his 2014 Hyundai Genesis. She's now trying to enforce a large arbitration award.

SUMMARY: Both groups can be seen in the spotlight as abortion and gun violence take hold of the national conversation. Though similar in name, each stands behind different political issues.

SUMMARY: Many women say store shelves that once had the menstrual essentials have been sparse for months. When they are available, tampons have been a lot more expensive recently, due in part to inflation.

TITLE: Abbott's baby formula plant closes again after severe storms and flooding
SUMMARY: Abbott's Sturgis, Mich., plant was open for less than two weeks before it had to close again after flooding from severe weather. The company said it hopes to resume production in a few weeks.

TITLE: Jan. 6 committee plans to ask Ginni Thomas, wife of Justice Thomas, to testify
SUMMARY: The panel will invite the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas to appear after reports that she communicated with a lawyer who pressured Mike Pence to reject the election results.

TITLE: Days of intense heat have killed thousands of cattle in Kansas
SUMMARY: Temperatures topped 104 degrees in the state's top cattle county. In widely seen video footage, rows of carcasses are shown lined up along the edge of a field.

TITLE: Users beware: Apps are using a loophole in privacy law to track kids' phones
SUMMARY: <em>Washington Post

TITLE: Ikea packs up Russian operations and plans sale of factories
SUMMARY: The Swedish furniture giant previously shut Russian stores and now says it cannot see a way to resume operations "any time soon" as the war in Ukraine continues.

TITLE: Jan. 6 committee leaders say Trump broke the law by trying to pressure Pence
SUMMARY: The former president's campaign to get his vice president to overturn the election "was not just wrong," said Vice Chair Liz Cheney, a Republican, "it was illegal and unconstitutional."

TITLE: In a place with little sea ice, polar bears have found another way to hunt
SUMMARY: An isolated population of polar bears in southeast Greenland has learned to hunt on freshwater glacier ice. That means they may be able to survive longer as climate change makes sea ice scarce.

TITLE: The U.S. cities hosting the 2026 World Cup will be announced today
SUMMARY: The U.S., Canada and Mexico will host the first-ever 48-team World Cup. Sixty of the matches will be played at stadiums across the U.S.

TITLE: Elon Musk addresses Twitter staff about free speech, remote work, layoffs and aliens
SUMMARY: Elon Musk addressed Twitter employees for the first time since striking a deal to buy the social network for $44 billion. He did not say whether he was having second thoughts.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (June 16)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: The Dow Jones sinks below 30,000 as fears about a recession grow
SUMMARY: Stocks sank a day after the Federal Reserve delivered its biggest rate hike since 1994.

TITLE: The Google engineer who sees company's AI as 'sentient' thinks a chatbot has a soul
SUMMARY: The Google computer scientist who was placed on leave after claiming the company's artificial intelligence chatbot has  come to life tells NPR how he formed his opinion.

TITLE: A respected conservative judge is now a critic of his party — and former clerks
SUMMARY: Retired federal judge J. Michael Luttig was questioned by one of his former law clerks about the role of another in the insurrection. He hss spoken out against former clerks John Eastman and Ted Cruz.

TITLE: Jan. 6 committee asks Ginni Thomas, wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, to testify
SUMMARY: Ginni Thomas said she would "look forward" to talking to the committee after reports surfaced that she communicated with a lawyer who pressured Mike Pence to reject the election results.

TITLE: Pence prevented a fall into chaos, and 3 other takeaways from Jan. 6 hearing
SUMMARY: The committee laid out how Trump and a lawyer advising him pressured Pence even after Trump was aware there was a riot. The question now is whether Trump could face criminal consequences.

TITLE: Despite warnings from economists, Biden says a recession is not inevitable
SUMMARY: In an interview Thursday with The Associated Press, the president says the American people are "really, really down" after two years of pandemic, volatility in the economy and surging gas prices.

TITLE: American democracy is more vulnerable now than on Jan. 6, Schiff says amid hearings
SUMMARY: American democracy is more vulnerable today than it was on January 6 because the "big lie" that Donald Trump won the 2020 election has spread, says Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA).

TITLE: The Seattle Storm's Sue Bird announces this season will be her last in the WNBA
SUMMARY: Bird has played with the Seattle Storm since being drafted by the team in 2002. On Thursday, she announced that the current WNBA season, her 19th playing, will be her last.

TITLE: The U.S. cities hosting the 2026 World Cup are announced
SUMMARY: The U.S., Canada and Mexico will host the first-ever 48-team World Cup. Sixty of the matches will be played at stadiums across the U.S.

TITLE: Omicron poses about half the risk of long COVID as delta, new research finds
SUMMARY: Some scientists estimate that cases of long COVID from omicron will still rise, however, because of high transmissibility and the misconception that people don't have to worry about catching it.

TITLE: Students in Alaska drank floor sealant believing it was milk, school district says
SUMMARY: At least one child was taken to a hospital after a dozen students were served floor sealant during breakfast on Tuesday instead of milk.

TITLE: Some lawmakers hope to crack down on drag shows watched by children
SUMMARY: Republican legislators in Florida, Arizona, Texas and other states have proposed to ban minors from drag shows.

TITLE: 1 person has died in an Alabama church shooting
SUMMARY: Two others are wounded, police say, adding a suspect was quickly taken into custody.

TITLE: Buffalo shooting suspect says his motive was to prevent 'eliminating the white race'
SUMMARY: Prosecutors release court documents in suspect Payton Gendron's first appearance in federal court on hate crime charges.

TITLE: 2 people have died in an Alabama church shooting
SUMMARY: A third person was wounded, police say, adding a suspect was quickly taken into custody.

TITLE: Golden State defeats the Boston Celtics to win the NBA Championship
SUMMARY: The team completes a historic run of claiming its fourth title in eight years and just two years after recording the worst record in the NBA. The Warriors beat the Celtics on the road 103-90.

TITLE: China upgrades its naval force with its first indigenous aircraft carrier
SUMMARY: The newest ship's capabilities are thought to rival those of Western carriers, as Beijing seeks to turn its navy, already the world's largest, into a multi-carrier force.

TITLE: After more than a decade of accolades and controversy, 'The Wendy Williams Show' ends
SUMMARY: Wendy Williams, who has been the show's original host since its premiere in 2009, has not been on the air following her battle with Graves' disease.

TITLE: U.S. ambassador to Ukraine: 'It's going to be a long, grinding, tough war'
SUMMARY: The U.S. Embassy in Ukraine has been through a lot in recent years. It's just reopened and Ambassador Bridget Brink is overseeing a massive U.S. assistance operation with a limited staff.

TITLE: Who is John Eastman, the Trump lawyer at the center of the Jan. 6 investigation?
SUMMARY: The former law professor's name came up a number or times during the Jan. 6 investigation committee's hearing on Trump's pressure to get his vice president to overturn the 2020 election.

TITLE: Organizing and adding members are top goals for the newly elected AFL-CIO president
SUMMARY: Elizabeth Shuler, the first woman ever elected president of the labor federation, is pledging a massive organizing drive over the next decade, with a goal of adding 1 million new union members.

TITLE: California may require labels on pot products to warn of mental health risks
SUMMARY: A proposed bill would require cannabis products to carry large warnings, similar to cigarettes. But the state's legal pot industry says more rules make it harder to compete with the illicit market.

TITLE: Why cryptocurrencies have gone from the next hot thing to a full-on meltdown
SUMMARY: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies are plunging. Here's what to know about a market that just a few months ago was being touted as the future of finance.

TITLE: Black baseball players struggled long after Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier
SUMMARY: <em>After Jackie

TITLE: Companies are selling Juneteenth branded products. Here's why that's a big problem
SUMMARY: Brands and companies are working to remove their Juneteenth items from shelves, as experts say those who are selling Juneteenth-branded products are "tone-deaf."

TITLE: Americans support student loan forgiveness, but would rather rein in college costs
SUMMARY: A new NPR/Ipsos poll finds majority support for forgiving $10,000 in federal student loan debt, but even broader support for making college affordable for future students.

TITLE: Critics say campus sex assault rules fall short and need an overhaul
SUMMARY: On the 50th anniversary of Title IX President Biden is expected to announce new rules governing the protection of sexual assault and harassment accusers in education.

TITLE: The U.K. says Julian Assange can be extradited to the U.S. to face spying charges
SUMMARY: WikiLeaks said it would appeal. The decision is a big moment in Assange's years-long battle to avoid facing trial in the U.S. — though not necessarily the end of the tale.

TITLE: Commission recommends making Ukraine a candidate for European Union membership
SUMMARY: The European Union's executive arm on Friday recommended making Ukraine a candidate for EU membership, a first step on what was expected to be a long road for the country to join the 27-nation bloc.

TITLE: Bartees Strange explores his journey from 'Farm to Table'
SUMMARY: In an interview with <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Eurovision winner Ukraine can't host next year's contest because of the war
SUMMARY: Public broadcasters and security experts concluded it's not feasible for the war-torn country to host, organize and produce the event. They're now turning to the U.K., which placed second this year.

TITLE: Vince McMahon steps down as WWE CEO while the company investigates alleged misconduct
SUMMARY: Vince McMahon's daughter, Stephanie, will lead the wrestling company during the inquiry. McMahon, accused of paying $3 million to cover up an affair, still will control WWE's creative output.

TITLE: There's a nationwide Sriracha shortage, and climate change may be to blame
SUMMARY: The company that makes Sriracha told customers it will have to stop making the sauce for the next few months due to "severe weather conditions affecting the quality of chili peppers."

TITLE: Poet Amanda Gorman reflects on what lies beneath the celebrations of Juneteenth
SUMMARY: On Sunday, the U.S. commemorates Juneteenth, which marks the effective end of slavery in the country. NPR's Leila Fadel talks to poet Amanda Gorman, who reflects on the day and reads a poem.

TITLE: Coronavirus FAQ: Should I still take a COVID test before flying into the U.S.?
SUMMARY: This week, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ended the COVID-19 testing rule for air passengers traveling to the U.S. from abroad. Should you still take a COVID test anyway?

TITLE: Will Julian Assange be extradited to the U.S.? Where his case stands now
SUMMARY: The WikiLeaks founder will face 18 federal counts — whenever he's brought to a U.S. courthouse in Virginia. For now, he has at least one more avenue of appeal.

TITLE: Gabby Giffords is still fighting for gun violence victims, years after she became one
SUMMARY: Former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords was shot in the head more than a decade ago, but this week threw out the first pitch at Fenway Park as part of its Gun Violence Awareness Day.

TITLE: Poet Amanda Gorman celebrates the gift of Blackness for Juneteenth
SUMMARY: To mark the holiday, Gorman reads "Fury and Faith," a poem from <em>Call Us What We Carry.

TITLE: 'On Juneteenth' historian examines the hope and hostility toward emancipation
SUMMARY: Juneteenth celebrates the day slavery ended in Texas, June 19, 1865. Historian Annette Gordon-Reed studies the early American republic and the legacy of slavery. <em>Originally broadcast May 25, 2021.

TITLE: The U.S. Capitol has named two rooms after female senators for the first time ever
SUMMARY: Sens. Barbara Mikulski and Margaret Chase Smith couldn't wear pants or use the main bathroom during their tenures, when female senators were scarce. Rooms in the Capitol now honor their legacies.

TITLE: Russia's Putin lashes out at the U.S. and claims victory over sanctions
SUMMARY: The Russian president blamed the U.S. for fostering crises in global relations, food security, inflation and trade. He also said he had no objection to Ukraine's bid to join the European Union.

TITLE: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (June 17)
SUMMARY: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: What's open and closed on Juneteenth
SUMMARY: The federal holiday will primarily affect government offices and buildings.

TITLE: COVID cases are upending cycling, and the Tour de France starts in 2 weeks
SUMMARY: "It's just crazy," Welsh cyclist Geraint Thomas said at the Tour de Suisse on Friday, after around 30 riders were forced to abandon the race.

TITLE: A British journalist's remains have been found in Brazil's Amazon, police say
SUMMARY: Human remains found deep in Brazil's Amazon have been identified as belonging to British journalist Dom Phillips, according to Brazil's federal police.

TITLE: The FDA authorizes COVID-19 shots for infants and preschoolers
SUMMARY: The vaccinations for children as young as 6 months old could start next week. But first, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention must sign off.

TITLE: EBay seller says coins depicting Haitian migrant incident at border may be sold again
SUMMARY: The coins depict the now-infamous, real-life incident of a Border Patrol agent on horseback chasing down Haitian migrants along the U.S.-Mexico border last year.

TITLE: Flight cancelled? Pete Buttigieg is telling airlines to step up their game
SUMMARY: The transportation secretary is one of the many travelers who had their flights cancelled in recent days. His happened the day after he met with airline CEOs about their operational struggles.

TITLE: Sikh temple in Afghanistan rocked by explosions, gunfire
SUMMARY: Several explosions and gunfire ripped through a Sikh temple in Afghanistan's capital on Saturday morning

TITLE: Gaza rocket into Israel breaks 2-month lull, Israel responds
SUMMARY: Palestinian militants fired a rocket into southern Israel early Saturday. Hours later, Israeli aircraft carried out a series of airstrikes.

TITLE: In a time of national division, polarizing primaries are part of the problem
SUMMARY: It is said the best medicine for what ails democracy is more democracy. But what does more democracy mean? If it just means more of the kind of politics we have now then it hardly offers a remedy.

TITLE: Sports betting ads are everywhere. Some worry gamblers will pay a steep price
SUMMARY: Gambling on sports has becoming a billion-dollar industry in the U.S. But critics warn that the torrent of ads — and limited regulation — could pose risks for problem gamblers and young people.

TITLE: Bill Cosby civil trial jury must start deliberations over
SUMMARY: After two days of deliberations, jurors in a civil trial who were deciding on sexual abuse allegations against Bill Cosby will have to start from scratch on Monday.

TITLE: 18 dead in India, Bangladesh floods; millions without homes
SUMMARY: At least 18 people have died as massive floods ravaged northeastern India and Bangladesh, leaving millions of homes underwater and severing transport links.

TITLE: A new exhibit takes visitors closer to the National Museum of the American Latino
SUMMARY: The National Museum of the American Latino in Washington, D.C., won't be finished for another decade, but a pop-up exhibit from the museum has opened on the National Mall

TITLE: Europe wilts under early heat wave from Med to North Sea
SUMMARY: A blanket of hot air stretching from the Mediterranean to the North Sea is bringing much of Western Europe its first heat wave of the summer.

TITLE: At least 1 killed in attack on Sikh temple in Afghan capital
SUMMARY: Several explosions and gunfire ripped through a Sikh temple in Afghanistan's capital on Saturday morning.

TITLE: A Philadelphia firefighter died in a building that caught fire and collapsed
SUMMARY: Four other firefighters and an inspector with the city's Department of Licenses and Inspections had been rescued from the rubble and were in stable condition at hospitals.

TITLE: Uvalde officials are using a legal loophole to block the release of shooting records
SUMMARY: After 19 children were killed at a Texas elementary, law enforcement officials have given little information. They're now using the "dead suspect loophole" to prevent the public release of records.

TITLE: PBS NewsHour commentator Mark Shields dies at age 85
SUMMARY: Mark Shields, the longtime commentator known for his weekly political analysis and sense of humor, has died at the age of 85, <em>PBS NewsHour

TITLE: Biden falls while getting off his bike after a beach ride
SUMMARY: President Biden fell when he was getting off his bike after a ride near the beach in Delaware. He quickly collected himself and the White House said he is "fine."

TITLE: Vaccinations for children 6 months to 5 years old can begin after CDC clears the way
SUMMARY: CDC advisers are recommending the use of two separate COVID-19 vaccines for the youngest children made by Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech, paving the way for vaccine rollout as early as next week.

TITLE: Poor People's Campaign rallies in Washington to mobilize low-income voters
SUMMARY: A few thousand activists, advocacy groups, and religious leaders protested in Washington, D.C., on Saturday. They are calling for what they say is a Third Reconstruction.

TITLE: CDC clears the way for vaccinations for children 6 months to 5 years old
SUMMARY: CDC advisers are recommending the use of two separate COVID-19 vaccines for the youngest children made by Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech, paving the way for vaccine rollout as early as next week.

TITLE: Former federal judge warns of danger to American democracy
SUMMARY: NPR's Adrian Florido speaks with retired federal judge J. Michael Luttig about his testimony during a recent Jan. 6 committee hearing.

TITLE: Apple workers vote to unionize at Maryland store
SUMMARY: Apple store employees in a Baltimore suburb voted to unionize by a nearly 2-to-1 margin Saturday, joining a growing push across U.S. industries to organize for workplace protections.

TITLE: French voters elect parliamentarians, in test for Macron
SUMMARY: French voters are going to the polls in the final round of key parliamentary elections that will demonstrate how much legroom President Emmanuel Macron will be given to implement his domestic agenda.

TITLE: Tight Colombian runoff pits former rebel, millionaire
SUMMARY: Voters in Colombia will choose between a former rebel and an unpredictable millionaire when they vote in a presidential runoff that promises to reshape the country.

TITLE: A French city approved burkinis in its pools. Then the backlash came
SUMMARY: The city of Grenoble's move to allow the full body-covering swimsuit for Islamic women has sparked a legal battle. Activists say it's a matter of civil — and women's — rights.

TITLE: For many dads, the COVID pandemic brought new perspectives on fatherhood
SUMMARY: With the pandemic giving fathers working from home a chance to spend more time with their kids, dads look back on how they've maintained the balance between their jobs and their families.

TITLE: Juneteenth is a jubilant celebration — and a sacred lament
SUMMARY: On Sunday, Churchgoers will celebrate Juneteenth during their worship services. Members of the clergy reflect on the role of the church and the holiday marking the notification of the end of slavery.

TITLE: On Juneteenth weekend, Black activists march for abortion rights
SUMMARY: Black abortion rights leaders say reproductive justice and racial justice are inextricably connected.

TITLE: Three single, gay dads reflect on fatherhood, surrogacy journeys
SUMMARY: For Father's Day, NPR spoke to three, gay single fathers who made the choice to become parents via surrogacy.

TITLE: Crypto billionaire says Fed is driving current downturn
SUMMARY: FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried says that, until investors get used to higher interest rates, risk assets, including cryptocurrency, won't recover.

TITLE: Vincent Chin was killed 40 years ago. Here's why his case continues to resonate
SUMMARY: Forty years have passed since Vincent Chin was killed. But today's wave of hate incidents against Asian Americans make what happened in 1982 even more relevant in the fight for civil rights.

TITLE: Yellowstone National Park will partially reopen Wednesday after historic floods
SUMMARY: The park has been closed since floods washed away roads, damaged buildings and knocked out water and power to parts of the park and communities nearby. The park's northern loop will remain closed.

TITLE: Oxford High School students sue for changes after deadly mass shooting last year
SUMMARY: The federal lawsuit in Michigan requests a "fully transparent and independent third-party investigation" into what led to the shooting as well as other policy changes.
